Sir,

English name
Age
Name of Band
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid
Father's full name and No.
Mother's full name and No.
Parents living or dead
State of child's health
Religion
Does applicant speak English?
Previously attended school for years

(Signature of father)

Re: Children for Moose Fort School

Further to, Mr. Clark phoned me, after calling you, all is clear and will adjust itself.

On the Mistassini kids, bad weather caused us difficulties, finally ending with 20 kids at Cochrane and 16 at Oskalence. Cochrane got excited (or desired a little publicity), at Cochrane, I am of the opinion it was no trouble to look after these 20 kids.

Those left at Oskalence (Oskalence was out of flour, bread, etc., when the strike came on) 16 kids, I removed by aircraft on Sunday, provided for at Amos, at hospital, nurse was in-charge of the kids, the kids themselves had lot of fun out of all this.

Others are at home, that is 54 from Waswanipi and other points, as soon conditions return to normal they will moved by normal and usual means of transportation.

Had we not been caught with bad weather, all the Mistassini kids would have been landed at Moose Fort, on time, before the strike went into effect.

1. Mr. Clark took care of the children at Cochrane - D and escort Miss. Midlige all at Moosonee now.

2. Nurse at Oskelance, with 16 kids, had to be removed, on Amos, via Senneterre, this work was done combined with other Agency affairs.

3. From Amos, we transferred to Moosonee, the 16 kids by air, one trip with permission from Department of Transport, to take number desired, providing we would not exceed maximum weight allowed for mileage to be done.

Above cleared all Mistassini children, the total cost, won't exceed very much, the regular transportation.

Mr. Clark requested our aircraft to proceed to Neskana, to take out via Senneterre a Mr. Jackman, Teacher, our aircraft landed at Neskana, found party out fishing instead of standing by waiting. Pilot requested instructions, I advised to return to his base at once. He waited in view to leave, etc., but found he was away by about 15 miles, so it was useless to wait extra time. The Pilot had to make Waswanipi for the night, weather bad, Miss. Midlige returned with him, on an Agency combined trip Miss. Midlige was returned to Oskelance.

As regard the Waswanipi children, waiting at home, further to telephonic conversation, they will be sent out direct from Waswanipi to Moose Factory, from Senneterre to Waswanipi trip both ways, will be combined trip, medical etc., usual run, Department of Transport is being requested to authorize, on same condition as we did for the Mistassini kids, One trip only.

.........................
Air Transport for stranded pupils, Moose Fort Residential school.

On Friday morning, August 25, I visited the office of the Austin Airways in South Porcupine and contracted with the pilot in charge for two and one-half trips (Cochrane to Moose Fort and return) to handle the twenty children and escorts.

I escorted the first flight of children and was quite busy on route with air-sick children. Miss Fur Supervisor F.C. Racicot accompanied another flight, and the original escort, Miss Eva Molodge of Oskelano, also was flown to Moose Fort where she rode back to Amos in a plane that brought sixteen children from Amos. This plane may also have taken Mr. Jackson from Timiskwa to Amos.

On the last trip from Moose Fort to South Porcupine I brought out the two summer school teachers, Mr. Spurs and Miss McQuillan. Dr. Cosack of Health Services came out at the first opportunity.

We might have saved one trip by getting Air Transport Board authority to over-load the plane, but I thought you would prefer not to attract criticism of the handling of Indian children. Besides, phone calls require special permission and I would have had to negotiate with a Toronto office.

In all 36 children were transported (20 from Cochrane and 16 from Amos). On the phone Mr. Sept. Lariviere told me he would defer sending the remaining 24 of his quota until the railroads are again operating.

CAT Clark

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re David Koomayuk, Disc No. 24-364, Eskimo age 15

In February, 1949, a fifteen year old Eskimo boy, David Koomayuk, was flown by mercy plane from Creasewell Bay on Boothia Peninsula to the Dr. Charles Gamsell Memorial Hospital in Edmonton suffering the loss of both feet from gangrene. Since then he has been fitted with artificial limbs and is now able to move around quite freely. During his stay in hospital he has been taking advantage of the educational opportunities provided, and has learned to talk English fairly fluently already. He has received considerable amount of publicity due to his rather extraordinary progress for he is considered particularly brilliant. He has started Grade 3 arithmetic and in his reading has almost completed his Grade 2 reader.

Unfortunately, a short time ago he contracted a slight case of tuberculosis, but this has been cleared up and Dr. Falconer advises that the boy will be ready for discharge about January 1, 1951.

I am attaching herewith a copy of a letter I am sending to Dr. Moore. In this you will notice that the suggestion has been made that David should be placed at Moose Factory in order that he can attend the school there and also have the benefit of the medical service available at the hospital. Furthermore, he would be in the company of other Eskimo people and would possibly have the opportunity to work into a job that he could handle satisfactorily.

Colonel B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Capitol Theatre Building,
OTTAWA, Ontario,

Ottawa, November 18, 1950.

Dear Dr. Moore:

I have received a copy of Dr. Falconer's letter to you dated October 10 in which he advises that the above-named Eskimo boy, approximately fifteen years of age, should be ready for discharge about January 1, 1951. The question of David's immediate future was discussed between Mr. Bailey of this Administration and Dr. Falconer recently when it was learned that Dr. Falconer was not too anxious to see this boy return to the rigorous climate of the north too early. He suggested that it would be preferable for this young Eskimo to be placed in a residential school for the next year or two if possible close to a medical centre.

The problem of this boy's placement has been discussed with both Dr. Simpson and Dr. Procter, the latter of whom suggested that David might be sent to Moose Factory where he could attend school and be close to the hospital there. Furthermore, he might very well work himself into a reasonably good job either as an interpreter or clerk. At the same time being at the gateway to the Eastern Arctic, it might be easier to obtain a position for him in one of the Hudson's Bay Company posts if that became possible at a later date. Dr. Simpson has stated that he is in agreement with such a plan.

It would be appreciated if you would ask Dr. Falconer to discuss this matter with David and ascertain whether this plan would be agreeable to the boy. In the meantime, a copy of this letter will be sent to Colonel Neary, Indian Affairs Branch to determine whether some arrangement might be made at Moose Factory for him at the school.

Yours very truly,

Dr. P.A. Moore,
Director of Indian Health Services,
Department of National Health & Welfare,

Ottawa, Canada.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd inst., along with copy of letter received from Miss Jane Mark, with regard to the above referenced Indian youth.

Rev. Seismiller, Principal of the Fort Residential School, on several occasions, complained about the conduct of this boy in school and felt that he was unmanageable. To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Admission of pupils to Residential School

The question of returning our children to their families was settled this morning following telephonic conversation with Mr. Clark.

As regard returning them to residential school, selecting etc., our quota, I would greatly appreciate hearing from you, if at all possible by first week in August. Our last arrangement was as follows:

1. Selecting children - Based on our medical records, free of T.B. and fully protected against contagious diseases - preventable by vaccination - also of a certain degree of intelligence. This to be done by AGENCY.

This method has given best results - none of our kids died etc., since.

2. Transport arrangement.

3. Can the children return home - every summer.

4. The Residential school should favor us with results - Examination at end of year - indicate degree of intelligence, etc., for I feel a child cannot learn anything at school, it is useless to keep on sending him, when others could replace and do well.

At Mistassini and Waswanipi, we have reached the stage now, only children of school age, about 7, are available, this class is well protected etc., considering number ready, we can select among the most promising kids.

Thanking you in advance, I am leaving today for Mistassini, to return Amos on about July 1st.

This fills the school but does not give the promising children an opportunity of advancing as quickly as they should. Moose Factory, Ont.,
November 26, 1951

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 2nd inst., along with applications for Admission to the Moose Fort Indian Residential School, which have been returned for parents signature.

The parents of these children are scattered throughout a wide area in the James Bay District and we are unable to have the necessary signatures attached. The majority of these children come from the Abitibi Agency and any attempt to locate the parents, the expense of same would be prohibitive. It is therefore recommended that these be accepted for this year and the Principal will be instructed to see that all documents are properly signed when picking up these pupils next year.

I am therefore returning Applications for Admission as I feel that by the time we would be able to contact the parents of these children it would be probably sometime next summer.

J.S. Allan
Superintendent
James Bay Indian Agency
Department of Citizenship & Immigration

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Fault Ste. Marie, Ont.,

I have a letter from Mr. J.S. Allan, Superintendent Indian Agency, Moosonee, Ontario requesting a transfer of Charles Cachagee from the Moose Fort Indian Residential School to the Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

This boy has completed Grade 8 education and is interested in continuing with his Grade 9 work. This boy has a brother who has completed Grade 7 and will be taking Grade 8 work this coming term. Mr. Allan has requested that he be transferred with his brother.

Please advise whether sufficient space is available in the Shingwauk Home and whether the Principal is prepared to accept the two boys.

for Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
August 11, 1952.

Mr. J.S. Allan,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Moose Factory, Ont.,

With reference to your letter of August 4th regarding the transfer of three children from the Moose Fort Indian Residential School to the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, you are advised that we are writing Superintendent Laurence regarding Charles and Michael Cachagee asking him whether sufficient space is available in the Shingwauk school to accept these two boys.

When we hear from Mr. Laurence you will be advised accordingly.

With reference to Jean Davies our records indicate that this girl is only in Grade 4 and is 14 years of age and we do not see any necessity for her transferring to the Shingwauk School. If this girl is considered to be a problem case, it is hardly fair to the Principal of the Shingwauk school to transfer her to his school as it is likely that he has similar cases to contend with.

For Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

School Attendance of Children
of Chief Frank Pelletier

Under date of August 10, Chief Frank Pelletier wrote
to the Director as follows:

"As I live a considerable distance from Fort
William, my children find it very hard going back and forth
to school. If they are to have success in school they
should be in a boarding school where they can put all their
mind on their school work. I can't move closer because I
have my work to do to support my family. I would appreciate
it very much if you would grant your kind permission of
putting them in Spanish School."

You are requested to report as follows:

(a) What are the ages of these children?
(b) What school are they attending?
(c) How far is it from their home?
(d) How do they make the journey?
(e) Is there any other day school which they could appropriately
and more conveniently attend?
(f) Are there any other considerations which might require the
admission of these children to the nearest residential school?

C.A.R.C.
C.O.C. to Mr. F. Matters

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attached hereto copy of a letter which speaks for itself.

I am taking advantage of the fact that our nurse is escorting child Roman Petawabano, of Mistassini, to the school, to bring about a definite check on our children taken care of at that point.

This year, it has been a proper mix-up. The Indians at Mistassini particularly delayed their departure for their trapping lands, which caused poor feeling, etc. At Hanunipi, the same difficulty was experienced, but it was not so serious. During summer it was understood with Bishop Clarke I would be given definite quota early in August, and date of admission to be definitely fixed, with that it would have been easy to arrange and cause no friction. We know nothing yet about the children who were returned to school; it follows we are running into complications, parents, family allowances, etc., etc. We understand the staff is changed at Moose Factory school. However, through our nurse, we hope to establish a definite record. On her return, copy or 'em.

H. Lariviere - Superintendent

The Director,

Dear Major McKays:

I am enclosing the ten applications of Protestant children to the Fort George Roman Catholic Residential School to which I referred in my telephone conversation yesterday.

I have wired Mr. Allan as per the attached copy of telegram and in conversation with him today requested that he place as many as possible of these children in the Moose Fort Residential School.

This may tend to cramp the living space at Moose Fort but it were far better to have the school crowded for the balance of this winter than have these children remain in a school other than their own religious denomination. Dear Mr. Matters:

Complying with request contained in your wire of Saturday, October 18th, I have to advise you as follows:

I discussed with Father Houle, on Tuesday morning, the question of transferring these children from the Fort George P.C. Residential School to Moose Port. He stated that he had not received any word from the Bishop. In this connection and would be contacting him in the evening. I explained to Father Houle that this was the wishes of the Department but I would be willing to detain my flight to Fort George for a day or so in the event that there may be any further developments. Not hearing from father Houle by Saturday, I arranged for the trip to Fort George and left in the evening reaching Rupert House where I stopped over for the night. I arrived at Fort George at 12:35 Sunday morning and immediately made contact with Father Couture, presenting your wire regarding situation of the children now in his care. He informed me that he would not release these children without the authority of the Bishop and he also stated in any case they would not be able to return with me due to the fact that they were on a picnic. He further stated that he would only release the children on the authority of the Bishop or the parents of the children. Due to the fact that it was the close of the season and the pilot was afraid of being frozen in we had to return immediately without the children.

After my return here, Father Houle informed me that two of the children were in hospital and four had been returned to their parents at Fort George. The other 4 children belonging to Rupert House would be returned to their parents at Rupert House by plane or snowmobile. Father Houle advised me that he had
received this information from Father Couture through the Hudson Bay Co. radio and he would send me a letter of confirmation. To date I may advise that no confirmation has been received.

Yours truly,

J.S. Allan
Superintendent
James Bay Indian Agency

Dear Reverend Sir,

In connection with admission and discharge of Indian children attending Bishop Horden School, we find the admission date as fixed now is a cause of difficulties to all concerned. To solve the problem you suggest that the school close on June 15th and re-open on August 15th. I think this would be in line with the needs and prevailing conditions at Mistassini and Waswanipi, as it appears you cannot overcome the fact that the staff must have two months off, also the children.

I suggest that you discuss the matter with Reverend Bishop Clarke and Reverend Canon Cook, and if you can arrive at something definite refer the matter to the Superintendent of Education in Ottawa.

The Indians at Mistassini particularly must get on the move to return to their trapping lands by early August, and they cannot very well leave children with others trapping closer to Mistassini awaiting for transportation and so on. The same remark applies to Waswanipi, although here they can wait a few days, etc.

When at Mistassini and Waswanipi recently arrangements were made for children to return and be on hand for dates as called for by you, I might add the Indians at Mistassini were not too happy about it.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Moose Factory, Ont.
June 26th, 1942

The Officer Commanding,
ReCo Division,
Ottawa, Ont.

In the early morning of June 20th I left Moose Factory with Doctor T.J. Orford, Indian Agent, aboard the Department of Indian Affairs' Motorboat "Charles Bowyer", enroute to Fort Albany, Ont.

We arrived at Fort Albany the same evening, after a delay in James Bay, caused by Doctor Orford giving medical attention to an Indian who had accidentally shot himself at Lake River, Ont., a week previous, and who was being taken to Moose Factory in the ReCo Motorboat "Joy He".

The whole of June 21st was spent holding a full meeting of the Iroquois Band of Anglican Indians, at which all band matters were fully discussed.

On the same evening we left for Lake St. Anne, some 4 miles up the Albany River, where the Roman Catholic Mission School is located, and where we spent the night at "Honor".

The next day, June 22nd, a Board of Inquiry was held into the deaths of three Indian boys while truant from the ReCo Mission School; this is covered by a separate report.

After the Inquiry a full meeting of the Roman Catholic Band of Indians were held and all matters pertaining to their welfare gone into. During the evening numerous Indians received medical attention from the Doctor.

No complaints calling for police action were received.

Adverse weather delayed our return to Moose Factory until June 25th, when we left in the early A.M. and arrived at Detachment at 10:30 P.M.

Days on Patrol - 6
Mileage - 200

Expenses - Nil

The Commissioner,
R.O.M.Police,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Attention: Dr. F.E. Moore

With reference to your letter of January 20th, John Sutherland died in Lady Minto Hospital, Cochrane, January 8th, of Tuberculous Meningitis.

I was called to the School at Moose Factory to see him on December 19th. The day previous he had complained of a frontal headache and was put to bed with a Temperature of 101F. Before this time he had apparently been without any complaints.

On examination I found a very well nourished boy with absolutely no objective signs or symptoms of disease. He said he had occasional headaches and his Temperature had risen to 102F. He was immediately moved to the Hospital, on December 19th. On Dec. 20th there was some irregularity in the eye reflexes and he was somewhat irritable and had vomited once. The diagnosis of Meningeal infection was tentatively made but on examining his ears I found a fly imbedded in the left canal against the ear drum. There was peripheral inflammation of the drum and the vault of the canal was tender and blod easily. On pressure over the Mastoid area there was tenderness. The fly was removed, warm irrigations of boracic solution begun and he was given Sulphathiazole. After 48 hours there was no change and there seemed to be more Mastoid tenderness. Considering the possibility of a slow acting Mastoid infection which would require surgery I sent him to Cochrane December 25th, with his Father as escort, recommending to Doctor Empye that he keep in mind that the apparent ear condition might be masking a Tuberculous Meningitis.

When I phoned Dr. Empye about the boy's condition a few days later the Mastoid infection had practically all cleared up and the evidence of his Meningitis was clearer.

In July 1943 on chest X-ray minimal active Tuberculosis was discovered in the right lung and he was recommended for rest by Toronto. He was kept in Hospital here to February 1944 and returned to School in greatly improved condition with a gain of 12 lbs. in weight. May 1944 X-ray showed the previous evidence of Tub. had cleared up—the report from Toronto reading—"This case was previously diagnosed as Pulmonary Tuberculosis, minimal, active, but there is no definite evidence of parenchymal..."
infiltration now."

From then until the time of his last illness he had had no symptoms of disease and appeared to be healthy. He was due for re X-ray this month along with two other School boys who had previously been under treatment for Tuberculosis. These other boys have been X-rayed but reports from Toronto have not yet been received.

Experience convinces us that the only way in which Indians of this country can be permanently elevated and thoroughly civilized, is by removing the children from the surroundings of Indian home life and keeping them separate long enough to form those habits of order, industry, and systematic effort which they will never learn at home.

The proposal that boys should spend the last two years exclusively in learning trades, and attend school at night, is, in my humble judgment, impracticable, so far as the latter part is concerned. As a rule, Indian lads have no great love for study, and after having worked at a trade all day it will be very difficult.

For nearly thirty years there was no vacation, and the pupils were supposed to be in the school every day. During that period not one of them ever obtained a certificate as a public school teacher.

This seemed the advantage of a graded school.

The senior classes were given four full days in the school each week, and two days to the different branches of industry. The junior pupils averaged three and a half days in school, and two and a half days at the different industries.

At the same time the summer vacations were commenced, and were limited to six weeks, with two weeks off for Christmas.

It was found however, that the winter vacation was impracticable as the pupils lacked the clothing necessary, and the Christmas vacation was added to that of the summer, making the two months.
Four years ago, the vacation was extended three months, beginning from the third Wednesday in July to the third Wednesday of October.

To make up for this, it was decided to have school every Saturday afternoon, and to have the teacher present for one hour each evening to assist the pupils in the study of the lessons for the following day.

To all these changes the Indian Department consented, and the results have justified its action. Twenty pupils have obtained certificates in eight years, while for thirty previously there was none, while there has been an equally marked improvement in the different branches studied.

As regards the Nitrogen in Nitrates, the amount is so very high as to call for special explanation. It has been determined by two independent methods, so that no error of work can account for these high numbers. Nor can I believe that they represent the true character of any naturally occurring water. I am therefore driven to conclude that the bottles (stopped Winchesters) need as containers have originally contained Nitric Acid and have not been properly washed out. It is remarkable that all the samples (and notably numbers 2 and 3) have a decidedly acid reaction—which seems to favor the explanation suggested. If the Nitrate Nitrogen found by
me, is actually present in the water, it must be held to indicate past sewage pollution to a frightful and most dangerous extent.—But this I am not prepared to admit—

Judging from the other results of analysis, Sample No. 2 is to be regarded as distinctly objectionable, and probably dangerous. The Chlorides and phosphates as well as the ammonical nitrogen point to sewage.

The other samples are not altogether above suspicion of pollution; although the absence of marked traces of phosphates, make it possible that the nitrogenous pollution may have a vegetable rather than an animal origin. While I do not feel at liberty to condemn any of these samples (Nos. 1, 3, & 4) absolutely, I cannot pronounce any of them as safe or desirable sources of supply.

Precautions to be observed in procuring Water Samples for Analysis.

Two Winchester Steppered Bottles are to be used for each sample. (Stone-ware bottles should not be used.) They are first to be rinsed out then filled about one-third full with water and some coarse sand and shaken continuously for several minutes; they must then be again washed out and show themselves perfectly clean. In filling them with the sample water they are first to be rinsed out with it several times, then once completely filled and emptied, and after this has been done again filled with the water for analysis and securely stoppered; the stoppers should not be sealed, but firmly and securely tied over, either with a piece of cloth or, after the manner of druggists, with leather, and the string sealed with sealing wax, that the water may not be tampered with in transit. If the water is taken from a tap, enough should be pumped or allowed to run to waste to thoroughly clean the pipes. In taking water from a pond or river the bottle may be filled by plunging it beneath the surface so as to avoid any sown or floating material. The accompanying label should be filled up and affixed to the bottle.

This does not include debt on account of improvement, of which I shall speak later. If we had a larger farm without paying rent it would put us in a different position. Two hundred and four acres is the amount of land belonging to the Institution for which we do not pay rent; the other land we occupy is rented from Indians through the Department, and after paying the rent and making use the fences (as we have to do) and properly tile draining the land the profits are comparatively small.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Rev. Mr. Shepherd, Principal of the Mount Elgin Institute, Muncey, calls the attention of the Department to the requirements of this school, referring first to the insufficiency of the per capita grant.

This school was established more than fifty years ago and was placed in charge of the Methodist Missionary Society by whom it is still conducted, the Department contributing a per capita grant of $60 per annum to assist them in carrying it on. One hundred pupils are authorized to receive this grant, making the total contribution of the Department $6000.00 per annum. It must be admitted that $60.00 a year is not a sufficient sum for the maintenance and education of these pupils and unless such grant is supplemented by liberal contributions from the Methodist Missionary Society, or the earnings of the institute, financial disaster is bound to overtake the school. Mr. Shepherd, in his endeavor to make up the required difference has gone very extensively into stock farming, and, as he says, after the most careful economy, he is unable to make ends meet, the deficit on last year's transactions being $86.19. His statement of Receipts and Expenditure for the year ended 30th June 1902 does not show that he received any money from the Methodist Missionary Society.
Society, beyond the sum of $6000.00 sent to it by the Department. It may be therefore taken for granted that the Methodist Missionary Society does not contribute anything towards the support of this school, although so long as it remains under their control, they are bound to make up the deficit. This Society has other pressing calls on its funds and last year it withdrew its contributions to the day schools in Ontario, which were formerly carried on under its auspices. This leaves Mr. Shepherd to rely upon the Departmental grant and what he can make from his farm, which with the land attached to the institution and that rented from the Indians, comprises 504 acres. Mr. Shepherd has to pay rent for 300 acres of this land as well as keeping up the fencing and other improvements, all of which is quite a drain on his earnings, to say nothing of the expenditure of energy on the part of his pupils, who are, as he says, of necessity unwarrantably industrious! The care of over two hundred head of cattle, which chiefly involves an the pupils, entails more work than is good for them and leaves no time for other farming operations which they should be taught and in the interest of the school I consider that Mr. Shepherd's stock operations should be largely curtailed, even if it affects the income derived from this source. As the school cannot fall back upon the Methodist Missionary Society for aid, and they receive no contributions from other sources, it naturally looks to the Department to come to its relief. Mr. Shepherd asks that the present grant be doubled and if the school is to be kept up to a proper state of efficiency, a substantial increase will have to be provided. Experience has shown that it is difficult to finance a...
upon even the largest per capita grant.

In the second place the Principal calls attention to the needs of the school in the way of buildings and repairs and asks for a grant of $2500.00 which the Minister has authorized. I may mention, however that the item of $1000.00 for material already expended is presumably for the construction of a large concrete stable for stock. This was require to furnish accommodation for his extensive operations in this direction. The other items appear to be for reasonable expenditure. In fact there are other requirements for which Mr Shepherd has not asked a grant and which I consider are absolutely necessary. The building set apart for the boys recreation room needs extensive repairs in the way of new flooring and some provision for bathing and ablutions. When I was at the school in September last I found that they had no bathing facilities except the water of the Thames in summer and wash-tubs in winter, taking their morning wash at the pump. Baths should also be placed in the laundry for the girls; the baths in the main building are not for the use of the pupils. The new building is a very handsome structure but the out-buildings are not at all in keeping with it and certainly want renovating, as a survey of the present premises presents a showy front and a shabby back.

Mr Shepherd was away when I visited the school, having taken his family to California and returning by way of Winnipeg to attend the Methodist Conference. the crop with the assistance of the hired men and 24 boys who had remained at the school during vacation. There were also 23 girls at the school. Any additional grant that is made should be conditional upon an entire change of the present system of conducting the school. All the boys attending this institution come from reserves where farming could be successfully carried on and yet I was informed by the teacher in charge that none of them had ever handled a plow or were even allowed to drive a harrow as time could not be spared to teach them. The boys of this school are indeed hardworking not only working but are being worked, and they as well as their parents see the difference, hence the numerous complaints which reach the Department of ill-treatment of pupils. I saw the meals that were served, and while plentiful, they were not at all inviting and the pupils made of eating did not speak very well for their training in table etiquette. The supply of clothing on hand was scanty and well worn, but I was told it would be replenished after the Principal's return.

Even at the risk of being considered too insistent I cannot help again expressing the opinion...
that the system of training pursued at this and other schools requires careful revision, as it is little less than a waste of time and money to follow the present methods as there is little use in our educating an Indians if, in our endeavor, we spoil a horn and fail to make a spoon. That our schools have failed in their object is generally admitted. I think I can point out why they have failed and make some practical suggestions as to their improvement is called upon to do so.

Mr. Macdonald's report on Caradoc Bay.

The Caradoc Bay Industrial School was visited up to May 6th in connection with the question that smallpox existed in the vicinity of the reserve. Upon turning up there, I had the opportunity to see how many of the children had been vaccinated before they came to the school. It was found that many of them had not received the inoculation. MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Supt., General,

In connection with the Rev. Dr. Sutherland's application made in a personal letter addressed to you on the 23rd July last for an increased per capita grant for the Muncey Institute, I beg to say that I have on several occasions pointed out that the contribution of $60.00 for each pupil by the Government to the Industrial Schools in Ontario is quite inadequate to meet the increased cost of living at the present day, and I think the desire of the different denominations conducting these schools to be placed on a better financial basis is only fair and reasonable, and that $100.00 per capita would not be an excessive amount to allow.

With reference to Mount Elgin School I may say that under management of the late Mr. Shepherd the school was carried on with a very small deficit: it was considerably less than $100 a year. This economical management is accounted for by the methods pursued by Mr. Shepherd who was extensively engaged in stock raising and feeding cattle for the market. To such an extent did he carry on these operations that I have no hesitation in saying that he sacrificed the interests of the school to make both ends meet. Rev. Mr. George who succeeded Mr. Shepherd about a year and a half ago has, as appears from his statement of receipts and expenditure for the year ended the 30th June accumulated a deficit of $3,498.40 since he has had charge of this school, and I think it would be well for the Department to examine carefully into his financial transactions and management with a view to discovering how this deficit occurred. My own impression is that he has lost on his cattle transactions and it would take a very skilful drover to carry on Mr. Shepherd's work in this line.

When I was at this school two years ago I found that nearly all the energy of the school was directed to the care of
of stock, and if Mr. George has let this run down in the interests of the school, he is hardly to blame. I think that if the grant were increased the Church would make no demand on the Department for the payment of the deficit, and if the cattle transactions were curtailed, it would be an advantage to the school as nearly all the pupils' spare time is taken up in attending to the live stock while their industrial training is neglected. Sir,

Re Muncey Industrial Institute.

Some three years ago, the Rev. W.W. Shepherd, then Principal of the Mount Elgin Institute, brought to the notice of the Superintendent General the impossibility of maintaining the Institute on the existing per capita basis, and strongly urged a substantial increase. Mr. Shepherd informed me that the Minister frankly acknowledged the justness of the claim, but was not prepared at that time to make the desired increase until the whole question of Indian Institutes had been more fully considered. For a number of years Mr. Shepherd was able, by extensive dealing in live stock, to earn sufficient to prevent the heavy deficiency that otherwise would have occurred; but the trade in live stock is a very fluctuating and uncertain source of income, and during the past two years very heavy deficiencies have occurred in carrying on the work. We think that these deficiencies, in so far as they represent legitimate work done by the Institute, should be met by the Indian Department, and such substantial increase made in the per capita grant for the future that the Principal may not be hampered in his work and worried by ceaseless endeavor to keep out of debt.

I would respectfully request, therefore, that the Department grant such relief for existing deficiencies as may seem just and reasonable, and that the per capita grant be increased to at least One Hundred Dollars ($100) per annum.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Yours obedient servant,

A. Butler,
General Secretary.

In further reference to your letter of the 5th ult., complaining that Mrs. Nahdee was refused permission by the Principal of the Mt. Elgin Institute to see her adopted son, James MacDonald, a pupil of that school, I beg to say that a report has been received in regard to this matter which fully exonerates the Principal from any blame in connection with his action.

The school authorities make no objection to parents, relatives or guardians seeing pupils at certain times and conditions, but they do rightly object to clandestine interviews with pupils, which always have a disturbing effect, and in the instance of this boy a previous secret interview led to his desertion. Report of the Rev. T. Ferrier

MOUET ELGIN INDUSTRIAL INSTITUTE
April 24-6, 1906.

STAFF.
The staff appear to be doing well and working harmoniously together, and it is just a question whether another likely member should not be added to the same; there being no laundress, nor seamstress and the matron has no assistant.

CHILDREN.
One hundred and three boys and girls were in attendance to meet us; they bright, healthy-looking children. They appear to be well-fed, but their clothing is hardly up to the average.

PROVISIONS.
A very large supply of clothing - rich and provisions in one hand, our farm is fitted out to be for the proper equipment of an Institution of this kind.

STOCK.
Cattle. A herd of about two hundred and thirty-eight head of pretty fair cattle. Some twenty-four of these are ready for beef, and have been sold on hoof for five cents per pound. The outlook is that quite a number will be ready for next year's market.

Some of the younger stock are not looking as well as we shall like to see them. There is considerable ringworm among the calves, notwithstanding preventatives and cures have been applied.

Horses. About thirty horses, a few of which are not in the best condition, they having the appearance of not being properly grain-fed.
Hogs. From eight to twelve sows are kept for breeding purposes, and a large supply of pork is furnished.

Hens. About one hundred hens. These could be made more profitable if the number were increased and a more up-to-date henry provided.

Bees. Appear to do well, there being about eleven hundred pounds of honey on hand from last year's stock.

FENCES. There is about a thousand acres of land under the control of the Institution, and such a large herd of cattle and horses with so many neighbor's interests to protect, the question of fencing is one that ought to receive due attention.

Two miles of new fencing has been done of late; some of it by fire and some by replacing the old rail fence. These rail fences are of short duration and are constantly needing repair. The length of new fence will be about that which would be made practicable by repairs, I had not tome to estimate. The Principal informed me that the wire fence costs about 40 cents per rod. This will be the most economical fence for the two hundred and twenty-five acres belonging to the Institute, also for all lands where the lease has a number of years to run, and for those lands where a new lease is a strong probability.

SEWERS. During the past three years some repairs and changes have been made to the sewers. The sewer leading from the stable wing of the main building to the river has been diverted so as to empty into the river. This was a necessity since it existed without an outlet from the end of the building; it being kept with the intention of using it as a fertilizer which was found to be impracticable.
WATER SUPPLY.

Until recently there were three tile drains: 1st, One draining the surface of the land used for a garden situated close to the south-west of the main-building; 2nd, One draining the swamp three-quarters of a mile south-west; 3rd, One draining the springs from the hillside, about half a mile to the south—all three uniting in a well in the yard from which the supply of water was taken for all purposes. As this supply of water from the garden and swamp was likely to be impure, unwholesome and very undesirable, the arrangement has been changed and the good spring water from the hillside is gathered in a manhole and driven from there by a hydraulic ram into the main building, thus furnishing a continual stream of pure water for all domestic purposes.

The water from the garden and swamp flows continually into the troughs situated at convenient points in the stock-yard and into drinking-panes in the stables, furnishing an abundant supply for all the stock.

An extensive system of drains from the west delivers water on the side of the hill, which is a little back by a cement dam, and from which a portion flows through a two-inch pipe to a man-hole, giving sufficient power to keep in motion a hydraulic ram that drives to the attic of the main building a constant stream of sufficient volume to supply the laundry, bath-room, closets, etc., for fire protection.

In order to complete this entire water and drainage system, I had brick (not hewn or cured) laid that about three million of bricks were used. The tile laid at the top of each pile of brick stood fast. This involved a vast amount of labor and the whole system has been carried out with considerable hydraulic skill, and is a decided success from a two-fold point of view.
1st, These drains drain a large area of land thus making it more valuable for agricultural purposes.

2nd, They furnish an abundant supply of water for all purposes, and for this there will be but little cost for many years to come.

FIRE PROTECTION.

The whole Institution is practically without any fire protection, and the main building without any fire escapes.

There are two small water tanks in the attic of the main building. Another large tank should be built that will hold as great a volume as can be sustained by the floor of the attic. These three tanks should be all connected so as to allow the water to syphon from one to the other and will be kept full by this constant stream.

If four or five thousand gallons can be sustained, a 3" stand pipe should be let into the flats below. There should be a system of pipes to carry it to two different points on each floor, and then connected, hose of sufficient length to reach any part of the flat. This would furnish some protection. The advisability of installing a chemical outfit is worthy of consideration. For the main building fire escapes should be constructed.

BUILDING.

The building, some changes in the most affecting the girl's comfort and portion used for stores and bakery have been authorized by the Department, and when completed will be installed in accordance for convenience in the general work of the kitchen, library, the keeping of supplies, coal etc., and at the same time for the privacy and comfort of the girls.

When the house-cleaning is done, with a good general whitewashing of the walls and ceilings, on all those portions
that are not painted or papered, it will add to the sweetness and the general appearance of the interior.

Three sets of outside steps are worn out and rotting away, and must be replaced by new. The two on the east should have their position slightly changed in order to prevent shading the light of the kitchen windows.

The heating is by hot-water plant that appears to be in good condition and to give excellent results except in some rooms to the north-west in extreme weather. The radiation surface is not sufficient at these strategic points and should be increased.

The closet in the men's bath-room is without a breathing pipe; this ought to be remedied at once.

A limited supply of soft water is obtained from the seven-inch tank tank whenever it reaches a depth of over five inches. This tank is served by a small well in the back, which is damaged by the freezing of the water from the cold private water. This should be remedied by strengthening the old tank or building a new one.

Ventilation. A small 4" pipe in each dormitory has just been put into already overtaxed smoke-flues for the purpose of drawing air from the most important point in each, and it is in a position where the incoming vent will not come more than three feet from the inside of the building. In any case, it is all that could be accomplished by such a method and is far from being adequate, since it does not provide the air-breathing part of the volume that ought to be systematically taken from the entire building; and no provision whatever is made for supplying fresh air except by the use of open windows. In the interest of the health of the pupils and the staff this ought not to be continued.
INSTITUTE BUILDING.

This building is occupied by the families of two employees, and is also used for two school rooms. These schoolrooms are heated by a hot-water plant which is too weak to do the work and has to be supplemented by a stove in each. They have been without ventilation until recently, when two 7" galvanized iron pipes have been placed to draw air from the floor to the smoke-flues. This provides an exit for some of the foul air, but no provision is made for a supply of fresh air. While this has been accomplished at a small cost, and is an excellent scheme to the extent of its power and is about as strong as the flues will permit, yet, the fact remains, it is far from being sufficient, since the air, when the windows are closed, becomes stifling. If caging so many children in such, practically, unventilated buildings during the winter months does not break down the general health of the pupils and staff, it is more a matter of good fortune rather than of a good policy.

LAUNDRY & BOYS' PLAY-HOUSE.

A new steam boiler has been placed in the laundry and the old one discarded, and none too soon, for it was so badly rusted that it could be punched in places by a screwdriver. The boys' play-house is under repairs. These two buildings can be placed in good condition by the improvements which have been authorized and the amount already granted by the Department.

NEW PIGGARY.

A new piggery that will accommodate seventy-two hogs was built last year, also a NEW CATTLE STABLE sufficient for sixty-eight head.

Some substantial repairs have been made to the horse stable which holds twenty-two horses.
The work in these new buildings and in the repairs is well executed. The buildings have excellent concrete foundations, well ventilated, and with many conveniences that will tend toward the saving of labor and the comfort of the stock.

**BIG BARN.**

This building needs to be tied from eave plate to eave plate, for one of the main cross beams is badly cracked, and the plate of the north-side has broken one of the chief posts and is pressed out with the broken portion. These ties are a necessity before another crop is harvested.

The foundation beams and posts in this barn are in a bad state of decay. Two long beams from end to end were placed in last year; this postponed the much-needed and more extensive repairs, including shingles, which will have to be attended to in a year or two at the most.

There are three silos—one of them is about rotten. The position they occupy prevents the utilizing of the space in the barn to the best advantage when threshing a harvest.

When these posts and beams are placed in the foundation of the barn, the whole of the cattle stable should be rearranged and fitted up, and in doing this, one of the doors should be taken out, and if a thorough job is to be made of the barn and stable all three silos should be taken down and new ones placed at such places as will leave the entire space for granary, threshing and mowing purposes.

**SMALL BARN.**

This building is in need of some repairs. One of its largest beams is broken at a very strategic point and must be strengthened by a new post or replaced by a new beam, and it will also have to be reshingled in the near future.
SAPOR WORK-SHOP. This has a good strong frame. The foundation sill on the west side is about rotted away. The building should be raised and placed upon a concrete foundation and its many needed repairs attended to.

The undersigned was asked for an opinion on the advisability of removing this building over to the east side of the laundry. It would be more convenient on this new side, and much easier watched, since it now stands in the territory occupied by the boys for sport, and if placed by the laundry the power of the steam engine could be utilized at times to a great advantage in the work-shop. There is one serious objection to placing it there, and that is, it is of such a size and of such combustible material that, in the event of fire, it would make a strong connecting link between the barns and the two main buildings. The large number of sheds and outbuildings should have covered a much larger space than they do, and all changes of their position should tend toward expansion of the territory occupied.

DRIVE HOUSE. The drive house or implement shed requires some repairs and new shingles.

OTHER OUT-BUILDINGS. The lumber-shed, ice-house, wood-shed and coal-shed are all in a dilapidated and tumbling-down condition, and the only remedy is to take them down and rebuild.

The repairs authorized for the boys' play-house and laundry including a new steam boiler for the latter will be fully met by the $200 appropriated by the Department. The $800 assigned for repairs to the main building will fully cover all improvements sanctioned except fire pro-
tection; it may also furnish material for the three sets of outside steps, soft water tank, breathing pipe for closet and material for general house-cleaning.

The necessity of fire-protection, fire escapes, increasing the radiation surface of the hot-water plant in the north-west portion of the main building, some system of ventilating dormitories and school rooms, the numerous repairs required to the barns and out-buildings, also fences are all of great importance and will have to be attended to in the near future. I would, therefore, recommend that a detailed statement of all these essential improvements with accompanying specifications of work and material required, together with a careful estimate of the cost, be presented in a business-like form to the Indian Department for their information and consideration, and I am sure that all reasonable and necessary requests will be favorably considered on their merits, providing they are assured that good material will be used, the work executed according to specifications and the money voted from time to time be expended for such improvements as have been authorized by the Department.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Yours obedient servant,

(Signed) T. Ferrier.

My dear Mr. Pedley,

Permit me to call your attention again to the great importance, and indeed urgent necessity, of an increase in the per capita grant for the Mount Elgin Institute. For many years this grant has been entirely insufficient and those in charge of the Institute have been compelled to make up the leeway by extensive dealings in live stock. This is very unsatisfactory, and involves risks which the Principal should not be required to assume. The reasonableness of an increase in the grant was freely admitted by the previous Superintendent General, and the arguments in favor of such a course are quite as strong today as they were then.

I think the very lowest figure at which the per capita grant should be placed is £100 (One Hundred Dollars) per annum. With this amount, plus the proceeds of the farm, the institute could be maintained in efficiency without the risk involved by speculating in live stock.

I expect to be in Ottawa on the 8th or 9th of November and would be very glad to see the Superintendent General or yourself respecting this matter and any other matters pertaining to our Indian Schools.

Hoping for a favorable issue, I am,

Yours faithfully,

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Re Mt. Elgin Institute.

Complaints have lately been received from parents of Indian children at the Mt. Elgin Institute, reflecting on the management of that institution, and a short time ago Mr. Calvert, M.P., forwarded correspondence addressed to him by Jacob Fisher, demanding the return of his daughter from that institution on the ground of ill-health. Fisher's letter to Mr. Calvert was accompanied by a medical certificate, which stated that she was suffering from incident pulmonary tuberculosis and a general weak condition of the system and recommended her removal from the institute for proper care and medical attention.

The Principal was written to for a report regarding this case and he sent in a medical certificate from the regular attendant of the school, Dr. Norris, who said that he found her in good health and free from any active disease and taking into consideration the healthy surroundings he was of opinion that her remaining in the institution would be more beneficial than detrimental to her health. Mr. George, the Principal, in his
report gives it as his opinion that, owing to the girl's ability and qualification to earn good wages as a domestic, the father wishes to have her under his control and that he experiences the same difficulty in retaining girls over sixteen on this account.

Another letter was received last week from Mr. Fisher, through Mr. Calvert, renewing his application for his daughter's discharge.

From the correspondence it would appear that something more than the alleged illness of the daughter is influencing Fisher in this case, and a telegram has just been received from Mr. George, stating that the institute kitchen was set on fire by Lottie Beaver, who says that Winnifred Fisher, the girl above referred to, told her to do so. Luckily no damage occurred and Mr. George has asked for instructions.

I think that, under the circumstances, an immediate inspection of this school should be made.

I first interviewed Dr. Lawrence of St. Thomas (where I was obliged to wait over for train connection). Dr. Lawrence formerly practiced among the Indians about Mt. Elgin Institute. He stated that scabies always existed more or less amongst these Indians. There was a predisposition to it where people were housed up in small houses and particularly in the winter time. About two years ago he sent a large quantity of ointment to Mr. George as a remedy for this disease.

Mr. Sheppard was Principal of the Institute, scabies was very bad. Children were taken home and cured and when they went back caught it again. He frequently attended patients in the Institute then and knew of this but cannot speak of conditions under present regime, although he has frequently heard Indians complain still. Dr. McEwen says the drainage at the Institute is good and the water should be good. The situation is very healthy. There is no Doctor nearer than 7 miles.

The same evening I called upon Jacob Fisher the father of Winnifred Fisher. Fisher stated that he had no complaint whatever against the Institute other than as to its management.

His complaints are (1) Pupils are punished by being put to work during school hours when they should be at school, citing the case of Nelson Peters a Delaware from Six Nations who although at the Institute has not been in school for the past two years. (2) Pupils do not get enough to eat, and the same food is placed on the table day after day until it is eaten or becomes too stale or bad for food except when visitors are expected when the pupils get an extra good meal. (3) Pupils are made to nurse the sick and sometimes tubercular patients. Said his daughter had to nurse a child who died of tuberculosis and she afterwards contracted the disease. There is no tuberculosis in his family. (4) Parents are not notified if children get sick. (5) Has seen body lice in heads of pupils when at Church. Thinks pupils are left to wash themselves, without sufficient supervisions. "There is no body lice in our people at their own homes".
He did not know of any itch but said some pupils had skin diseases on their necks, a sort of acrofula. Knew nothing of the fire or its cause.

I then called on Chief Joseph Fisher a brother of Jacob's. He said he had no children at the Institute. Some people will always complain and are never satisfied. He thinks the Institute is well managed and there is no cause for complaint. His brother's child Winnifred won a foot race after returning from her visit to Dr. Cairns (who declared she had insipient tuberculosis) therefore he thinks she could not have been very sick.

Dr. McEwen was with me when I made these two visits and informed me afterwards that Jacob Fisher was a chronic grumbler and that Chief Joseph Fisher was one of the most intelligent Indians on the Reserve. He also stated that Dr. Cairns was not a particularly reliable physician, was said to be a drug fiend, and had little weight in the profession.

Dr. McEwen is of opinion that he should be called in to attend patients from his own Reserve.

Next morning (Tuesday) I saw Andrew McGahy who had a boy at the Institute last year very ill. He alleged that he or some of his family had to go to the Institute every second night to nurse his child while the Matron took a night off to rest. The child got worse and worse and nothing was done for him so that at last he determined to take him home and get his own Doctor to attend to him, but it was too late, for the child died soon after getting home. His charge is that the boy did not get proper attention.
I also saw Murray Henry an Indian who was loud in his denunciations of the treatment of the pupils. He had none there himself but knew of several cases. None of these Indians had any complaint about the prevalence of scabies.

On Tuesday morning I met Mr. Sutherland the Agent at Muncey who drove me out to the Institute. Dr. McEwen told me that Mr. Sutherland would not hesitate to fully inform me of any cause of complaint if any existed, but evidently he is well satisfied as I could not get confirmation of any of the complaints above mentioned.

Dr. Morris of Delaware is his own and also Mr. George's family physician and is most attentive to his patients. He has telephone connection between his house and the Institute and can in his motor car reach them in 20 minutes if necessary.

It was about 11:45 before I informed Mr. George of the object of my visit as we were walking from the barn to the house. He asked me if I would like to see the children at dinner and when I said yes we went into the dining room. He said he knew no more than I did what they were going to have. Each child had a plate well filled with potato pie, plenty of gravy and a small piece of meat, four half-slices of bread, but no butter, and water to drink. Mr. George said they had milk as far as it would go, at every meal, if there was any, but sometimes they were short. There was abundance of the potato pie left over in the kitchen and I noticed that the children got a second supply if desired.
I think there was sufficient food.

The first question I took up was the fire in the kitchen. Mr. George showed me statements written and signed by Lottie Beaver, Annie Comego and Lottie Nicholas respectively.

Lottie Beaver stated that she was asked by Winnie Fisher to light the fire in the kitchen. After supper about 7 o'clock she went into the kitchen, took some paper out of a warming closet in the range set light to it through the stove door and placed it among some shingles used for kindling wood against the wainscoting. While doing so Annie Comego was watching at an outer door and Lottie Nicholas at another door. Winnie Fisher stood at the kitchen door told Lottie Beaver to "hurry up" and after she had done it & asked her if it was done and Lottie said yes. Annie Comego confirmed this; the other girl was too far away to hear what was going on. I then had the girls brought in individually and cross-examined them and they all confirmed what they had written, but Mr. George said that Winnie Fisher said more to me than he could get her to admit viz., that she told Lottie Beaver to "hurry up" but Winnie persisted in saying that she did not ask Lottie Beaver to set the place on fire while the other girls all said they were asked to do what they did by Winnie. Lottie Beaver is a heavy stolid girl, who could probably be easily led, and influenced by fear if necessary, while Winnie is a small nervous child strong willed and aggressive, and sharp. The girls were told by Winnie to say if found out that she
(Winnie) was in the clothes room changing her clothes. They would give no reason for the fire other than that they wanted to see it burn. I am of opinion that Winnie Fisher was the ring leader, that Lottie Beaver did the deed, but that the other girls Annie Comego and Lottie Nicholas though accessories, were not aware of what was actually going on or what was intended. Mr. George thinks the Fisher girl was put up to it by her father or some outside influence, but I do not think so, though perhaps she may have heard her father or others say "I wish the whole place would burn down" or something to that effect, which may have suggested the idea to her.

On the other hand I do not think there was anything in the daily surroundings or treatment of the girls to cause them to do the deed. In answer to a question Winnie told me she was happy at the school did not want to go home, got plenty to eat and did not have to work too hard. I think it was just a sudden attack of wickedness which came over the girl probably caused indirectly by complaints against Mr. George and the School which she was no doubt hearing every time she went home.

The fire in the barn last January Mr. George states was started by a boy in the belief that if the place burnt down he would get a holiday. The boy had been punished and was chaffing under discipline.
The fire in the boys play house in November was clearly incendiary, but happened about 3 A.M., when all the pupils were up in their rooms. Mr. George says it cannot be charged to the pupils.

With reference to the charges made by Jacob Fisher I took particular pains to question his daughter closely on these points. She said she had plenty to eat that day, was never hungry. Her food was good, and there was no bad food given to them. She was not sick and did not feel sick.

Admitted winning the foot race after returning from her examination by Dr. Cairns. Had not to work too hard. Some days she worked in the laundry and some days at something else.

Did not have to nurse a sick girl, but only stayed in the room with another girl so that if the sick girl wanted anything she or the other girl could run for the matron. The sick girl, who had tuberculosis, was able to attend to her own immediate wants up till Sunday when she died. She had paper cones for her sputa which she wrapped up herself and put in the fire. Winnie was there off and on from Friday morning till Saturday night. The child died on Sunday. In view of the circumstances and the standing of the two physicians concerned I think that Dr. Morris's certificate should be received as containing the true statement of facts regarding Winnie Fisher's health.

None of the children had any sores on their faces or bodies but when questioned further she said there was one, naming her, who scratched her arms, but
no others. I had this girl brought in, and saw a pretty healthy crop of scabies on her arms, chest and back. The matron informed me that her instructions were that no other child was to use her towels but she said it was almost impossible to prevent it. This was the only case in the school and they thought it must have been contracted at the girl's home. There were occasionally cases of it, but nothing more than might happen in any white public school.

With regard to Jacob Fisher's charge that a boy was 2 years at the Institute and not once in school Mr. George admitted this but said Nelson Peters, the boy in question was a good boy in most ways but when he was sent to school he always ran away, and after recapturing him several times Mr. George came to the conclusion that he would let him go for good the next time, as he could not afford to pay out so much Constable's fees and get no returns. He then suggested to the boy that he stay and work in the fields with a team and not go to school, and he has had no further trouble with him, but the moment school is suggested he rebels. Mr. George therefore concludes that it is better to teach the boy farming than have him run away for good.

The boy Mr. Gahey was full of disease when he came to the Institute and shortly after took to his bed and steadily declined despite the Doctor's care. Towards the end the parents persuaded him to let them come and sit with the boy, but as they smoked so much tobacco in the boy's bedroom did more harm than good, he refused them admission again. They then
insisted on taking the boy home, though Dr. Norris said it would be fatal. The case was fatal anyway but he had more comforts at the Institute than at the home.

Naturally when he got home he died soon after and the parents blame the Institute for his death, because another Doctor said he could cure him. There is no case against Mr. George on this charge.

I stayed at the Institute from Tuesday morning till Wednesday morning and had every opportunity of noting how affairs were managed.

The children appear bright, clean and happy. They have their sports after hours. All the boys take turns at different kinds of field work. One group today will be hoeing mangelas, while tomorrow they may be helping with the hay. The girls likewise change about. One girl waits on the Principal's dining table for a month, another on the officer's dining table, another helps the cook and so on giving each a turn, and varying their experience and occupations.

The discipline appears good, though not so strict and military-like as I believe is the custom at the Mohawk Institute. Mr. George strikes me as a man of great earnestness and enthusiastic in his work, and is doing his work faithfully and well.
The close proximity of the Reserve is the cause or most of the trouble I think. A boy after four when his duties are over, will skip away home across the fields perhaps two miles away and get back by six. They meet their parents at Church every Sunday, their friends and relations sometimes surreptitiously join them in their walks and if there is discontent it is kept alive by this means of communication. A boy quite clean has returned after one of these short visits infected with body lice. While I was there parents came asking permission to see their children. They join them in the play ground and in fact are hanging around the neighbourhood more or less all the time.

The sanitary condition is good. The kitchens, bakeshop, lavatories &c are clean and tidy. The barns yards and stables are clean and tidy and Mr. George appears to spare neither himself nor his officers in the discharge of his duties.

The only recommendation I have to make in regard to the management is that no pupil should be asked, in fact it should be forbidden, to attend any patient, suffering from tuberculosis, or even to enter the room where such a patient is, and I also think that greater precautions should be taken to prevent the spread of scabies by contact with towels clothes &c than is now done.

As to the fire I think some punishment should be inflicted upon Winnifred Fisher and Lottie Beaver though it may be difficult to satisfy a magistrate that the Fisher girl is guilty. The other girls are
practically innocent of wrong doing. Lottie Beaver has been confined to a separate room ever since the fire and the matter should be attended to without delay.

I will report on the matter if needed in improvements under separate cover.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum for
Deputy Superintendent General.

In view of certain complaints received from parents of Indian children attending the Mt. Elgin Institute reflecting on the management of that school, Mr. Superintendent Smith of Brantford was sent there to make an inspection and report.

Mr. Smith's report which deals very fully with all the matters complained of goes to show that the school is in his opinion well managed. He makes one or two recommendations which it might be well to have carried out. The principal reason for sending Mr. Smith to the school was in connection with an outbreak of fire which was said to be the work of an incendiary. Mr. Smith obtained ample proof that the fire was set by one of the girl pupils at the instance of another girl named Winnie Fisher who is a daughter of Jacob Fisher, one of the strongest opponents of the school. Mr. Smith goes fully into the case and recommends that some punishment should be inflicted upon these two girls, although he says it would be difficult to satisfy a magistrate that the Fisher girl is guilty. She made a catapaw of Lottie Beaver who actually fired the building and if she could escape punishment there would be very little use in proceeding against the Beaver girl who is only a tool in her hands. In fact I do not think it would be a wise policy of the Department to bring...
either girl before a magistrate; if conviction was secured they would most likely be sent to prison, which would do them more harm than good. In my opinion their punishment should be left to the Principal. The whole trouble appears to be that Jacob Fisher was anxious to get his daughter away from the school and he is more to blame than either of the girls. Fortunately the fire did little or no damage.

Another complaint refers to the prevalence of scabies in the school and Mr. Smith found only one case and it was thought that this must have been contracted at the home of the girl who was affected. There have been occasional cases, but nothing more than might happen in any white public school. On the whole Mr. Smith's report is favourable to the institution and he thinks that the proximity of the school to the reserve is the cause of most of the trouble.

He concludes by recommending that pupils should be forbidden to attend any patient suffering from tuberculosis and it would be well to instruct the Principal to this effect and that greater precautions should be taken to prevent the spread of scabies.

It would be well if the minds of the Indians could be disabused as to the treatment of pupils at this school. The Gibson Indians, who are all Methodists and have had several children in attendance, are especially bitter against the Principal and I would suggest that Mr. Supt. Macdonald should be instructed to inform these Indians when he next visits the reserve of the result of Mr. Smith's inspection, and that Agents Sutherland
and McDonald be given similar instructions.

My dear Mr. Pedley,

On my arrival here from Ottawa word is to hand from the Rev. S.R. McGivney stating that he will accept the principalship of the Mount Elgin Institute. REPORT OF THE MONT NIGIN INSTITUTE.

August 7th, 1909.

I spent from July 29th to August 7th at the School. The time was occupied in stock-taking and assisting Mr. McVitty in his initiation to the many duties devolving upon him as Principal of the Institute.

Mr. Shannon has made a careful audit of the books and accounts up to June 30th. This audit shows that the income for the past year was $13,659.42 made up as follows:

Missionary Society. ................. $10,000
Government Grant for Mission. ....... 1,758
Sale of cattle, horses, etc. .......... 1,701.42

The audit also shows a deficit of $4,618.90. If to this is added a normal loan of $1,000 from the Missionary Society and the increase of $4,000 from the Board over and above the Government grant, we have a total deficit of $13,618.90 all of which has been paid by the Missionary Society. From this it will be seen that the grants of $10,000 which were made by the Board for last year will have to be the minimum annual grant for main chance for the future.

It is therefore clear that the time has come when the Government grant must be increased from $100 to $170 per pupil.

The taking of stock took up the greater portion of the time at my disposal, and a complete inventory of all chattels to other with the value of the same is herewith given. From this it will be seen that the total value of the stock is $12,000.00 which is $6,000.00 less than that given by Mr. George. This difference is accounted for by the following:

1. I have not included any part of the plant in my statement.
2. The former valuation is, in my judgment, very much beyond its real value.
3. A number of the farm and garden implements are absolutely worthless and have been so entered.

These articles I have had moved out of the buildings, sheds and yard to a private lot on the farm, their room being of more value than they are to the school. Mr. McVitty may be able to dispose of some of them for a pittance to the Indians, but he must have only value as scrap iron, and he ought to receive instructions as to what he should do with them and have them removed for they have disgraced the premises long enough.
Report of the Mowat Plain Institute, August 7th, 1910.

The live stock has been severely culled and all that were suitable disposed of. The books show that since June 14th, $4,126 for horned cattle and $1,375 for horses have been received.

About one-half of the milch cows are not of much use for milking purposes and are too light and poor for beef; only four of them were known to be with calf on July 1st. There were 35 cows milking at the beginning of July, and no cream was got for the month of June was 17.6%, and for the previous month 16%. The low returns are partly due to a lack of supervision of the milking. A new man has been put in charge of the stock and the revenue from this source will be increased.

250 pounds of wheat were sold in June with only about two weeks' flour on hand.

Potatoes have also to be purchased for 1 ton to use, and with only four acres in crop means that the most of the year's supply and seed will have to be provided.

The selling of so much of the live stock when pasture was abundant is a serious handicap on the chances of profit from the herd for the next year or two.

I have looked up some of the leases containing certain lands used by the Institute. Some of these are numbered, and the following may be information:

LEASE NO. 236. - Is for 47 acres and runs for 14 years at a rental of $8 per annum. This land lies east of the Institute and controls the water supply.

LEASE NO. 235. - Is for 27 acres and runs for 16 years at a rental of $15 per annum. This land lies to the north east and is also needed for control of water supply.

LEASE NO. 212. - Is for 50½ acres, rent $40 - This land is east of LEASE NO. 236, and has 6 years to run.

LEASE NO. 220. - Is for 40 acres, rent $12 and has 5 years to run.

LEASE NO. 241. - Is for 60 acres, $200 rent paid in advance for 7 years. Runs out May 1st, 1911.

LEASE NO. 201. - Is for 60 acres at $20 per year - runs for 5 years.

LEASE NO. 200. - Is for 170 acres at $1,200 for ten years - paid in advance. This lease expires March 1st, 1910. Its renewal is a necessity, because:-

1. It is needed for pasture being the most valuable we possess.

2. All the land in the valley belonging to the Institute would be of no value without it because of the problem of fencing which has to be done on both sides of the river above the flood line.
