The sale of $461 worth of live stock in the latter half of June, reduces the liabilities against the Institute. At the same time it has left the stock in such an unsatisfactory condition that something must be done to replace a portion of it this fall. There will be food sufficient to winter about 130 head. I would therefore recommend that a loan of $100 be advanced to the Principal to purchase about 30 stock cattle and some good cows.

The Main Building, the two large barns, stables and hog-pen are in a good state of repair, but all the other out-buildings and sheds are in a neglected condition and will soon need to be rebuilt.

The bath tubs in the laundry are of wood and not plumbed with the rain. They are about used up and unnecessary. New iron tubs and two steam boilers should be installed at once, and an additional amount of $100 more for material which can be used to good advantage during the balance of this Fiscal Year.

Rev. J. R. McVitty and his excellent wife have taken up the work in an energetic and beautiful spirit.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

T. Ferrier
My dear Mr. Pedley,

I enclose herewith a copy of my Report of the Mount Elgin Institute. When in Ottawa I left a stock-sheet of all the chattels with the Department. You will see that the Missionary Society have had to pay $13,618 (Thirteen Thousand Six Hundred and Eighteen Dollars). The position I have taken with our Board is that when we agree to run any Institution, on a per capita basis, with the Government, that all deficits should be paid by the Church. Up to date this has been done, but I feel that the time has come when the grant for Muncy must be changed from $60 to $100 (Sixty Dollars to One Hundred Dollars) per pupil. I believe it to be next to impossible to run it satisfactorily on a smaller sum of money. It is true that for a number of years it was run without much additional cost during Mr. Sheppard's time, but then it must be remembered that in those days the stock market was much better and a more reliable asset to the Institution than it is today, and further the wages that were paid in those times are no longer adequate to get suitable members on the staff; also the class of goods that were used for clothing would not be acceptable to the Indians, and the same thing may be said regarding the food that used to be provided; these together with the fact that the purchasing power of money is not as great as it was ten or fifteen years ago make the advance a necessity.

I believe that this Institution can do a good work in the education of Indian boys and girls for many yea...

Deputy Superintendent General,

The question of increasing the per capita grant paid the Mt. Elgin Institute is again brought to the attention of the Department in Mr. Ferrier's letter of the 10th instant. It is clear that these institutions in Ontario cannot be conducted upon a grant of $60. per capita and that such assistance must be largely supplemented by those who are interested in the educational work amongst the Indians. The representations of Mr. Ferrier in the interests of the Mt. Elgin School cannot be considered by themselves. Better treatment if accorded to this institution must also be extended to the others. The Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie has been compelled, owing to lack of funds and our failure to meet their request for an increased per capita grant, has been compelled to curtail its operations, to cut down its staff &c; and upon the present scale it hardly amounts to anything but a small boarding school. The R. C. School at Wikwemikong, with the largest number in attendance of any school in Ontario, is not in such financial straits as the others, but would certainly expect the increased grant if it were to be given anywhere. The Mohawk Institute at Brantford is hardly in the same position as it is partly supported by the New England
Company. In some late recommendations which I made I suggested that the per capita grant might be increased in Ontario to $85.00. Upon this basis it would be necessary for us to find funds for the following pupils:

Rev. Dr. Sutherland,

Dear Bro-

Your favor of the 7th inst. to hand I am gratified that
the Department is moving in the right direction. I am sorry they
did not see their way clear to go a little further and make the
grant $160 per cap. as Mr. Faivier recommends. After nearly six
month's close study of conditions here I am fully satisfied it
will take at least that amount to run the school successfully.
The school has been seriously handicapped in the past and its
usefulness much lessened by lack of funds.

Permit me to submit to you the following facts:

1. We own but 280 acres of land all the rest is rented. We
are practically on a rented farm. I am applying this week
for renewal of a lease - which means payment in advance of $1470.00.
Yet this is land we cannot do without. It lies right across the
river from the Institution. It is our cow pasture.

2. It has become almost impossible to get efficient officers and
teachers without paying very large salaries. Our head teacher is
receiving $600, free house heated and milk for use of his family.
His hours are from about 7 to 9 seven days of the week. I know he
is offered a position in a white school at same salary - hours from
9 to 4 p.m.

The position of Cook in our upper kitchen is vacant. I have
replied to fifteen persons advertising for position of cook etc., not one of them would accept the position even at a good salary. It is too confining and trying. Mr. McVitty has been forced to take it for past month or more.

3. The price of food has increased enormously and the pupils and their parents are much more exacting than formerly. A five cent meal for a pupil would mean $4.75 per year, leaving $5.25 for clothing, sickness, education and all other necessary expense. To meet this condition pupils have been kept in the school longer than necessary simply for the work they could do and very many of them left it in the end far from being the friend either of the Government or the Missionary Society. It is my conviction that the aim of the school should be to fit boys and girls for farm and domestic work (not by any means for office work or even teachers unless in very few cases,) and just as soon as they are will fitted to earn their own living let them go out to good homes and do so. The last couple of years they are kept here after they and their parents think they should go tends to develop all that is sullen and revengeful in the Indian nature besides larger boys and girls in this mood have a most beneful effect upon younger pupils. As a rule pupils should enter the school at ten to twelve years and leave it about sixteen and they should be and would be pupils from the best families and would go out as a real asset to the church and the nation. The pupils would feel that they were kept here until they could help themselves and no longer and in most cases they and their parents would be our friends, and they would early take their place in the nations life and be a real help to those who so much need farm and domestic helps.
We are enjoying the work here and doing our very best to make the work a success. We are very grateful for the deep interest taken in us by your Department and the Department at Ottawa, and respectfully submit to you the above facts not in any spirit of complaint, but in an earnest endeavor that every thing possible be done to make the school a great blessing to the Indian people and their families.

(Signed) S. R. McVitty.

REPORT OF THE MOUNT ELGIN INSTITUTE
YEAR ENDING MARCH 31, 1911.

The main building is kept neat and clean. Considerable furnishings have been put in and some improvements made, the most important being new range for the kitchens, some good furniture and the installation of an electric light plant, which furnishes light for the main buildings, cottages, laundry, stables and barns. The light plant was put in by the Government at a cost of about $2,400, also $500 for the material in a new hen house.

CLASS ROOMS.

The half day system is carried out for most of the older scholars, while many of the younger attend the class rooms all day.

The teachers are doing good work and up-to-date methods are in vogue, especially in the senior rooms, where a class of nine are in preparation for the Entrance examinations in July.

LIVE STOCK.

There are at present 196 head of cattle, 31 horses, and 74 pigs, all looking well for this season of the year. 70 cattle, 10 horses and 40 pigs, and a total increase of about $6,000 in the value of the live stock have been added since July, 1909.

CHILDREN AND STAFF.

The health of all has been very good, the doctor's bill and drug account being only $35 for the past year and nine months.

The conduct of the pupils has been worthy of praise, and they have greatly assisted the Principal and his staff to create a homelike atmosphere about the entire Institution. There are 102 children in attendance.

Helping the Indian: How it is Done at Mount Elgin Industrial Institute

By Rev. S. R. McVitty

Of the many splendid enterprises, missionary and educational, connected with the work of the Church in Canada, none is more interesting than that of the Mount Elgin Industrial Institute, situated on the north bank of the river Thames, in the township of Caradoc, county of Oxford, about thirty-five miles west of the city of St. Thomas. The school was founded by the late Bishop John Henry McGregor, who was the first Bishop of the Methodist Church in Canada.

At the conference of 1854, held at Brockville, Ontario, the Rev. Peter Jones, a veteran missionary and pioneer, was appointed to raise funds for the erection of suitable buildings. He succeeded over to Great Britain, and spent several years preaching and laboring in the mission field. Upon his return, he found that the funds had been raised, and the school opened its doors in 1860. The school has since grown in size and influence, and now has a large number of pupils attending.

At the conference of 1859 the Rev. James G. B. George was appointed principal. After serving for some time, he was succeeded by Rev. James G. B. George, who continued until 1873.

The school has always been under the supervision of the Board of Education, and has been visited by many prominent persons. It is now under the administration of Mr. W. W. Sherrard, who has been very successful in his work.

We are constantly adding to the supply of our school and to the number of subjects being taught. We have at present over two hundred boys and girls attending our school. We are also engaged in the training of teachers, and have already trained several.

We are grateful for the support of our friends, and we trust that they will continue to give us their encouragement and assistance.
present three competent public school teachers in charge of our primary, intermediate and senior rooms. Thorough instruction is given in all subjects of the Ontario public school course.

A year ago we added music to our curriculum, and found that the girls are receiving a thorough education in theory and vocal music, under a most competent and fully-qualified teacher, who has also done much composition, composed songs for boys and girls of the school.

The building system obtains division one and two in the primary school, and divisions two to six in the intermediate school; the primary division is in school full time. Workrooms of various kinds are taught, sewing, tailoring, cooking, and fitting of garments, cooking, and all kinds of housework. The boys are taught farming, mechanics, carpentry, care and management of live stock, gardening, carpentry, blacksmithing, cement work, fencing, the making and repairing of all kinds of farm machinery, including steam and gasoline engines. As the pupils advance and show an aptitude for certain lines of work, they are encouraged to specialize, and the last year or so of industrial training is usually spent on their chosen subject.

Our buildings are thoroughly modern, and very suitable for the work being done. We have recently installed an electric hot water plant, consisting of an oil tank, boiler, and pump, with 100 16-candle-power lights, a fireless hot-water heating system, and an upright piano. In addition to these conveniences, we added two large wings to the main building, besides some minor improvements. All the time we have received most courteous and generous assistance from the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, who supply us the funds and pay the wages entirely out of their own. We are pleased to say it has been carried through to the entire satisfaction of all concerned.

Mr. Thorburn makes it abundantly clear that the Christian defense can only be maintained on the basis of historic Christianity. To some extent at least we must admit that he has succeeded in getting at the real historic figure of Jesus.

SOCIAL RELIGION—AN INTERPRETATION OF CHRISTIANITY IN TERMS OF MODERN LIFE. By Scott Macmillan. London: The Macmillan Company of Canada. $1.50 net.

Charles Macmillan seems right say a harsh and brutal, and yet there is something in the unreasonableness of modern social life which makes it hard to believe and help together with a fairly reasonable interpretation of things. A startling and strong book; if only it could be shown that those people should read who refuse to believe in any sort of social remaining that is before us. The Motherless Girl is terribly arresting.

JOHN BRASH: MEMORIALS AND CHRONICLES. By John Brash. 8 pages. (London: Charles H. Kelley, 1913.)

A volume which seeks to perpetuate the memory of a man whose untimely death, in Texas earnestness, seemed to have interrupted his work. The sketch of the life given in brief is interesting, but it seems more made up chiefly from the writings of others than from his own. He read widely in literature, and his comments are often keen, fresh and stimulating. Mr. Brash was a man of wide interests and his work, though contrary to what some might think, was not narrowly or singularly free from anything like narrowness. He visited Canada with a Kewick delegate and experienced a very entertaining time. His letters are full of spiritual stimulus.

THE GREAT OUTDOORS is the title of a very excellent tract by the Rev. Richard Duke, of Toronto, an experienced missionary worker among the Indians. Mr. Duke has given much thought to the subject of systematic giving. This tract is a thoughtful and practical exposition of the subject given in a very convincing manner, and will do good to all our people. We hope the pastors, the members of the churches, and all who will read it and urge the people to do the same, will find that the lesson as here taught, a mighty work would be accomplished in advancing the cause of God.

School, also pointed out, that, at the barns of said school was one of the best Imported Clydesdale Horses in Canada, an imported standard bred horse about as good as money could buy, a Holstein bull, sired by a full brother to the Champion cow of the world, and a Shorthorn bull, the highest priced animal at the Western Ontario Consignment Sales Co.'s sale last Fall. In view of the great demand for farm help, and the urgent and repeated requests reaching us from farmers and farmers' wives to permit some of our senior boys and girls to go out to service for the Summer, I appeal to you for advice. To permit the seniors to go would, of course, rob us of their assistance, and would also entail much extra labour on the members of our staff in carrying on the work of the school, yet, I feel something ought to be done. The following seems feasible:

Dear Mr. Scott;

Mr. Ferrier has been good enough to furnish me with a copy of his letter to the Department, also a personal one to you requesting an increase in Per Capita Grant to this school. There are certain additional facts, better known to me than anyone else, which we think you should have clearly before you when considering this matter.

1. The fact that our school is always filled to capacity, without military canvass, is abundant proof that it is in great need.

2. The record made by our pupils year after year is proof that they are capable, and that our teachers and instructors are efficient.

3. The fact that we seldom ever have a truant or a complaint is proof that the Indian people appreciate what we are doing.

4. This efficiency has been made possible by the fact that although our Per Capita Grant is very low, our Live Stock operations have been unusually successful, we have always been able to really augment our grant by our Live Stock profits.

5. Our gains in Live Stock business have completely changed. And I venture the assertion that the great majority of Live Stock men are scarcely breaking even. We are more attentive to business than ever before, but the more business done the more losses, so much is on the wrong side. The price of cattle makes it impossible to produce beef or milk at a profit.

6. Clothing, bread and other food we buy, etc., are abnormally high. With the result that we have to draw from our reserve fund about $350.00.

To the Secretary,

Dear Sir;

In reply to your letter of the 21st instant,
I would say we have tried a third teacher on several occasions, and the unanimous opinion of our staff is that it is an unnecessary expenditure of funds at our disposal.

We have two teachers, and neither one wishes less work than at present. Our senior teacher has 47 pupils in the morning, with four classes; and about the same number in the afternoon with three classes. The junior teacher has about 45 pupils with three classes. A country teacher will often have as many pupils and about eight classes.

Classroom work is an important part of our training, but not by any means the most important. Our experience indicates girls who have had a thorough training in domestic work have succeeded much better in future life than those who devoted most of their time in trying to secure high school entrance. In the case of the Indian "a little learning is a dangerous thing."

Our school is well organized and well manned. Pupils are not kept out of class room for any reason save sickness or they are well taught in the other departments.

The plan of alternating schoolroom class work, farm work for the boys and some form of house work for the girls is an admirable one but is faulty in that there is not enough diversity in the practical work which they do. Indian children, while not inferior in mentality to white children, are particularly clever with their hands; if it could be arranged that instruction could be given them similar to that in Technical Schools, but not necessarily as comprehensive, I am satisfied the problem of Indian Education would be well on the way to a satisfactory solution. Only 3 senior IV pupils are in the classroom all day. Of the remaining 106 senior room pupils, 53 attend in the forenoon and 52 in the afternoon. Every possible care for the health and comfort of the Indian children in residence seems to have been taken by the principal and his assistants, as evidenced by their splendid physiques. Wholesome food, comfortable sleeping quarters and wise disciplinary measures have been contributory causes to these results and all reflecting great credit on the management. I would suggest that at least one instructor be added to the teaching staff. Two teachers cannot adequately deal with 140 pupils especially when so many require special attention. Many come here without a speaking knowledge of the English language.

Dear Sir:

We have pleasure in submitting herewith our quarterly returns for the end of the Conference Year 1932. Attendance has been large, health and conduct excellent and we have with some effort balanced our budget.

Our great problem is our senior girls, how to bridge the gulf between the Entrance Room and Real Life. Sir:

A complaint has reached the Department, contained in a letter intended for publication in a Toronto newspaper, making certain charges against the conditions existing at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. I quote therefrom:

"Wouldn't the general public be surprised to know that these children, who work hard, have nothing softer than a box or table to rest on from the time they rise at 6:30 a.m., till they go to bed at night? (The beds must be kept neatly made up to impress visitors.) That they have not one home-like room for their use? That there is not one bath-tub for the use of the children? That skin diseases and sores are prevalent among the children? That, on a farm where a large dairy herd is kept, not one ear nor mouth average more than 2 lbs. of butter for the whole 160 children allowed daily? That, not once last year, did those 160 children receive one whole egg each? That, where sports should naturally flourish, the school will not provide even lacrosse sticks for the Indians' own games? Don't start thinking of depression! There wasn't enough the past summer to build stone pillars (to add to the appearance of the school) and to install new bath-tubs for the staff. And wouldn't the public be incensed to learn that some big boys who have worked at the school during the summer holidays never received their promised pay?

The children go to school half a day and work half a day, and are provided with food, shelter, and clothing. Their whole life, day in and day out, is spent under them; they are forced to work under direction which doesn't require, and indeed discourages, any individual acting or thinking on their part. Punishment goes to those who don't keep in line. Consequently, when they leave school, and this commanding hand is removed, what is the result? - The school is not proud of its graduates."

I would request that you forward, at an early date, a report regarding each of the complaints, as mentioned above. It is especially requested that you will report concerning the lack of provision for medical care and the prevalence of skin diseases and sores and if the larger boys, who worked at the school during the summer, were paid for their services. I would advise that you consult the Assistant Principal, Rev. Mr. Strapp and forward a full report.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-0-1 of January 9th, with reference to Mount Elgin School and would advise that I visited this school on Jan 15th and consulted the Assistant Principal, Rev. Mr. Strapp and also had a look over the school proper and would desire to report on the separate complaints as follows,

1. Re; Rest Room at the School.

When the pupils are not at work or in the class room or at play they have access to their locker rooms which are in the basement of the school and are rooms 30' X 40' and have cement floors, with a row of locker boxes around the outside of the room which are 18" high and outside of a small table in the girls part, they are barren of furniture. On account of the cement floor they were not very warm on the day of visit. Two other rooms are also available after supper time, being the prayer room and the reading room, there being school desks in the former and a long table with wooden benches in the latter, all seating being of wooden construction. The lawn and grounds are used by the pupils in warm weather to lounge about on. The pupils are not allowed in the dormitories only at bedtime or on account of illness.

2. Re; Bath accommodation.

All pupils of the school are bathed on Saturday of each week and the laundry room is used. Twelve wooden tubs 18" X 18" by 20" deep, three feet from the floor are used and are plenty small enough to bath children in, as well as being hard to keep in a sanitary condition. The laundry building in which the children bath is a very old structure and not in a good state of repair.

3. Re; Skin diseases among pupils.

On the day of my visit there were 16 boys in bed with colds and sixteen girls and I examined their hands and faces and found...
two boys and two girls with sores either on their hands or faces and had the assurance of the Assistant Principal and the nurse that there were no other cases in the school. These skin diseases were quite common for some years back and according to Mr. Strapp, the pupils brought a lot of it with them when they returned from their holidays and it was not until recent months that separate towels were provided twice weekly to the pupils on the request of the Med. Supt., and this has done a lot to curtail the spread of skin ailments, which is at a low mark at the present. It has apparently taken some considerable time for these skin diseases to clear up on some pupils, as some have large and numerous scars and this fact may have been due to neglect on the part of the school nurse, or some blood disorder in the pupil, or even from diet or other cause.

4. Re: Pupils diet.

A little butter is supplied each pupil at Supper, 3 times a week. No eggs have been supplied during the past year, in previous years one egg each was supplied each pupil at Easter time. Dr. McLeod informs me that Mr. McVitty advised him that the pupils were getting an abundance of butter and eggs.

On the day of my visit the following was the Menu:

Breakfast, rolled oats; cold milk; 3 slices of bread for senior pupils and two for junior pupils; preserved fruit.

Dinner, Stew composed of beef, potatoes, carrots, onions & turnips; milk; rice for dessert; 2 end one slices of bread.

Supper, Macaroni and tomatoes; any potatoes or porridge left over is given; milk; preserved fruit and bread the same as breakfast. Occasionally cold meat, pickles, ripe apples and drippings from fried meats are given at a meal. The plate the cook informs me that she has been at four Indian Residential schools and that Mount Elgin has better food and a larger assortment than the others she was at and the pupils all appear well nourished. The School has a variety of fresh fruit.

5. Re: School sports.

The Rev. Mr. Strapp informs me that the pupils have soft balls and foot balls, skating and sleigh-riding in season and they wander around the grounds and woods at the school at will. No lacrosse sticks are supplied as they are dangerous to the pupils without proper padded protection and would be a source of much ill feeling among the pupils.

6. Re: Stone pillars.

Pillars were erected at the entrance to the school grounds in memory of pupils who died during the war and the cost to the school was in the vicinity of $150.00.
7. Re: Staff bath-rooms.

Excluding the Principal's quarters, there are three bath-rooms for the convenience of a staff of seven persons in the school proper.

8. Re: Unpaid wages of pupils.

In the Summer of 1932, Carmen Sickles an older pupil who is at present in the school, had an agreement with Mr. McVitty to work at school during the holidays. Recently Mr. Jamieson, farm foreman informed Mr. Strapp that Sickles had not been paid his wages and Mr. Strapp investigated and took the matter up with Mr. McVitty and the boy did receive a cheque for $30.65 on the 11th of Jan., 1934. This boy was engaged during the Summer of Mr. Strapp and he was unaware of the non-payment of wages, and this is the only case that is known of.

9. Re: Graduates of Mount Elgin Institute.

The pupils of this school come from many reserves and many classes of Indians and as Agent on two reserves I have seen many good pupils and may not be good. Of recent years I have seen many pupils return to their homes or the India reserve of this Agency who have not been a credit to any school and firstly this must be considered from the class of pupil that is admitted and secondly from lack of control on the part of the India parents after the pupils return to their homes on the reserve after being discharged.

In speaking to the Assistant Principal and going over the school with him, he brought to my attention several requirements which he maintains are badly needed, but as I had not been asked for recommendations by the Dept., I have not submitted these. Dr. Creed, however, brought to my notice that when he asked that fruit be supplied a sick Indian, the Principal would not allow it on account of the cost and the doctor also gave some reasons to which I shall refer. Health and sanitary conditions at school which he considers would be a benefit to the school. If you require these to be submitted, I would be pleased to send them forward on your request.

RESOLUTIONS ADOPTED BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE
OF THE BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS,
THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA.

January 16th, 1934.

RE RESIGNATION OF REV. S. R. McVITTY.

The Secretary read a letter from Rev. S. R. McVitty, resigning from the principalship of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School as at June 30th, 1934.

On motion, IT WAS UNANIMOUSLY RESOLVED:

1.- THAT this Executive of the Board of Home Missions has heard with profound regret that on account of advancing years and declining health Rev. S. R. McVitty has tendered his resignation as Principal of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. In accepting this resignation, we desire to place on record our deep appreciation of the twenty-five years' service he has rendered the cause of Indian education. His knowledge of Indian life and character and devotion to the best interests of his pupils have enabled him to exert an abiding and creative influence on hundreds of Indian boys and girls. His executive ability and keen sense of financial values have combined to make the Mount Elgin Institute one of the most efficiently managed residential schools in Canada. We rejoice to assure him that he retires from the exciting duties which he has carried on with such conspicuous success for a quarter century enjoying the confidence of all those who have been associated with him;

2.- THAT, as a mark of our appreciation, this Executive offers Mr. McVitty leave of absence from all responsibility, with full salary, until the end of the conference year;

3.- THAT the Chairman of the Board, Dr. D. C. MacGregor, and the Superintendent of Indian Missions, Rev. Arthur Barner, be requested to visit Mr. McVitty and convey these resolutions to him;

4.- THAT we nominate to the Department of Indian Affairs Rev. O. B. Strepp as Principal of Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Principalship, Mount Elgin Residential School,

The Executive of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church on Thursday, January 16th, accepted the resignation of Rev. S. R. McVitty, Principal of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School. A committee, consisting of the Chairman, Rev. D. C. MacGregor, D.D., and our Superintendent of Indian Missions, Rev. Arthur Barner, was appointed to wait on Mr. McVitty and convey to him the enclosed message of appreciation.

These two gentlemen met Mr. McVitty yesterday and spent a couple of hours with him, discussing the offer of the Executive that he should be given leave of absence from all responsibility, with full salary, until the completion of his twenty-fifth year of service, namely, June 30th, 1934.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Rev. O. B. Strapp has called my attention to a letter received from you, under date of May 28th, as well as to a copy of a communication addressed to Mr. Moore, Indian Agent at Muncey, Ontario. In taking the matter up with you I am presuming that a similar letter has gone out to the Indian Agent who is in closest contact with each one of our residential schools and I am therefore anxious to secure a little elucidation of what is involved.

We have been making every effort for four years to direct through this office all the important correspondence with the Department of Indian Affairs concerning policy and problems in connection with residential schools. It is exceedingly difficult to secure uniformity and to make the decisions which we have to make concerning our schools fairly and impartially if the Principal of the school corresponds directly with the Department of Indian Affairs. The fact that I, as the Secretary responsible for Indian Missions, have the privilege of being in Ottawa frequently, has helped cut a good deal, although I would very much prefer to know beforehand concerning any negotiations which the Principal of a residential school desires to conduct with the Department.

If every approach concerning a residential school must be made in the future through the local Indian Agent, it would certainly complicate our problem in this office just at a time when we were beginning to get a system set up which was satisfactory to us - and, so far as we know, satisfactory to the Department.

I can also see for most of our Principals difficulties of a different type in this regulation. For instance, in a school like Muncey or Coqualeetza, recruiting pupils from half a dozen or more agencies, it seems strange that the Principal should be required to conduct all his negotiations through the Agent who happens to be located closest to the school geographically.

Probably your letter does not intend to imply that the Principal of the Muncey school, in dealing with problems, say, in Mr. McCormick's or Mr. Stone's territory, should address
these gentlemen or the Department of Indian Affairs through Mr. Moore.

So far as the Board of Home Missions is concerned, we welcome contacts with the schools under our direction by the Agents of the Department of Indian Affairs, whether local Agents, Medical Officers, or Inspectors. We believe that in a co-operative venture of this type we have everything to gain by consistent and careful inspection from the standpoint of the Department of Indian Affairs, and we have been fortunate in recent years in the harmony which has prevailed between the Indian Agents and Inspectors and the Principals of our Schools.

Yours very sincerely,

Grand Jury Presentment.

London, Ontario, March 16, 1935.

To His Lordship,

Sir Justice Kingstone,
Judge Presiding, Supreme Court of Ontario,
Spring Assizes.

May it please your Lordship,

We, the members of the Grand Jury at the present sitting of the Supreme Court of Ontario, beg leave to make the following presentment.

We desire to express our thanks to your Lordship for the very clear and comprehensive explanation of our power and duties as Grand Jurors.

Our attention was directed to four indictments, three of which were "Motor Manslaughter" and one of "Assault" and after the examination of the witnesses and due consideration a "True Bill" was arrived at in each case.

On Wednesday, March the 11th, we visited the County Gaol and Court House. We were received by Governor Charles Mitchell and conducted through the Gaol where we found everything to be exceptionally clean, the walls, clothing and all equipment were free from vermin of any kind. The food was found to be fresh and of good quality.

We should recommend that a small drain be placed in the exercise yard to remove water that collects from the melting snow also that the windows in the Court House be tightened to prevent rattling.

The Court House Steam and return mains in the corridor that leads from the prisoners cells to the Court House requires immediate attention. The covering on the pipes is in bad need of repair and the return main has no covering whatever. The comfort of the Court House will be...
more than repaid in the spring and fall if these mains are properly covered and insulated. We would suggest that proper covering be 85% Magnesia sectional pipe covering, one inch thick. The total distance would be about twenty-five feet.

We found confined in the Gaol forty-six prisoners two of whom were females, and we received no complaints as to their treatment or food.

Governor Mitchell informed us that Divine Service was conducted every Sunday and appreciation is extended to those who carry on this excellent work.

We congratulate the Sheriff, Donald Graham, upon the efficiency of his work and office, and also the Governor, Charles Mitchell. Both officers are deserving of commendation.

On Wednesday afternoon, March the 11th, we visited the Mt. Elgin Indian Residential School at the Muncey Reserve. This was the first visit by any Grand Jury to this Institution. This school, built many years ago, closed by reopened in 1867, occupies a tract of land consisting of 200 acres and with a further rental of 750 acres. We were introduced to the Principal, Rev. Mr. Strapp, by Dr. T.R. Nelson, Resident Physician and the Indian Agent, Mr. A.D. Moore. This school teaches Academic, Vocational and Dairy work. Their registration is 61 girls and 75 boys, aged from eleven to seventeen years. Much credit is due the Federal Government in maintaining an Institution of this nature. We would recommend that the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa be requested to supply this Institution with adequate inventory accommodation also an Emergency Hospital, capable of taking care of both sexes, with
accommodation for six or eight patients. The heating system is at present inefficient, and could be improved at least thirty per cent in the installation of a vacuum pump or air eliminator on the return lines.

On Thursday, March the 12th, we visited the Middlesex House of Refuge at Stratford, and were conducted through the premises by the Superintendent, Mr. Alex. Anderson and his wife who is Matron. There are sixty-one men and twenty-three women a total of eighty-four aged persons being taken care of in this Institution. The main building is receiving interior decorations and floors are being replaced. All other buildings are very clean and in excellent condition.

The Stratford General Hospital was inspected and we found twenty-three patients receiving treatment, seven men, eleven women and six children. The Superintendent, Mrs. N. Malone R.N., conducted us through and explained fully the activities, and we found everything exceptionally clean. We believe that a sign should be placed at the intersection of the Highway and the Street leading to the Hospital, to note location in case of emergencies.

The McCormick Home for Aged People was visited where Miss S. J. Little, R.N., the Superintendent conducted us. Those in charge are endeavouring to make comfortable many who have arrived at the advanced time of life. Here we found spring cleaning in progress and everything in a most sanitary condition. At present there are 39 men and 50 women in the residence, some confined to their beds. One lady is 106 years old.

On Friday Morning, March the 13th, we visited Victoria Hospital on Ottawa Avenue, where Dr. L.C. Fallis, the Superintendent, conducted us through the Main Building.
and the War Memorial Children Hospital. We found the main building crowded to capacity, more especially in the Women's Public Ward where every available space including the passage was occupied with beds. Immediate attention should be given to relieve this situation. The Hospital requires more room for the X-ray equipment, and much larger sections for the Eye, Ear, Nose, Throat and Maternity departments.

The manufacturing of Splints upon the premises deserves special mention and we are informed that Victoria Hospital is one of the very few carrying on this class of work.

We are pleased to see that a citizen of London was interested in the Children's section by placing therein a small but adequate swimming pool, which permits those requiring limb exercise to secure it while still patients.

Too much credit cannot be given to those in charge for their excellent administration under the existing conditions.

We found all buildings exceptionally clean.

There are 354 resident patients of which 50 are children.

Friday afternoon, we visited the Ontario Hospital. We met Dr. O. H. Stevenson who arranged for his assistant Dr. J. R. MacGeech to conduct us through this vast Institution where we found buildings crowded beyond capacity. There are 645 males and 823 females, a total of 1468 in residence as compared with 1565 last year.

The Dairy and Stock barns are very clean and well managed, but we notice the lack of toilet accommodation for those employed there.
The Recreation Building and the Vocational work greatly assist the convalescents in keeping themselves occupied while still patients.

We note the foundation of an additional building which, although immediately required, will not be completed, we are informed, until the Government has available funds.

We congratulate Dr. Stevenson and his staff upon the efficiency of this Institution.

The University of Western Ontario was visited on Saturday morning, March the 14th, and the Grand Jurors were impressed with the Arts, Science and the Lawson Memorial Library Buildings. Col. Walter James Brown, the Executive Secretary, and Prof. Fred Landon, Librarian, conducted us as we inspected the Class Rooms and the Museums. The buildings are located on a tract of land consisting of 260 acres and immediately to the north-west of the City Limits. The registration from the City of London is 479 students with an outside registration of 1094 making a total of 1573. The affiliated Colleges have a registration of 448, thus making a gross registration of 2021.

In the Summer School of 1935 there were 350 students registered, most of whom were teachers who were improving their academic standing and it is expected that the Summer School registration for 1936 will exceed 700.

All buildings are clean and well ventilated and are a credit to the Board of Governors and staff. Your Jurors were surprised to find no lockers for the students' wearing apparel, most of which was allowed to remain on racks in the corridors; they feel that some public spirited citizen should assist this Institution very much by installing these necessities.
On Saturday Afternoon we visited Westminster Hospital for returned and disabled soldiers numbering 576 resident patients. In the absence of Dr. Morrison, we were conducted through the buildings by Mr. D.J. McDonald, Chief Orderly Officer. It is gratifying to note how the Doctors and Nurses are endeavouring to alleviate the sufferings of these men who sacrificed all in the Great World War. We found the buildings clean and very neat and everything most orderly.

The question of dispensing with the Grand Jury, it is in our opinion very unwise to make any change in the Jury System at the present time. If the State is desirous of increasing National economy, we believe it might be advisable, if it be feasible, to adopt the British system of Parliamentary Representation.

Finally, Your Lordship, may we be permitted to wish you many years of health to enable you to direct the destinies of those who may require your patience, diligence and sound judgment.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been informed by Mr. Strapp, Principal of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, that Mr. John Kapayo, who for forty-five years has been mechanic at that institution, is now seriously ill. He has had several operations for cancer, and you will see by the enclosed communication from his doctor that he is not only incapacitated for work, but is not likely to live for more than a year or so.

Mr. Strapp feels that beyond paying Mr. Kapayo his full salary until the 31st August, there is not much more he can afford to do out of the revenue of the School. It seems to us that, under all the circumstances, the Department might very well consider granting Mr. Kapayo, in view of his long service, a pension on his retirement, amounting to at least one-half of his pay—which has been $70.00 a month and a house.

Confidentially, I may add that the situation is complicated by the fact that Mr. Kapayo claims that his illness is traceable to an injury which he received in the laundry of the School, through the carelessness of one of the first pupils, who let the door of the drying machine fall on his back some years ago.

Mr. Kapayo's relatives threaten suit, if something is not done to look after him now. I suppose if the suit were entered, it would be an attempt to recover damages from both the Department and the Church. Mr. Strapp is of the opinion that a moderate pension would satisfy all parties concerned. Will you be good enough to take this matter up and see if something cannot be done. I will be glad to hear from you after you and the other Department officials have been able to consider the question thoroughly.

Doctor McGill

Catalog:
Residential School

The residential school on this reserve, known as the Mount Algin Institute, is one of the oldest residential schools, if not the oldest, in the province of Ontario. It was built in the year 1849, probably by the Methodist Church of Canada, and officially opened in 1851. It is now the only residential school operated by the Government in cooperation with the United Church in the province of Ontario. An enrolment of 150 pupils is allowed at this school and per capita grant is at the rate of $160. The cost of operation per pupil, according to the last audit statement, is $241.66 per annum.

The classroom buildings, which are detached from the main building, are the original buildings erected almost a century ago. In addition to the regular classrooms, accommodation is provided on the second floor of this building for certain members of the teaching staff. These residential school buildings are on a mound and subject very much to erosion. This is particularly true of the classroom, one gable of which might collapse at any time. Mr. Dudley had this particular gable strengthened with four or five square timbers. This rendered the wall reasonably safe for a time, but the wall above and below these supports shows signs of bulging and disintegration. The main building was rebuilt in 1898, probably by the Methodist Church, with a contribution from the Government. The records here indicate that from 1898 to 1911 and 1912 £21,000 of government funds have been spent on this school and £11,600 from band funds. In 1912 and 1913 a new addition was built to the main building at a cost to the Government of £17,260.00. This main building represents a style of architecture that has long since been abandoned. The ceilings are at least 12 feet high and the cost of heating from year to year must be enormous. However, the building is of brick construction and from the outside presents a somewhat imposing appearance, but inside it is one of the most dilapidated structures that I have ever inspected.

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6205, file 468-1, part 3)
At the time of my visit the plumbing in the boys' wash-room was in a faulty state of repair, with the result that the wash bowl were full of filthy water and the floor of the wash-room in a filthy condition. The odors in the wash-room and indeed throughout the building were so offensive that I could scarcely endure them. Certain parts of this building are literally alive with cockroaches - this applies particularly to the kitchen. The treads I noticed on the stairway were literally worn away until they are no longer safe. If this were not a government-operated institution, I feel confident it would be closed by the municipal health authorities.

However, when I later discussed the state of this school with Dr. Ochreane, he expressed the opinion that it was a model of sanitary perfection when compared with the United Church school at Round Lake, Saskatchewan. I must state, though, in fairness to all parties concerned, that this school reflects no credit on either the Department of the United Church of Canada. In my judgment, it should be immediately closed or rebuilt. Consider the principal, the Reverend Mr. Strapp; a good man and a man with a very practical turn of mind, he has experienced the utmost difficulty this year in securing pupils, particularly senior pupils. He had at the time of my visit 120 pupils on the roll and is worried almost to the point of collapse by the financial outlook for the school. The school, he assured me, simply cannot continue to operate with the present allowance. It would appear as Indians become economically better off they display a tendency to keep their children at home and send them to the day schools rather than to the residential school. This may be a rather encouraging tendency but is one that makes it exceedingly difficult for our schools to operate until certain adjustments have been effected. I estimate that it would require the sum of $200,000 to rebuild and furnish the Mount Algin School with accommodation for 150 to 175 pupils.

In contrast to the school building, the farm operated in connection with this school is a model of efficiency. Mr. Strapp has one of the best pure bred Holstein dairy herds in southwestern Ontario. He has in addition at this time 70 pigs of the bacon type, and has one of the best Yorkshire bears in the province. He also has a good poultry house, well stocked with poultry and his farm buildings are all that one might desire. I am disposed to think that we should cease to operate this residential school and that the place it occupies should be taken by a four-room classroom building, in which we would make provision for continuation classes and vocational instruction. This would enable us to take the
pupils from the day schools at Grades 7 and 8 and give them advanced courses in academic subjects in agriculture or auto mechanic, carpentry, etc., and the girls, courses in home-making, domestic science, dressmaking, etc. The principal of this school should, in addition to his duties at the school be made supervisor or inspector of all the schools on the reserve. This would enable us to have an almost ideal experimental educational unit. In view of the fact that this school has been operated for a century by the United Church, we might have to nominate as the principal of the school a United Church clergyman. Such a clergyman, if appointed, however, should be a fully qualified teacher with training in vocational subjects, and in agriculture. It has occurred to me that if the New England Company withdraw their support from the Bradford school and transfer the property to the Department, we might well consider the advisability of appointing a fully qualified teacher as principal of this United Church and Anglican children, particularly orphans, could be sent from the whole of southwestern Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re - Operation Mount Elgin Institute
Your File 7-0-

I have your letter of May 26th, and, after giving it some consideration, I am writing to let you have my own personal reaction. Naturally, such a drastic proposal as you outline will have to receive the consideration of the Executive of our Board. I do not remember that you had spoken to me about the approach which had been made to the New England Company with respect to the future of the Mohawk Institute, but we did discuss the problem of education on the Caradoc Reserve. I shall be quite frank in my reaction.

In the first place, I do not think you intend the suggestion that the School at Munsey be closed on June 30th, 1943, to be taken seriously. To ask the Board of Home Missions to consent to this after the School has been in operation "for these many years," when a notice is sent to us on May 26th - which is just one month and four days' notice - is a good deal more than I think you think we are likely to consider as within the realm of practical politics.

I also note that your proposition involves closing the School now and leaving all these children who are at present in the School without any educational facilities, and that next year a secondary or continuation school and a teacher's residence would be built. I do not think that is feasible - and I do not think you do either.

I should also like to draw your attention to the fact that the suggestion that the Mohawk Institute be operated on a departmental basis is so complete and radical a departure from the system which has hitherto obtained in the operation of residential schools, that I do not think it can be carried out without taking into account certain factors which involve the Churches. I do not know what the attitude of The Church of England would be, but I believe, however, that it is proposed to set up this institution as a residential school for non-Catholics. May I ask if it is seriously proposed that the non-Catholics in Ontario would be treated in one way and the Catholics and all the rest of the Dominion would be treated in another way? I do not think this is possible. Nor do I think that the United Church would look with any favor on the setting up of a residential school of the size of the Mohawk Institute, to be operated on a purely secular basis. I am not very strong on sectarianism, but I do feel that the religious side of the work of the Indian schools must be considered. However, the relation you have with the Mohawk Institute and with The Church of...
England is not my business.

I come next to a very serious feature of the proposition. According to the last Census, there are 5533 Indians in Ontario who are counted United Church. There are 9747 Church of England, and 9262 Roman Catholics. Your proposal, if it were carried through, would mean, so far as the United Church is concerned, that there would not be a single residential school in Ontario to which our children could be sent; but it would leave all the Roman Catholic schools, with a total pupilage of 705, in full operation. It would leave The Church of England schools, with a pupilage of 520 (I have eliminated the Mohawk Institute), also running. I do not think that this will commend itself to the judgment of the United Church.

Further - and in this I am only expressing my opinion - I do not know what the official attitude of the Executive of our Board will be - I think it is quite improbable that our Executive would look with equanimity on a proposal that would deprive the United Church of another residential school. I beg to point out that we gave up Coqualeetza. Ahousaht has been closed - Kitamaat has been closed - and whilst these latter two were not very large, yet the total pupilage in residential schools under the care of the United Church is a good deal less than it was some years ago. We shall await with a good deal of interest - and I was going to say expectation, although that is the wrong word - to hear of one single, solitary Roman Catholic School having been closed. We might as well face the fact that when the school was closed at Coqualeetza, and also the school at Ahousaht, the Indian people, whose children had been going to these schools, were approached by representatives of the Roman Catholic Church, with a proposal that their children attend one of the Catholic schools. I know perfectly well that the law says that Catholic children will go to Catholic schools and Protestant children to Protestant schools; but there is absolutely nothing which says that a man may not change his church affiliation in order to get his children enrolled in the school which seems to him, for the time being at least, to offer the greater advantage. This has been done. You and I are powerless to do very much about it, because we believe in freedom. But I think these matters must be faced.

Having said all this, I fully realize that the Mount Elgin School is in a deplorable condition and that it has long outlived its usefulness; but I have not yet come to the place where I would ask the Executive of our Board to urge the expenditure of $200,000 of Government money to replace this old building. I realize that the situation at Mount Elgin is in a bad way, and, personally, I am quite prepared to co-operate with the Department in making the survey suggested; but we might as well face the fact that, so far as our Church is concerned, we are not going to be pushed around too far nor too fast in connection with these residential schools; and we shall expect the same policy to be followed on Reserves where the people are Roman Catholic as you are suggesting in the case of this Reserve, which is predominantly Protestant.

Finally, may I say that it does not seem to us to be fair - and I do not think we can get away with it - to notify Mr. Strapp on the 27th May that his ten years' principalship will expire on June 30th. This is what the proposal to close the school would mean; because I do not think that either you or I can envisage Mr. Strapp as an educationist, doing the work which you suggest should be done on this particular Reserve. Some men have some gifts, and others have others - there is good Scripture for that - and, quite frankly, I do not think Mr. Strapp's gifts...
lie in that direction.

The Secretaries of the Board of Home Missions would, I think, be prepared to continue to explore the possibility of radical changes in the educational set-up at Mount Elgin—or anywhere else, but I think we should have time in which to do it, and the 30th June, which is the end of the academic year, is hardly time enough. With this end in view, I shall try to arrange for a survey of conditions in the Caradoc Agency, and to assist in submitting a report on the programme which might be carried forward in the Agency. This might be done during the coming summer, in co-operation with the public school inspector.

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM: DOCTOR DOREY.

Re: Operation Mt. Elgin Institute.

The Mount Elgin Institute has at this date an authorized enrolment of 150 pupils, for which per capita grant at the rate of $160 is allowed. The actual enrolment is approximately 120 pupils, the number of these are school girls who have exceeded the age limit. The pupils are drawn from the following reserves: Waipole Island; Barna; Kettle Point; Oneida; Muncey; Caradoc; Cape Croker; Hagersville (New Credit); Moravian; Saugan; Christian Island; Six Nations; Gibson (Perry Sound); Caughnawaga.

The departmental records indicate that there is ample accommodation at the day schools on the reserves from which pupils are recruited and that the closing down of the Mt. Elgin Institute would cause little inconvenience in this respect, although transportation in one or two cases would no doubt have to be provided. It is interesting to note that a day school was closed at the Caradoc agency during the present academic year for the reason that the number of pupils available did not justify its operation. The teacher of the school was last term employed in the agency office where she now serves as clerk. It will be noted that 17 pupils are recruited from the Kettle Point agency and yet the attendance at this school has become so unsatisfactory and the number of pupils of school age reduced to such an extent that we are now considering the advisability of closing this school. These are matters that confront us, apart altogether from the insanitary condition of the building. From a sanitary standpoint the building has been condemned by the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services, the Inspector for Ontario and a number of Indian agents at the Cowichan and other Indian agencies. The R.C.W.P. in the district have not advocated the closing of the building but have expressed the view that the institution, in their judgment, is no longer necessary.

The educational set-up suggested in my letter to you of May 28th is exactly the same set-up as we have now in operation at the Sts. Catherine (R.C.) School in the Cowichan Agency. This school was built in the year 1921-30. The set-up is exactly the same as the one approved by the Government for Eskasoni and for Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia. A clergyman with pedagogical training will be in charge of these schools.

The Mohawk Institute, the St. George's School at Lytton and the Shubenacadie Residential School (R.C.) are, and always have been, departmentalized institutions. The St. George's School and the Mohawk Institute have never been operated at any time by the Anglican Church or by the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Church of England. Should the Mohawk Institute be operated jointly, there would be no change whatever in the status of the school. The New England Company, in making their grant request that a regularly ordained Anglican clergyman be employed as principal.

There is of course a financial side to this question. I have no desire to emphasize this side unduly but I do feel that it is worthy of consideration, in view of the difficulty we have experienced in securing the funds necessary to...
maintain our Indian day and residential schools in a high state of efficiency. I have before me the last audit statement on the Mt. Elgin Institute. This statement is dated May 26, 1945. The Auditor, in this report, states:

"The cost per pupil per year shows an increase of $34.10 over the previous year. The increase is due to the reduction in the average attendance from 141.15 in 1941-42 to 127.70 in 1942-43. The total cost for the operation of the school for the period April 1, 1944 to March 31, 1945, amounted to $75,982.35." In this connection it is significant that the total welfare program on the Caradoc Reserve for the fiscal year, which includes the care of the aged; deserted wives; agricultural operations; drainage; house repair; construction of homes; the purchase of seed, farm machinery, etc., amounted to $10,827.84. In other words we are spending $200.61 annually for the general welfare of the Indian population and $200.61 on each pupil in attendance at the Institution, and this figure of course does not include other educational costs on the reserve. I am frankly of the opinion that these expenditures are out of balance. This was the opinion expressed somewhat bitterly by the agents at the conference already referred to.

It is scarcely necessary to add that should you require additional information I shall be glad to supply it at any time.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Following receipt of your last letter and memorandum, we have had the opportunity of thinking more about this, and also of having a conversation with Mr. Strapp, the Principal; and as our Executive will not meet until June 21st, I thought I should write regarding certain matters which I think need a little further clarification.

May I say that it is our information that, whilst one school was closed on the Reserve, another room was opened in the basement of a church, and that this is in operation. Perhaps you would clarify that for us. Our information is that there are just as many rooms being operated today on the Reserve as there were. In that connection, may I point out something of which you are already aware—that the policy of withholding from the public the information concerning school enrolment and a great many other details which were available some years ago is altogether to be deplored, and I hope that some way will be found to get this information available for free distribution. At the same time, I would like to make it quite clear that I have never yet asked for any information from your Department without its being forthcoming immediately—and sometimes, I am sure, at great trouble to those who work in your Department. I do not know to whom we should make representation, but there is altogether too little information available in detailed form.

I went over the Mount Elgin building a week ago, and whilst it is not in good repair, as I have already admitted, it is no different in construction from what it was fifty years ago, and the fire hazards which now obtain have been the same all through these years. In that connection, may I ask if it is to be assumed that the Mohawk Institute—which dates from approximately the same period—is to be considered so much superior to Mount Elgin that it is going to be continued? You have the advantage of having visited both—I have never seen the Mohawk Institute and would not presume to pass any judgment on it—but we should like to be sure that the basis on which the proposal is made that all the children go to the Mohawk Institute—which is that the building there is much better—is actually based on fact.

The difficulty at Mount Elgin is very largely with the basement. There is no question that the boys' playroom was wet and dirty when I was there a week ago. The water seeps in from the side walls, and the result is very bad. There is no doubt about that! But, in the meantime, I think that the situation could be remedied if one were to go to the expense of digging a trench all around the building down to the floor level of the basement—which, by the way, would be some three...
or four feet above the bottom of the foundation; clean off the wall, coat it with cement; paint it with asphalt; and then put weeping tile all around it. I think that would eliminate all the wetness in the basement; but, not being a builder, I can only venture the opinion of an amateur.

As I have already stated, we are ready to assist in a survey of the Reserve; but may I say that there must also be a survey of the Six Nations Reserve. From what little knowledge I have, I think it would be apparent to anyone that the place where there is least need of a residential school is the Six Nations Reserve; and, conversely, the place where a continuation school is most likely to be successful, on the basis suggested in your letter, is precisely the same point. From the little information I have been able to gather, I think that it is extremely unlikely that it would be possible to get a sufficient number of children of the secondary school grade to make worthwhile the operation of a school of that kind on the Caradoc Reserve, unless it were fitted up to provide accommodation for pupils from outside Reserves. This brings me to a suggestion which I have been making for a number of years—seemingly without effect. It is that some competent educationist be asked to make a survey of the educational needs of all the Indians of Canada. Let him start, if you will, in Ontario; and then after he has done that, let him sit down for a day or two with representatives of the Department and of the Church and see whether a satisfactory solution cannot be arrived at.

The more I think of your proposition to place all the children of school age who need residential school care in one institution—and that one under the direction of the Church of England,—the less I think of it. We have already had experience in a number of cases of children of United Church parents being sent to Anglican schools. Whilst I have no fault to find with the religious and moral instruction which they are given, yet the fact remains that when they come back to the Reserve they consider themselves members of the Church of England, and when our missionary tries to interest them in church work, they reply that they are members of the Church of England—and very often that is simply a cloak for non-attendance and indifference. That difficulty has arisen in a number of cases, and that, in spite of the finest co-operation between the two Churches where the local school is situated, I have no doubt that the Church of England missionaries on Reserves where the children attend United Church schools find that the same situation obtains.

I know that you will think that I am raising a great many objections; but this is a pretty serious step to take and I want, so far as it is possible, to see how each step in the process will work out.

I was quite interested in your description of the Mohawk Institute, the School at Lytton, and the Shubenacadie Residential School as being departmentally operated institutions. Are we to presume therefore that in these departmentally operated institutions—such as the Mohawk Institute—no one church is given any special privilege or right to give religious instruction? I am afraid that your argument will hardly hold water. And I am sorry that there are no Protestant Indian children in the Shubenacadie Residential School so that I might test out this question of departmentally operated institutions!

I should like to have some further elucidation of the Auditor's report quoted on the second page of your memorandum. Here again, of course, we have no figures. The total amount which the Government paid to the Mount Elgin School for this period was $22,871.02, and the $37,000 includes the sum of $11,749.33, which Mr. Strapp has entered as "value of produce raised and consumed." I suppose it is fair to include that as part of the cost per pupil, but, if this is done, then I think...
it could be very materially reduced so as to make a much better showing.

There is no doubt that the total cost of the welfare programme on the Caradoc Reserve is high; but so long as the Government maintains the Reserve system, there is only one thing to be expected—that it will decrease but rather increase. One cannot expect, on the one hand, to maintain a system, the operation of which saps all individual responsibility from the Indian, and, on the other hand, hope that the amount which will be required for the care of the aged, agricultural operations, drainage, etc., will decrease. That is simply impossible!

I should be very glad if you would give further consideration to the matter of having a complete survey of educational needs in Ontario; and also if you could send me a full statement of the cost of operation of all residential schools for the fiscal year 1942-43. You have been good enough to send me these statements for the years in which they have not been printed in the Auditor General's Accounts. These include per capita grants, etc., and give the total for each school. If it is necessary to have them mimeographed, I should be glad to get a sufficient number of copies so that they could be sent to the representatives of all the Churches.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 10, in which you seek additional information with respect to the marginally-noted subject.

I am anxious to avoid in this correspondence, if I can, a discussion of government policy. Such discussion should really be carried on by the Minister or by the Deputy acting on his behalf. I am convinced that I should confine my attention to the task of supplying information and an interpretation of the educational policy followed by the Department, particularly in recent years.

The records here indicate that the Back Settlement School, in the Caradoc Agency, was totally destroyed by fire on April 30, 1943. Immediately following this fire, the Anglican Bishop placed the nearest Anglican church at our disposal, without cost, for educational purposes. A school has been conducted in the basement of that church during the present academic year. It has at this date a small enrollment, with an average attendance of 14. In my last letter to you, I referred to the closing of the Muncey School, which had at the time it was closed an average attendance of approximately 5.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, a report of this branch for the fiscal year 1942-43. The figures for the fiscal year 1943 have not been completed by the Treasury Branch but will be released in the course of a few weeks. I shall be glad to have Mr. Phelan prepare for you a statement somewhat similar to the statement prepared by him last year.

I have never pretended at any time to pass judgment on the general condition of the Mt. Elgin Institute. I did state quite frankly, however, after my last visit, that in my judgment the building was in an insanitary condition. It has, however, been considerably improved around in recent years. These men point out that the buildings themselves are on a mound and consequently subject to erosion. When Mr. Dudley erected supports to protect the gable of the classroom building from collapse, he did so on the specific understanding that it should not be hazardous. He did the building collapse some time in the immediate future. It has always appeared to me that the building is somewhat deceptive in that the outside appearance is not wholly unattractive. I think it is only fair to you to add that a number of the agents at the recent convention held in

Rev. George Dorey, D.D.,
Associate Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
United Church of Canada,
299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2, Ont.
Toronto stated quite emphatically that, in view of the inadequate condition of the building, they were not prepared to encourage Indian pupils to attend the institution.

I note that the Mohawk Institute was reconstructed at a cost of approximately $50,000.00 in the years 1922-23 and 1923-24. In addition to this, the grant of $5,000.00 a year contributed to the Department for the operation of this school has been spent from year to year on general maintenance. The school should be borne in mind that children for the Mohawk Institute are recruited from Tyendinaga, Gibson, Caughnawaga, Sarnia, Moravian, Walpole Island and a number of outlying reserves. The pupils in attendance at this school from the Six Nations Reserve are, with one or two exceptions, orphaned or children from deserted homes. In this connection, I should mention that two years ago we made an arrangement whereby high school studies are provided at two or three of the Indian day schools on the Six Nations Reserve. In addition to this, we have an arrangement with the Brantford Collegiate Board whereby the children who complete the high school course on the reserve with a creditable standing proceed with Grades 10, 11 and 12 at the Brantford Collegiate Institute. In my judgment, it would be very unwise and - if I may say so - pedagogically unsound to modify this program in any sense until it has been given a few years' trial. What's more, I find in Canada was a continuation school to which we could send pupils for training in agriculture, home economics, auto mechanics, handicrafts, etc. These children might remain at the Indian day schools until they were 18 or 13 years old and then proceed to the continuation school where they will be interested to learn that the number of pupils proceeding with high school studies on the Six Nations Reserve is equal to the number of white pupils proceeding with these studies in the adjoining communities.

You appear to have misunderstood my reference to the Shubenacadie Mohawk Institute and Lytton Schools as being departmentally operated. I can only repeat that statement, not as an expression of opinion but as a statement of fact. The Mohawk Institute and the school at Lytton are actually leased by this Department, on the understanding that they will be operated by the Department of Canada for the education and civilization of Indian children. They are leased on the understanding that a fully ordained Anglican clergyman will be employed as principal. The three schools, of course, are operated by the Department in conformity with subsection 2 of Section 10 of the Land Act, 1913, subsection (2). No Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices". You state that you are sorry that there are no Protestant Indian children in the Shubenacadie Residential School so that you might test out the question of departmentally operated institutions. I simply cannot grasp the meaning of this reference.

I was intentionally conservative when giving the expenditures involved in the operation of the Mount Elgin Institute. I simply submitted figures showing the actual disbursements. I did not include depreciation on buildings, farm machinery, etc., nor did I include inspection fees or the cost -
the cost of school supplies, desks, text books, maps, etc., which are supplied from year to year from a distinct and separate appropriation and which are not included in the regular auditor's reports.

I should like you to read again the last paragraph of the memorandum sent forward by me in my letter of May 31. Why I was anxious to point out there was the wide discrepancy between welfare expenditures and the annual expenditures at the Mt. Elgin Institute.

I shall be glad to send on the financial statement just as soon as we can secure the figures from the Treasury officials.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Mr. Greer:

We have, at the Caradoc Agency, Muncey, Ontario, a residential school, known as the Mount Elgin Institute. This school was established on the reserve about a century ago. Recent reports from our officials indicate that the building is at present in a somewhat dilapidated and insanitary condition. Despite this fact, however, it is not generally thought that we will be able to secure the funds for a new building at any time during the years immediately ahead of us. The suggestion has been made that it might be possible to close this school by making greater provision for the education of children at Indian day schools in the agency and that a number of orphan children now enrolled at the institution might be provided with accommodation at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario.

The Mount Elgin Institute is operated by the Department in co-operation with the United Church of Canada. The representatives of this Church feel that before a final decision is reached in respect to the residential school, a thorough survey of the constituency served by it should be made by a competent educationist. I have been wondering if it would be possible to secure the services of one of your public school inspectors for this task. It is our intention that the inspector undertaking the survey be accompanied by our inspector of Indian Agencies for the province of Ontario, Mr. W. S. Arneil, and by a representative of the United Church of Canada, probably a clergyman. I am disposed to think that the survey would require about two weeks of an inspector's time, and I would like it undertaken, if at all possible, early in September.

I am of the opinion that any of your inspectors familiar with conditions in southwestern Ontario would be suitable for the work I have in mind. I note that Inspectors Smith, Young and Webster report on the work of our schools in this section of the province from time to time. It might be advisable, however, to select an inspector other than the man actually responsible for the inspection of the Institute.

It is my present intention to visit Toronto on Saturday August 26. Would it be possible to have an interview with you on the morning of that date, say 10 o'clock? We could discuss the matter more fully at that time and perhaps reach a decision with respect to the inspector that might undertake the work.

I naturally hesitate to encroach on your time knowing how busily engaged you must be at this season of the year. If, however, you can grant me this interview, such action on your part will be deeply appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Minister:

I fear that it has taken some time to reply to your letter of December 23rd 1942 about the future of the Mohawk Institute, but it was necessary for the New England Company to take legal advice, and to ascertain the views of the Charity Commission as to how far the proposition in your letter was consistent with the Company's Charter.
