Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 10, in which you seek additional information with respect to the marginally-noted subject.

I am anxious to avoid in this correspondence, if I can, a discussion of government policy. Such discussion should really be carried on by the Minister or by the Deputy acting on his behalf. I am convinced that I should confine my attention to the task of supplying information and to an interpretation of the educational policy followed by the Department, particularly in recent years.

The records here indicate that the Back Settlement School, in the Caradoc Agency, was totally destroyed by fire on April 30, 1942. Immediately following this fire, the Anglican Bishop placed the nearest Anglican Church at our disposal, without cost, for educational purposes. A school has been conducted in the basement of the church during the present academic year. It has at this date a small enrolment of 20 with an average attendance of 14. In my last letter to you I referred to the closing of the Muncey School, which had at the time it was closed an average attendance of approximately 5.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, a report of this Branch for the fiscal year 1942. The figures for the fiscal year 1942 have not been completed by the Treasury Branch but will be released in the course of a few days. I shall be glad to have Mr. Phelan prepare for you a statement somewhat similar to the statement prepared by him last year.

I have never pretended at any time to pass judgment on the general condition of the Mt. Elgin Institute. I did state quite frankly, however, after my last visit, that in my judgment the building was in an insanitary condition. It has, however, been condemned by our own architects in recent years. These men point out that the buildings themselves are on a mound and consequently subject to erosion. When Mr. Dudley erected supports to protect the table of the chapel from possible collapse, he did so on the specific understanding that he should not be held responsible, did the building collapse at any time in the immediate future. It has always appeared to me that the building is somewhat deceptive in that the outside appearance is not shown by unrestricted use. I think it is only fair to you to add that a number of the agents at the recent convention held in Toronto stated quite emphatically that, in view of the insanitary condition of the building, they were not prepared to encourage Indian pupils to attend the institution.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR DOREY

Re: Operation Mt. Elgin Institute

The Mount Elgin Institute has at this date an authorized enrolment of 150 pupils, for which per capita grant at the rate of $2.00 is allowed. The actual enrolment last winter was 128 pupils, but 23 of these are senior girls who have exceeded the age limit. The pupils are drawn from the following reserves: Walpole Island 5; Sarnia 9; Kettle Point 17; Oneida 1; Muncey 1; Caradoc 52; Cape Croker 13; Hagersville 1 (New Credit); Moravian 2; Saugesen 4; Christian Island 7; Six Nations 9; Gibson (Parry Sound) 3; Caughnawaga 1.

The departmental records indicate that there is ample accommodation at the day schools on the reserves from which pupils are recruited and that the closing down of the Mt. Elgin Institute would cause little inconvenience in the reserves although transportation in one or two cases would no doubt have to be provided. It is interesting to note that a day school was closed at the Caradoc agency during the present academic year for the reason that the number of pupils available did not justify its operation. The teacher of this school was later transferred to the agency office where she now serves as clerk. It will be noted that 17 pupils are recruited from the Kettle Point agency and yet the attendance at this school has become so unsatisfactory and the number of pupils of school age reduced to such an extent that they are not considering the advisability of closing the school. These are facts that confront us, apart altogether from the insanitary condition of the building. From a sanitary standpoint the building has been condemned by the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services, the Inspector for Ontario and a number of Indian agents at the annual conference of Indian Affairs. The Rt. Rev. W. F. in the district has not advocated the closing of the building but have expressed the view that the institution, in their judgment, is no longer necessary.

The educational set-up suggested in my letter to you of May 26th is exactly the same set-up as we have now in operation at the Ste. Catherine (R.C.) School in the Cowichan Agency. This school was built in the year 1929-30. The set-up is exactly the same as the one approved by the Government for Eskasoni and for Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia. A clergyman with pedagogical training will be in charge of these schools.

The Mohawk Institute, the St. George's School at Lytton and the Shubenacadie Residential School (R.C.) are, and always have been, departmentally operated institutions. The St. George's School and the Mohawk Institute have never been operated at any time by the Anglican Church or by the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Church of England. Should the Mohawk Institute be operated jointly, there would be no change whatever in the status of the school. The New England Company, in making their grant, request that a regularly ordained Anglican clergyman be employed as principal.

There is of course a financial side to this question. I have no desire to emphasize this side unduly.

Following receipt of your last letter and memorandum, we have had the opportunity of thinking more about this, and also of having a conversation with Mr. Strapp, the Principal; and as our Executive will not meet until June 21st, I thought I should write regarding certain matters which I think need a little further clarification.

May I say that it is our information that, whilst one school was closed on the Reserve, another room was opened in the basement of a church, and that this is in operation. Perhaps you would clarify that for us. Our information is that there are just as many children attending school on the Reserve as there were. In that connection, may I point out something of which you are already aware - that the policy of withholding from the public the information concerning school enrolment and a great many other details which were available some years ago is altogether too deleterious. We hope that someone will be found to get this information available for free distribution. At the same time, I would like to make it quite clear that I have never yet asked for any information from your Department without its being forthcoming immediately - and sometimes, I am sure, at great trouble to those who work in your Department. I do not know to whom we should make representation, but there is altogether too little information available in detailed form.

I went over the Mount Elgin building a week ago, and whilst it is not in good repair as has already admitted, it is no different in construction from what it was fifty years ago and the fire hazards which now obtain have been the same all through these years. In that connection, may I ask if it is to be assumed that the Mohawk Institute - which dates from approximately the same period - is to be considered so much superior to Mount Elgin that it is going to be continued? I have the advantage of having visited both - I have never seen the Mohawk Institute and would not presume to pass any judgment on it - but we should like to be sure that the basis on which the proposal is made that all the children go to the Mohawk Institute - which is that the building there is much better - is actually based on fact.

The difficulty at Mount Elgin is very largely with the basement. There is no question that the boys' playroom was wet and dirty when I was there a week ago. The
water seeps in from the side walls, and the result is very bad. There is no doubt about that! But, in the meantime, I think that the situation could be remedied if one were to go to the expense of digging a trench all around the building down to the floor level of the basement—which, by the way, would be some three or four feet above the bottom of the foundation; clean off the walls, coat it with cement paint (or with asphalt), and then put waterproof tile all around it. I think that would eliminate all the wetness in the basement; but, not being a builder, I can only venture the opinion of an amateur.

As I have already stated, we are ready to assist in a survey of the Reserve; but may I say that there must also be a survey of the Six Nations Reserve. From what little knowledge I have, I believe it would be appropriate to arrange that the place where there is the greatest need of a residential school is the Six Nations Reserve; and, conversely, the place where a continuation school is most likely to be successful, on the basis suggested in your letter, is precisely the same point. From the little information I have been able to gather, I think that it is extremely unlikely that it would be possible to get a sufficient number of children of the secondary school grade to make worthwhile the operation of a school of this kind on the Caledon Reserve, unless it were fitted up to provide accommodation for pupils from outside Reserves. This brings me to a suggestion which I have been making for a number of years—seemingly without effect. It is that some competent educationist be asked to make a survey of the educational needs of all the Indians of Canada. Let him start, if you will, in Ontario; and then after he has done that, let him sit down for a day or two with representatives of the Department and of the Church and see whether a satisfactory solution cannot be arrived at.

The more I think of your proposition to place all the children of school age who need residential school care in one institution—and that one under the direction of the Church of England—the less I like it. We have already had experience in a number of cases of children of United Church parents being sent to Anglican schools. Whilst I have no fault to find with the religious and moral instruction which they are given, yet the fact remains that when they come back to the Reserve they consider themselves members of the Church of England, and when our missionary tries to interest them in church work, they reply that they are members of the Church of England—and very often that they are members of the Methodist Church and indifferent. That difficulty has arisen in a number of cases—and that, in spite of the finest co-operation between the two Churches where the local school is situated. I have no doubt that the Church of England missionaries on Reserves where the children attend United Church schools find that the same situation obtains.

I know that you will think that I am raising a great many objections; but this is a pretty serious step to take and I want, so far as it is possible, to see how each step in the process will work out.

I have your letter of May 26th, and, after giving it some consideration, I am writing to let you have my own personal reaction. Naturally, such a drastic proposal as you outline will have to receive the consideration of the Executive of our Board. I do not remember that you had spoken to me about the approach which had been made to the New York Committee with respect to the future of the Mohawk Institute, but we did discuss the problem of education on the Caradoc Reserve. I shall be quite frank in my reaction.

In the first place, I do not think you intend the suggestion that the School at Muncey be closed on June 30th, 1943, to be taken seriously. To ask the Board of Home Missions to consent to this after the School has been in operation for these many years, when a notice is sent to us on May 26th - that is, less than one month and four days' notice - is a good deal more than I think you think we are likely to consider as within the realm of practical politics.

I also note that your proposition involves closing the School now and leaving all these children who are at present in the School without any educational facilities, and to next year a secondary or continuation school and a teacher's residence would be built. I do not think that is feasible - and I do not think you do either.

I should also like to draw your attention to the fact that the suggestion that the Mohawk Institute be operated on a departmental basis is so complete and radical a departure from the system which has hitherto obtained in the operation of our schools, that I do not think it can be carried out without taking into account certain factors which involve the Churches. I do not know what the attitude of The Church of England would be. I note, however, that it is proposed to set up this institution as a residential school for non-Catholics. May I ask if it is seriously proposed that the non-Catholics in Ontario would be treated in any way and the Catholics and all the rest of the Dominion would be treated in another way? I do not think this is possible. Nor do I think that the Catholic Church would look with any favor on the setting up of a residential school of the size of the Mohawk Institute, to be operated on a purely secular basis. I am not very strong on sectarianism, but I do feel that the religious side of the work of the Indian schools must be considered. However, the relation you have with the Mohawk Institute and with The Church of England is not my business.

I come next to a very serious feature of the proposition. According to the last Census, there are 5533
Indians in Ontario who are counted United Church. There are 9747 Church of England, and 9862 Roman Catholics. Your proposal, if it were carried through, would mean, so far as the United Church is concerned, that we would have to close a single residential school in Ontario to which our children could be sent; but it would leave all the Roman Catholic schools, with a total pupilage of 705, in full operation.

It would leave The Church of England schools, with a pupilage of 520 (I have eliminated the Mohawk Institute), also running. I do not think that this will commend itself to the judgment of the United Church.

Further - and in this I am only expressing my opinion - I do not know what the official attitude of the Executive of our Board would be. It seems quite improbable that an Executive would look with equanimity on a proposal that would deprive the United Church of another residential school. I beg to point out that we gave up Coqualeetza. Ahousaht has been closed - Kitamaat has been closed - and whilst these latter two were not very large, yet the total pupilage of the residential schools of the United Church is a good deal less than it was some years ago. We shall await with a good deal of interest - and I was going to say expectation, although that is the wrong word - to hear of one single, solitary Roman Catholic School having been closed. We might as well face the fact that when the school was closed at Coqualeetza, and each year school at Ahousaht, the Indian people whose children had been going to these schools, were approached by representatives of the Roman Catholic Church, with a proposal that their children attend one of the Catholic schools. I know perfectly well that the theory that Catholic children ought to go to Catholic schools, and Protestant children to Protestant schools; but there is absolutely nothing which says that a man may not change his church affiliation in order to get his children enrolled in the school which seems to him, for the time being at least, to offer the greater advantage. This has been done. You and I are powerless to do very much about it, because we believe in freedom. But I think these matters must be faced.

Having said all this, I fully realize that the Mount Elgin School is in a deplorable condition and that it has long outlived its usefulness; but I have always been to the plainsmen to appeal to the Executive of our Board to urge the expenditure of $200,000.00 of Government money to replace this old building. I realize that the situation at Mount Elgin is in a bad way, and, personally, I am quite prepared to co-operate with the Department in making the survey suggested; but we might as well face the fact that, so far as the Indians concerned, they are not going to be pushed around too far nor too fast in connection with these residential schools; and we shall expect the same policy to be followed on Reserves where the people are Roman Catholic as you are suggesting in the case of this Reserve, which is predominantly Protestant.

Finally, may I say that it does not seem to us to be fair - and I do not think we can get away with it - to notify Mr. Strapp on the 27th May that his ten years' principalship is coming to an end, without saying why the proposal to close the school would mean; because I do not think that either you or I can envisage Mr. Strapp as an educationist, doing the work which you suggest should be done on this particular Reserve. Re: Operation Mount Elgin Institute.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

The Director is in receipt of a memorandum from the Deputy Minister, dated May 22, 1943, in which Dr. Camsell discusses the subject matter of certain reports that have been sent forward to him on conditions at the Mount Elgin Institute. Dr. Camsell, in his memorandum, states: "It would seem quite clear that we are not justified in permitting the Mount Elgin Institute to be operated after the end of the present school year, not so much because of recent happenings, but because of the unsatisfactory condition of the school building".

You may remember that during the course of one of our discussions I intimated to you that we were communicating with the New England Company with respect to the future of the Mohawk Institute. A few weeks ago the Minister wrote to the Secretary of the Company and in that letter offered to take over the property at Brantford and operate the school there as a departmental institution for the care and education of non-Catholic children in western Ontario. The Minister has not yet had a reply to this letter, but it is altogether likely that a reply will be received at an early date. My personal opinion is that the Mount Elgin Institute might very well be closed at the end of the present academic year, on the understanding that a secondary or continuation school and a teacher's residence would be built next year. At this school a course should be provided of a vocational character and a certain amount of training provided on the school farm, which, in my judgment, should be retained. The Principal of the School should be a United Church clergyman with special pedagogical training. In addition to being principal of the school, he should be Superintendent of the other Indian day schools in the Caradoc Agency. It is just possible that transportation would have to be provided along lines somewhat similar to the transportation now provided at the consolidated day school in the Cowichan agency. This is a matter which, I

Dear Sir:

The Department is anxious that you should undertake an educational survey of a number of Indian agencies from which pupils have been recruited in recent years for enrolment at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, Muncey, Ontario. We are attaching a list of these agencies for your information. We are attaching also copies of recent correspondence relating to the operation of the Mount Elgin Institute.

It is our intention that you should investigate and report upon the educational facilities available for the instruction of Indian children on the reserves visited by you and the adequacy of these schools to provide a worthwhile educational course and one designed to meet the peculiar needs of Indian pupils.

We are anxious that you should report also on the number of Indian pupils on each reserve for whom, in your judgment, institutional care or residential school accommodation should be provided. We have in mind orphan children and children from disrupted homes.

You will note from the attached correspondence that a decision was reached by the Government a few months ago to close the Mount Elgin Institute at the end of the academic year 1943. In view of the representations made to the Department by representatives of the Home Mission Board of the United Church of Canada, it has been decided to continue the operation of this school during the present academic year. In view of this decision, we feel that a very thorough survey of the educational facilities at the Caradoc Agency should be undertaken and a definite recommendation made with respect to the future of the Mount Elgin Institute. If you are of the opinion that this school should be closed in the immediate future, what type of school should, in your judgment, be substituted? It would be appreciated also if you would report
fully upon the adequacy or inadequacy of the accommodation available at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont., for non-Catholic orphan children and neglected children might be recruited from reserves in western Ontario, for whom educational facilities should be provided by Government.

The Minister of the Department is of the opinion that the educational courses provided for Indian pupils should become increasingly more practical and vocational in character. No doubt, you will keep this expressed opinion of the Minister in mind as you proceed with your survey. We should also add that it is the intention of the Government to proceed with an extensive building program in the immediate post-war period. This program will be undertaken to provide employment for men released from military service. As a department, we have been asked to provide a list of the school buildings, particularly Indian day school buildings, that in our judgment may be needed during the five year period immediately following the close of the war.

You will note in the correspondence a suggestion that the Caradoc Agency be organized as an educational unit with a full-time fully qualified superintendent in charge. You might express your opinion on this suggestion and its practical value from the standpoint of providing a more efficient educational set-up at the agency.

Where consolidated Indian day schools have been established in the Dominion, transportation facilities, usually motor buses, have been provided. It is just possible that you may deem it necessary to recommend that provision be made for somewhat similar facilities at a number of the reserves, particularly at the Caradoc agency.

While these terms of reference are submitted for your guidance and in the hope that they will prove helpful, we want you to feel perfectly free to submit any recommendations or make any suggestions which in your judgment would strengthen and improve the educational facilities on the reserves visited by you.

You will -
You will be accompanied during the course of this survey by Mr. W. S. Arneil, Inspector of Indian Agencies for the province of Ontario, and by a representative of the United Church. Transportation facilities will be provided by Mr. Arneil.

VII. THE SUMMER SCHOOL

This school will be organized to give graduates of Ontario Normal special preparation for teaching in Indian Schools by offering courses in the Special Subjects (Manual Work, Home Economics, Auxiliary Class Training, Kindergarten Primary, Music, etc.) and in Indian Service (Study of the life and customs of the Indians, Special Methods, etc.).

Courses in Special Subjects may be taken by qualified officials in the Indian Affairs Branch assisted by leaders in the Ontario System. The Special Indian Service Courses would be in charge of officials who know the life, habits and customs of Indians.

Teachers already in Indian Schools should attend this school and in this way qualify for better service.

By holding frequent discussion groups and conferences during the session of this school, these experienced teachers could help each other and the beginners to gain the objective of the school.

Attendance can be made compulsory by the Indian Affairs Branch assuming the cost of living allowance and transportation to be paid partly at the time of the school and the remainder after a period of service or by giving attractive increases in salary to those who attend the summer school.

VIII. CONCLUSION

We are conscious that this report leaves many details to be considered, many definitions to be clarified, but we believe that our commission was to point the direction rather than chart the course in detail. In fact the detail of this report may exceed our commission.

We believe that our proposals are sound and their adoption will lead to the improvement of Indian Education on our reserves. Difficulties lie in the way of this adoption but we trust that they will not discourage those in authority from daring to make the attempt to carry out our suggestions.

REPORT RE SURVEY OF INDIAN EDUCATION ON RESERVES IN WESTERN ONTARIO

The Survey consisted of:

(1) Visits to homes and schools on the Muncey, Oneida, Six Nations', Cape Crocker, Saugeen, Kettle Point, Sarnia and Walpole Island Reserves; (On these visits I was accompanied by some or all of: Mr. W.S. Arneil, Inspector of Indian Agencies; Rev. R.M.M. Joblin, United Church Missionary at Muncey; and Rev. Geo. Dorsey, D.D., Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada).

(2) Conferences with these three gentlemen and the inspectors named below.

The life-long experience of Mr. Joblin among Indians has been a valuable aid with certain phases of my work in this survey.

(3) Conferences with teachers and agents on these reserves;

(4) Visits to the Mohawk Institute and Mount Elgin Residential School;

(5) Written reports from five public school inspectors who visit these reserves — Messrs. J.B. Webster, Brantford; J.M. Gane, Walkerton; Geo. A. Pearson, Chatham; H.B. Galpin, Sarnia; and D.G. Smith, London.

(6) Examination of reports relating to enrolment, attendance and progress of pupils in the schools on these reserves;

(7) Reading of reports of other surveys in Canada and United States.

Points Revealed by this Investigation

(1) Indians who had attended Residential Schools appear to be very successful in later life although the younger Indians appear to drift back into old habits and customs for a time after graduation. They appear to find the progress of changing from a life where all features of it were ordered by the institution to one of absolute freedom on the reserves a very difficult adjustment and naturally so. It is not surprising if for a time they "run wild".

The older Indians who are so successful were usually individuals who entered the residential school about 12 or 13 years of age after having attended day schools near their homes. They also report that they were given opportunities of practising leadership among their fellow students and some opportunity of doing some advanced academic work in addition to good training in agricultural and vocational subjects. They prize the religious training received in those institutions. In their day at these schools the proportion of younger children was not so large as today.
There is a tendency today among many families to evade the responsibility of the training and raising the children by sending, or wishing to send, their children to the residential school.

Indian Agents at several of the reserves believe that the orphans and children from broken homes can be accommodated in Indian homes on the reserve and can receive their elementary education at the local Day Schools. Other authorities intimate that Indians will readily adopt such children. Such adoption deserves careful supervision.

Your committee believe that for children from Grades I to V or VI depending on the age of the children, a home atmosphere is superior to that of an institution for the natural development of the children, unless the home conditions are very adverse.

The education of Indian children requires teachers who understand these children, who have some knowledge of their background, who are sympathetic and who have sufficient training to enable them to adjust the curriculum and management of the school to the particular needs of the children. These teachers ought to be able to conduct elementary classes, at least, in Handwork, Home Economics, Agriculture, Art and Music. They require special K.F. Training and ability to overcome language difficulties.

Generally teachers in Indian Schools do not have these qualifications. Frequently they are selected without proper regard to qualifications and occasionally against the advice of the local inspector.

Some of the Day Schools have a very ample supply of necessary teaching equipment and books for supplementary reading. Many have a very inadequate or unsuitable supply of these things. The buildings in some cases are out-of-date; others are above the average of our white elementary schools. In a general way the best service occurs where the Indian Agent and the local Inspector work in closest co-operation. The Agent has so many other details and interests to take his attention that we should not be surprised when he fails to give this matter the consideration it requires.

Attendance at the Residential Schools is much better than at Day Schools. Attendance Officers with authority to enforce attendance are necessary.

The provincial course of study needs to be modified for Indian Schools. We believe that properly trained teachers with adequate supervision can make the necessary adjustments. Special attention to Arts and Crafts, Home Economics, Manual Training, Agriculture, Art and Music should be required.

A Senior School or a Senior Room could provide these in more detail for senior pupils and at the same time provide training in leadership, religion, sports and more advanced academic subjects.

This would leave more opportunity to overcome the language difficulty and the retardation in the earlier grades.
Our Residential Schools are planned as Vocational Schools. The enrolment indicates that they are being used in a large measure as orphanages or children's shelters, and in a certain measure, as reformatories. The large proportion of small children interferes with the other purpose of the school and the young children tend to be neglected for part of the day. Sending refractory children to the institution creates problems of discipline which definitely interfere with the good work which the school might do.

The younger children will receive more and better attention in a school planned for them. The school for older pupils could serve their needs more adequately if a sufficient number of them were present to carry out the plans of the school as they are intended to work. As it is today the pupils who are able to do the work on the farm and in the house are required to do more work than should be required. There is not sufficient emphasis on the training to be derived from this work and too much importance attached to the necessity of producing sufficient to keep the Institution running.

The education of the children is linked up with the progress in general on the reserve and thus many other factors on each reserve affect the efficiency of the work of the schools. Where parents are able to work at home on the reserve, the attendance at school is not subject to the same interruption as in cases where the parents have to leave the reserve for certain periods in order to earn a living.

The progress of the people and their outlook on the future has an important effect on their attitude toward the school. The response of the children to any educational plans for their improvement is affected favourably or adversely in an important measure by this attitude of the folks at home. Every improvement in the life of the adults will lead to better results in our schools. In this field the Indian Agents generally give good service. Their main efforts appear to be spent in plans for the improvement of living and working conditions among their charges. This work has an important bearing on education; as these conditions improve, the parents will give increased sympathy and moral support to the work of the schools, creating a more receptive attitude among the pupils. It may be possible to develop a co-ordination of the work of the Agent and the teacher so that each will aid the other in the main objective—to develop good citizens of Canada among our Indian people.
I. MOUNT ELGIN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

(1) The enrolment is too small for continued operation under present plans.
   (a) The per capita payment is insufficient to maintain the school;
   (b) This forces too much labour on the pupils (profit rather than educational policy becomes the object of this work);
   (c) This condition is aggravated by the presence of so many younger children.
   (d) The staff has been reduced; school hours are reduced; and the work increased for all.

It is but fair to note that these conditions have been aggravated by the present general prosperity due to war conditions when older pupils find jobs so easily. We doubt that these conditions will be permanently as bad as they are now, but we do believe that they will continue to affect the efficiency and usefulness of the school.

(e) The enrolment has been reduced also by the policy of sending only pupils from broken or disrupted homes; at least one Agent is so unsatisfied with this Institute that he has favoured others in competition for pupils; some pupils have been sent to the school for reformatory treatment - this has not enhanced the reputation of the school and has increased the severity of the discipline - discouraging the better type of prospect. Other Institutes have been able to secure pupils who under other circumstances should have gone to Mount Elgin. Possibly the main cause of the lower proportion of older pupils is the present opportunities for their employment.

(2) The main building can be used temporarily for the purposes indicated below, but this should be considered as temporary measure until war restrictions will permit the construction of a modern fire-proof building planned to serve these purposes. The old school building should be abandoned and removed immediately.

(3) Agents on the other reserves intimate that orphans and children from disrupted homes can be accommodated in other homes on the reserve. The adoption of these children should not be left entirely to the Agent for he as a rule, is not qualified to make such an important decision alone.

We recommend that the missionary to whose church the child and family are affiliated be required to report on the suitability of the home for such adoption and that the Agent be required to give a satisfactory explanation of every case in which he does not concur with the report.

(4) This leaves the orphans and children from disrupted homes at the Caradoc Agency whom we believe might be accommodated at the Mohawk Residential School if a similar policy were impossible on these reserves.

(5) We recommend that MOUNT ELGIN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL be closed.
and that in its stead there be established a SENIOR SCHOOL as described below.

II. SENIOR SCHOOL

(1) The Senior School should be a "Day" School with some Residential Accommodation.

(2) The School will serve pupils of 12-13 years of age and older. At present this means that instruction should begin as low as Grade VI and continue to Grade X. With improved educational facilities on the Reserves, it may not be necessary to offer a Grade lower than Grade VII. For the remainder of this report the use of "VI or VII" and "VII or VII" implies that at present the lower grade is recommended but that we hope for the time when the higher grade may be used.

(3) This school will accommodate Grades VI or VII to X from Caradoc Agency as Day Pupils and from outside Agencies as Residential Pupils. Residential Privileges may be open to the Caradoc pupils. Transportation for pupils from the outside fringes of the Reserves may be necessary but the proportion is so small and scattered that residence may be preferred.

(4) Pupils from Grades I to V or VI on the reserves of Caradoc should attend the local elementary Day School.

(5) Course of Study - Senior School:

The Courses or Studies for Grades VI or VII to X of the Province of Ontario modified specific needs of Indian pupils and including a large proportion of Vocational Training —

For Boys: Agriculture, General Shop, Motor Mechanics;

For Girls: Home Economics, Home Nursing, Sewing (Dressmaking as well as mending), Gardening and care of Poultry;

in addition to a good general training in English, Mathematics, Health Practices, Science as related to our everyday experiences, Social Studies (including Indian Life and History), Art, Music, Physical Training and Recreation.

The practice in Agriculture, Gardening, Poultry Management, Home Economics, Sewing, etc., may be provided by participation in work on the farm and in residence school dormitories. The emphasis shall be placed on the training to be derived rather than profits from the work. Merely routine tasks may be accomplished much more economical by the uses of experienced help and labour saving machinery. Acquaintance with the operation of labour saving machinery on the farm may open opportunities for employment in after life. A similar statement is true with respect to the work...
in the residence. At the same time it should not be forgotten that the majority of the girls eventually return to homes on the reserve for which much of such training is entirely unsuitable. The Home Economics should include training for the management of a small house with few conveniences, for the improved solution of problems connected with typical homes on the reserve. To train girls to be good house-maids in well-equipped houses ensures employment on graduation but may be a handicap in a short time when the girls return to establish homes of their own on the reserve. For this reason we recommend that the management of the humble home be given more ample attention than in the past. This led us to recommend training in Gardening and Care of Poultry for girls.

Indian Life and History is not included in Social Studies to revive old Indian Customs or to foster separations but to aid in the development of self respect in the Indian children. Pride in the achievements and deeds of valour by our ancestors arouses a pride in ourselves which is favourable to our best development.

For pupils having the necessary academic ability and ambition, special provision for qualifying for entrance to the higher grades to local High Schools should be available.

(6) The development of responsibility in the Senior pupils can be obtained or at least encouraged by giving them responsibilities to discharge in connection with work and supervision of younger pupils and as leaders in social and religious activities and in games and recreative activities.

(7) Day pupils as well as residential pupils will be required to work on the farm on Saturdays and holidays as needed. This work has a double purpose - part of the training and part of the price of the opportunity of attending.

(8) The Transition Period

The main building (now used for dormitories, offices, staff residence, etc.) may be used temporarily until war-time restrictions are relaxed and the construction of a modern plant undertaken. This old building is very unsuitable -- The dining-hall, kitchen, bathing facilities and dairy are in the basement which is dark, dingy and difficult to keep in a sanitary condition. Its construction constitutes a grave fire-risk. The dormitories are bare and lack adequate sanitary conveniences.

The building has ample space for starting the Senior School but will require extensive alterations to make it even partially suitable.

The new building should be fire proof with modern classrooms properly lighted and ventilated; a combination assembly hall and gymnasium; residence for staff and students; common room and library; vocational rooms for boys and girls; kitchen and dining-room; laundry; dairy.

We believe that in planning such a building the experience of the Canadian Indian Affairs Branch, the Indian Office in the
United States and the Ontario Department of Education will indicate whether all or part of these facilities or additional facilities are essential.

We think that the day of large barrack-like dormitories is past; that these should be planned to give students some privacy and opportunity to be responsible for a space which is more personal; rooms shared by not more than two with storage facilities for personal belongings should be provided for the pupils of the upper grades at least. Bathing and sanitary facilities should be convenient.

We note that some American Indian residences are more of the cottage type with groups having some semblance of family life under supervision of a member of the staff. Let us investigate the possibility of adopting such a feature in this new school.

May we also urge that the beauty of certain architecture be considered in the construction of this building?

III. DAY SCHOOLS

We recommend that the Day Schools now in use near Indian homes be devoted to the instruction of children from Grades I to V or VI.

While some of your buildings are very suitable for this purpose, others are entirely "out of line" with modern requirements for elementary education. A special survey of these may result in building schools more suitable.

These schools should have a definite programme aimed at overcoming the retardation which at present exists in Grades I to III.

(a) The language difficulty can be partially overcome by the use of "Experience Reading" used extensively in Bi-Lingual Schools.

(b) More regular attendance to be enforced — a bright interesting programme in which pupils succeed will improve this defect.

(c) Objective methods of teaching used more extensively will lead to better success and greater interest.

(d) These schools must have an ample supply of materials for objective teaching and for experience reading. Good readers for the purpose may not be as readily available as we who teach white children imagine.

(e) There should be much hand work of a simple nature. As the abilities of the children develop more complex work may be undertaken. Some Indian children are quite adept at an early age.

(f) The Day School Course of Study Grades I to V or VI may be a modification of the provincial course of study. The latter should be accepted as a guide only not as a requirement. It has to
be modified to suit the particular needs of individual pupils and localities. Teachers for Indian Schools should be trained to recognize the need for these modifications and to make such adjustments as are necessary. Below we suggest a plan for this training.

For Grades VI or VII to X a senior room or senior school is preferred. This may not always be possible, and the senior classes may have to be included with the juniors. Where possible we recommend that the Senior Room or School emphasize training in Crafts (Art), Manual Training, or simple shop activities, Home Nursing, Gardening and Agriculture, Music. The options will be determined very largely by the community.

If the Junior School has accomplished the conquest of retardation, the Senior Room or School will be able to carry most Indian children to Grades IX or X and accomplish much more than is possible at present.

Some of the very capable pupils may make definite preparation for Senior Grades in neighbouring High Schools, but only very capable pupils should be granted this opportunity.

School Attendance Officers who will enforce regular attendance are necessary. Attendance has deteriorated since these officers were released from duty recently.

An alternative plan which is preferred if the Indians adopt it is: Form a Parent-Teacher's or Home and School association in connection with each school. This association voluntarily assumes responsibility for enforcing attendance by creating a strong local public opinion favourable to regular attendance and by interviewing and persuading parents to send children to school regularly. This association may also report to the Agent cases where privation is the cause of absence or, better still, assume responsibility for relieving such privation.

IV. APPOINTMENT OF TEACHERS

Appointment of teachers to be made by the Department on advice, recommendation or approval of local inspector or educational superintendent -- to be free from political influence entirely.

V.

(a) Should be graduates of Normal Schools who are further prepared by
(1) The training received by teachers of Auxiliary classes.
(2) The training received by teachers of Kindergarten Primary Classes.
(3) And one of Home Economics, Manual Training, Agriculture or Music. (In normal peace time all of these courses are offered by Summer Schools in Ontario)
(4) Special training respecting Indian life, Indian outlook and objectives. (The plan for this training is outlined below)

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6205, file 466-1, part 3)
(b) Should have adequate salaries with superannuation - Salaries should be at least as high as teachers of white schools. (In normal peace time the salaries have met this requirement)

The superannuation can be arranged in one of two plans: (1) That the Dominion pay the Province the contribution just as Boards in Ontario do now and our Ontario Indian teachers be given the same status in the Ontario fund as the Ontario teachers. This may require a special agreement between the Province and the Dominion with respect to the contribution made from Provincial Funds. (2) That these teachers be admitted to the Dominion Civil Service Superannuation Fund and an agreement between the Dominion and the Province respecting the transfer of teachers from Ontario schools to Indian Schools and vice versa be made.

(c) Should have special training prior to entering Indian Schools. The summer school suggested below would serve this purpose. The teachers taking this course and agreeing to serve a definite period in Indian Schools would receive a living allowance, free tuition and transportation to the school.

(d) Residential teachers are preferred. They can assist as community leaders or directors of community activities carried by the Indians themselves.

VI. GENERAL SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

We recommend the training and appointment of a general superintendent of education for the Namaoy and Onela Reserves. Our ideal in this respect would be a young missionary of the United Church who has knowledge of and experience among Indians, interested in and sympathetic with their problems and difficulties and who is equipped with good academic training and religious leadership.

Such a man could be given professional training by a course of at least six months duration at the College of Education, Department of Education and Special Classes at Toronto.

At the College of Education he would be directed to reading related to the work required of him; supervision, administration, etc. He would attend lectures on special methods in subjects -- particularly public school subjects.

He would have frequent consultations with professors on matters relating to the work to be done.

At the Department of Education he would have consultations with leaders there -- particularly the inspectors of the auxiliary branch. Methods, organization and administration would be subjects of these consultations.

At Special Classes -- Auxiliary, Manual Training, Home Economics, Kindergarten Primary -- Visits and observations followed by
discussions with teachers and principals. Similar visits to the Normal School and observation of teacher training and practice teaching.

This man should be trained at the expense of the Indian Affairs Branch, either by paying him an adequate salary while thus engaged or by assuming the cost of training (tuition if any; living allowance and transportation). An alternative to this plan is to accept a qualified educational leader and train him with respect to special Indian problems.

The former plan is preferred because such leader can play an important part in the social, religious and community life of the reserves as well as in the more strictly educational field.

A third plan has been suggested: That for the reserves of South Western Ontario [Cape Croker to Six Nations] one Ontario Inspector of Public Schools have the supervision of elementary and Senior School education on these reserves and this inspector be assigned a special study of Indian Education to prepare him to perform the educational duties suggested below for the superintendent.

Your committee favours the plan mentioned first above, but recognizes that it may be the more difficult to adopt.

Duties of this Superintendent

[1] To supervise the work of the teachers in the Day Schools directing them in the adaptation of the school programme to the needs of the pupils, in the selection of methods, in the organization of the school and assisting them in this work. Our present system of supervision by provincial inspectors of public schools does not give the inspector adequate opportunity to help his teachers.

[2] To assist teachers in organizing and directing special activities in the Day Schools - Handwork, Home Economics, Agriculture, Music, etc.; and

[3] To co-operate with the Indian Agent and churches and other organizations in the promotion of social and religious activities on the reserve.

[4] To organize and direct a Summer School for the special training of teachers of schools for Indians for the following year;

[5] To advise, recommend or approve all applications for the positions of teachers on the Muncey and Omeida Reserves before acceptance.

[6] To organise and supervise the establishment and management of the Senior School at Mount Elgin. While he determines, directs and supervises the educational policy and programme of the school, the principal of the school will assume the responsibility of carrying out this policy and programme.

During the period of transition, the educational problems on the Muncey and Omeida Reserves, the establishment of the Senior School and Summer School will employ the full time of this official. Eventually he would be free to extend his supervision to such other reserves as the Indian Affairs Branch may deem advisable.
VII. THE SUMMER SCHOOL

This school will be organized to give graduates of Ontario Normal special preparation for teaching in Indian Schools by offering courses in the Special Subjects (Manual Work, Home Economics, Auxiliary Class Training, Kindergarten Primary, Music, etc.) and in Indian Service (Study of the life and customs of the Indians, Special Methods, etc.).

Courses in Special Subjects may be taken by qualified officials in the Indian Affairs Branch assisted by leaders in the Ontario System. The Special Indian Service Courses would be in charge of officials who know the life, habits and customs of Indians.

Teachers already in Indian Schools should attend this school and in this way qualify for better service.

By holding frequent discussion groups and conferences during the session of this school, these experienced teachers could help each other and the beginners to gain the objective of the school.

Attendance can be made compulsory by the Indian Affairs Branch assuming the cost of living allowance and transportation to be paid partly at the time of the school and the remainder after a period of service or by giving attractive increases in salary to those who attend the summer school.

VIII. CONCLUSION

We are conscious that this report leaves many details to be considered, many definitions to be clarified, but we believe that our commission was to point the direction rather than chart the course in detail. In fact the detail of this report may exceed our commission.

We believe that our proposals are sound and their adoption will lead to the improvement of Indian Education on our reserves. Difficulties lie in the way of this adoption but we trust that they will not discourage those in authority from daring to make the attempt to carry out our suggestions.
Hon. Mr. H. A. Hoey,
Superintendent, Welfare & Training Service

MEMORANDUM RE MOUNT ELGIN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

June 12th/44

I had an opportunity of discussing the whole situation with Dr. Cassell, Mr. Hoey and Mr. Jackson on Friday, June 8th. As a result, I think the following is clear:

1.- The Department intends to implement the Report of the Commission, - certainly in so far as the closing of Mount Elgin as a residential school and the establishment of a Senior School are concerned.

2.- This means the building of proper classroom accommodation, but, due to lack of materials, it is impossible to say when this will be done.

3.- This also means the building of a residence, - perhaps not so large as the present one.

I must say that it is my judgment that these two things do not necessarily hang together; that is to say, it is absolutely essential that a new classroom be built as soon as possible, but the present building would be suitable, temporarily.

I pass on my judgment as follows:

1st. There would be a smaller number of pupils to be accommodated, and the pupils would be older.

2nd. There would be no very small children, and consequently the present fire hazard would be to some extent, at least, mitigated.

3rd. The only reason that I have for even suggesting that the present building should continue is that, to my mind, the first thing the Department must face is the replacement of buildings that have been burned; and the next thing is the very much needed extension of buildings. These will certainly take all the money that the House of Commons is likely to vote for some years - even after the war.

4th. It seems obvious that if the whole School were closed now, it would throw altogether too heavy a burden on the present accommodation and a lot of children would be left without schooling at all.

5th. On the basis of the above, it is agreed that we should continue to operate as at present, with the definite understanding that whoever the new man is who is nominated to the Department, he will distinctly understand that it is for a limited period, on the present basis. What the period may be is difficult to foretell - Mr. Jackson thought two years, Dr. Cassell, Mr. Hoey and I thought it would be longer. I should have no hesitation in saying to a possible appointee that it would be four years before anything would be done.

6th. In the meantime, it is imperative that there be a clear formulation of the steps which must be undertaken in working out the policy. It cannot be put into effect all at once; indeed it would be very much better if the changes could be made gradually. In any case, the Indians should be advised of what is proposed.

I should, therefore, think that there should be next Fall a conference between Mr. Hoey, the representatives of the Church, and possibly Inspector Young, to discuss the Report and see what is the next step.

REPORT ON SURVEY OF INDIAN EDUCATION ON RESERVES IN WESTERN ONTARIO

The Survey consisted of:

1. Visits to schools and homes on the Muncey, Oneida, Six Nations, Cape Crocker, Sangen, Kettle Point, Sarnia and Walpole Island Reserves;
2. Conferences with teachers and agents on these reserves;
3. Visits to the Mohawk Institute and Mount Elgin Residential Schools;
4. Written reports from five public school inspectors who visit these reserves — Messrs. J.G. Webster, Brantford; J.M. Gane, Walkerton; Geo. A. Pearson, Chatham; H.B. Galpin, Sarnia; and D.C. Smith, London.
5. Examination of reports relating to enrolment, attendance and progress of pupils in the schools on these reserves;
6. Reading of reports of other surveys in Canada and United States.

Points Revealed by this Investigation

1. Indians who had attended Residential Schools appear to be very successful in later life although the younger Indians appear to drift back into old habits and customs for a time after graduation. They appear to find the progress of changing from a life where all features of it were ordered by the institution to one of absolute freedom on the reserve a very difficult adjustment and naturally so. It is not surprising if for a time they "run wild".

   The older Indians who are so successful were usually individuals who entered the residential school about 12 or 15 years of age after having attended Day Schools near their homes. They also report that they were given opportunities of practising leadership among their fellow students and some opportunity of doing some advanced academic work in addition to good training in agricultural and vocational subjects. They prize the religious training received in these institutions. In their day at these schools the proportion of younger children was not so large as today.

2. There is a tendency today among many families to evade the responsibility of the training and raising the children by sending, or wishing to send, their children to the residential school.

3. Indian Agents at several of the reserves believe that the orphans and children from broken homes can be accommodated in Indian homes on the reserve and can receive their elementary education at the local Day Schools.

4. Your committee believe that for children from Grades I to V or VI depending on the age of the children, a home atmosphere is superior to that of an institution for the natural development of the children, unless the home conditions are very adverse.

5. The education of Indian children requires teachers who understand these children, who have some knowledge of their back ground, who are sympathetic and who have sufficient training to enable them to adjust the curriculum and management of the school to the particular needs.
of the children. These teachers ought to be able to conduct elementary classes, at least, in Handwork, Home Economics, Agriculture, Art and Music. They require special K.P. Training and ability to overcome language difficulties.

(6) Generally teachers in Indian schools do not have these qualifications. Frequently they are selected without proper regard to qualifications and occasionally against the advice of the local inspector.

(7) Some of the Day Schools have a very ample supply of necessary teaching equipment and books for supplementary reading. Many have a very inadequate or unsuitable supply of these things. In a general way the best service occurs where the Indian Agent and the local inspector work in closest co-operation. The Agent has so many other details and interests to take his attention that we should not be surprised when he fails to give this matter the consideration it requires.

(8) Attendance at the Residential Schools is much better than at Day Schools. Attendance Officers with authority to enforce attendance are necessary.

(9) The provincial course of study needs to be modified for Indian schools. We believe that properly trained teachers with adequate supervision can make the necessary adjustments. Especial attention to Art and Crafts, Home Economics, Manual Training, Agriculture, Art and Music should be required.

(10) A Senior School or Senior Room could provide these in more detail for senior pupils and at the same time provide training in leadership, religion, sports and more advanced academic subjects.

(11) This would leave more opportunity to overcome the language difficulty and the retardation in the earlier grades.

(12) Our Residential Schools are planned as Vocational Schools. The enrolment indicates that they are being used in a large measure as orphanages or children's shelters. The large proportion of small children interferes with the other purpose of the school and the young children tend to be neglected for part of the day. The younger children receive more and better attention in a school planned for them. The school for older pupils could serve their needs more adequately if a sufficient number of them were present to carry out the plans of the school as they are intended to work. As it is today the pupils who are able to do the work on the farm and in the house are required to do more work than should be required. There is not sufficient emphasis on the necessity of producing sufficient to keep the institution running.

(13) The education of the children is linked up with the progress in general on the reserve and has many other factors on each reserve affect the efficiency of the work of the schools. Where parents are able to work at home on the reserve, the attendance at school is not subject to the same interruption as in the cases where the parents have to leave the reserve for certain periods in order to earn a living.

The progress of the people and their outlook on the future has an important effect on their attitude toward the school.
The response of the children to any educational plans for their improvement is affected favourably or adversely in an important measure by this attitude of the folks at home. Every improvement in the life of the adults will lead to better results in our schools. In this field the Indian Agents generally give good service. Their main efforts appear to be spent in plans for the improvement of living and working conditions among their charges. This work has an important bearing on education; as these conditions improve, the parents will give increasing sympathy and moral support to the work of the schools, creating a more receptive attitude among the pupils. It may be possible to develop a co-ordination of the work of the Agent and the teacher so that each will aid the other in the main objective — to develop good citizens of Canada among our Indian people.
Munsee and Oneida Reserves (Cont.)

II. Mount Elgin Residential School

(1) The enrolment is too small for continued operation under present plans.

(a) The per capita payment is insufficient to maintain the school;
(b) This forces too much labour on the pupils (profit rather than educational policy becomes the object of this work);
(c) This condition is aggravated by the presence of so many younger children;
(d) The staff has been reduced; school hours are reduced; and the staff increased for all.

It is but fair to note that these conditions have been aggravated by the present general prosperity due to war conditions when older pupils find jobs so easily. We doubt that these conditions will be permanently as bad as they are now, but we do believe that they will continue to affect the efficiency and usefulness of the school.

(e) The enrolment has been reduced also by the policy of sending only pupils from broken or disrupted homes.

(2) The main building is still serviceable and can be modernized for the use indicated below. The old school building possibly should be abandoned and removed.

(3) Eventually a new modern class-room building as suggested below should be provided.

(4) Agents on other reserves intimate that orphans and children from disrupted homes can be taken care of in other homes on the reserve. This leaves a small number from the Caradoc Agency who could be accommodated at Mohawk Residential School.

(5) We recommend that Mount Elgin Residential School be closed as such and used as indicated below.

III. Senior School

(1) We recommend that a Senior School partly Residential and partly Day be established at Mount Elgin.

(2) This school will accommodate Grades VI and VII to X from Caradoc Agency as Day Pupils and from outside agencies as Residential Pupils. Residential privileges may be open to Caradoc pupils.

(3) Pupils from Grades I to V or VI on these reserves to attend day school.

(4) Course of Study — Grade VI or VII to X — Courses of Ontario modified so as to include much vocational training—

Boys: Agriculture, General Shop, Motor Mechanics.
Girls: Home Economics, Home Nursing, Sewing (Dress-making as well as mending), Gardening and care of Poultry.

In addition to a good general training in English, Mathematics, Health Practices, Science of ordinary living, Social Studies (including Indian Life and History) Art, Music, Physical
RECOMMENDATIONS

Muncey and Oneida Reserves (Cont.)

III. Senior Rooms (Cont.)

Training and Recreation.

For pupils having the necessary academic ability and ambition, special provision for qualifying for entrance to the higher grades in local High Schools should be available.

The practice in Agriculture, Gardening, Poultry Management, Home Economics, Sewing etc., may be provided by participation in the work on the farm, and in the residence school dormitories. Emphasis to be placed on the training rather than the profits from the work.

(5) The development of responsibility in the Senior pupils can be obtained or at least encouraged by giving them responsibilities to discharge in connection with work and supervision of younger pupils and as leaders in social and religious activities and in games and recreative activities.

(6) Day pupils as well as residential pupils will be required to work on the farm on Saturdays and holidays as needed. This work has a double purpose — part of the training and part of the prize of the opportunity of attending.

(7) The Present Plant at Mount Elgin—

(a) The main building (now used for dormitories, office etc.) can be used temporarily for these purposes until such time as a modern class-room building can be provided. Part of the present staff can be utilized. The provision of the new class-room building should be made at the earliest opportunity as this suggestion in this section is made only for the purpose of continuing service while the change is being made or until war restrictions are removed.

(b) We believe that the present dormitory space is ample for future needs for an indefinite period, but that it should be remodelled for the use of Senior pupils by making the following changes:

(1) Divide the space into rooms for two pupils with storage accommodations for personal belongings. This can be done without altering the present position of the windows.

(2) Part of the area can be fitted up to serve as a wash-room and lavatory with modern sanitary and bathing facilities.

(3) There is also sufficient space for a Common Room on this floor.

(4) Rooms for academic and special classes can be provided in this building with very little changing.

(5) We think that the dining-room might be on the main floor when the modern class-room building is provided.

(6) The laundry may also be placed in this building.
IV. A Voluntary Enrolment

Your committee look for a change of atmosphere about the whole institution. We hope for the day when Indian parents and pupils will desire to attend such a senior school and count it a privilege to be admitted — one which can be held only by proper conduct and steady progress and application to studies. Instead of having to bring pupils back after they have run away from the institution, the principal may discharge those who refuse to conform to proper school practice. This will be the worst punishment that can be applied to the students of the future.

We realize that this vision involves great and important changes, but do not consider the ideal impossible of attainment. We further believe that the adoption of this report in its entirety will lead to a new day in Indian Education not only on the Munsey and Oneida Reserves but throughout Ontario Reserves and possibly all over Canada. We realize that we have merely indicated the way and that others will develop and improve the ideas suggested far beyond either our conception or our ability to conceive means of improving the schools devoted to Indian Education.

We trust that the difficulties lying in the way of the adoption may not discourage those in authority from daring to make the attempt to carry out our suggestions.
Suggested by Messrs. Joblin and Young

General.

I. Teachers

(a) Should be graduates of Normal Schools who are further prepared by:

(1) The training received by teachers of Auxiliary classes.
(2) The training received by teachers of Kindergarten Primary Classes.
(3) And one of Home Economics, Manual Training, Agriculture or Music.
   (In normal peace time all of these courses are offered by Summer Schools in Ontario.)
(4) Special training respecting Indian life, Indian outlook and objectives. (The plan for this training is outlined below)

(b) Should have adequate salaries with superannuation — Salaries should be at least as high as teachers of white schools.
   (In normal peace time the salaries have met this requirement)
The superannuation can be arranged in one of two plans: (1) That the Dominion pay the provinces the contribution just as boards in Ontario do now and our Ontario Indian teachers be given the same status in the Ontario fund as the Ontario Teachers. This may require a special agreement between the province and the Dominion with respect to the contribution made from Provincial Funds. (2) That these teachers be admitted to the Dominion Civil Service Superannuation system, an agreement between the Dominion and the Province respecting the transfer of teachers from Ontario schools to Indian schools and vice versa be made.

(c) Should have special training prior to entering Indian Schools. The summer school suggested below would serve this purpose. The teachers taking this course and agreeing to serve a definite period in Indian Schools would receive a living allowance, free tuition and transportation to the school.

(d) Residential teachers are preferred. They can assist as community leaders or directors of community activities carried by the Indians themselves.

II. Course of Study

The provincial course of study should be accepted as a guide. It has to be modified to suit the peculiar needs of individual pupils and localities. Teachers trained as suggested would be capable of making the necessary adjustments. It should include Indian Life and History in the Social Studies.
RECOMMENDATIONS

General (Continued)

III. Day Schools

Day schools near Indian homes to care for children from Grades I to V or VI.

These schools should have a definite programme aimed at overcoming the retardation which at present exists in Grades I to III.

(a) The language difficulty can be partially overcome by the use of "Experience Reading" used extensively in Bi-Lingual Schools.

(b) Regular attendance to be enforced—a bright interesting programme in which pupils succeed will improve this defect.

(c) Objective methods of teaching used more extensively will lead to better success and greater interest.

(d) These schools may have an ample supply of materials for objective teaching and for experience reading. Good readers for the purpose may not be as readily available as we who teach white children imagine.

(e) There should be much hand work of a simple nature. As the abilities of the children develop more complex work may be undertaken. Some Indian children are quite adept at an early age.

For Grades VI or VII to X a senior room or senior school is preferred. This may not always be possible, and the senior classes may have to be included with the juniors. Where possible we recommend that the senior Room or School emphasize training in Crafts (Art, Manual Training), or simple shop activities, Home Nursing, Gardening and Agriculture, Music. The options will be determined very largely by the community.

If the Junior School has accomplished the conquest of retardation, the Senior Room or School will be able to carry most Indian Children to Grades IX or X and accomplish much more than is possible at present.

Some of the very capable pupils may make definite preparation for Senior Grades in neighbouring High Schools, but only very capable pupils should be granted this opportunity.

IV. Appointment of Teachers

Appointment of teachers to be made by the Department on advice, recommendation or approval of local inspector or educational superintendent—to be free from political influence entirely.
RECOMMENDATIONS

Muskeg and Oneida Reserves

I. General Superintendent of Education.

We recommend the training and appointment of a general superintendent of education for these reserves.

(a) He should be a man with knowledge and experience among Indians, interested in and sympathetic with their problems and difficulties; with good academic training and religious leadership.

(b) Train this man (if necessary) by giving him six months at the College of Education, Department of Education and Special Classes at Toronto.

At the College of Education he would be directed to reading related to the work required of him: supervision, administration, etc. He would attend lectures on special methods in subjects — particularly public school subjects. He would have frequent consultations with professors on matters relating to the work to be done.

At the Department of Education he would have consultations with inspectors of auxiliary branch. Methods, organization and administration would be subjects of these consultations.

At Special Classes — Auxiliary, Manual Training, Home Economics, Kindergarten Training. Visits and observations followed by discussions with teachers and principals. Similar visits to the Normal School and observation of teacher training and practice teaching.

(c) Either pay this man an adequate salary; or assume the cost of training; during the training period. (Cost of training to include tuition, if any; living allowance and transportation). Pay him an adequate salary when he begins his duties.

(4) Duties of this Superintendent.

(1) To supervise the work of the teachers — directing them in the adaptation of the school programme to the needs of the pupils; in the selection of methods; in the organization of the school and assisting them in this work.

(2) To organize and direct special activities in the schools — Bandwork, Home Economics, Agriculture, Music etc., and assist teachers to do this.

(3) To supervise and organize social and religious activities in the reserve among adults in co-operation with the Indian Agent and the churches.

(4) To organize and direct a Summer School for special training of teachers of schools for Indians for the following year. Teachers from other reserves to be sent to this summer school.

(5) To advise, recommend or approve all applications for teachers of Indian Schools on these reserves before acceptance.

(6) To organize and supervise the establishment and management of a Senior School.
