Dear Mr. Arneil:

The Fifth Victory Loan is over, West Middlesex has 111% of its quota and the brakes will not hold, subscriptions are still trickling in.

In the period since you were here, I have had replies from my fellow inspectors. These I have summarized in the enclosed sheets. Naturally each man's opinion is coloured by the local situation under his supervision.

I have been consulting several reports on events. Today has been spent reviewing and summarizing these reports and reviewing our observations also in September, Tuesday and Wednesday, Mr. Joblin and I plan to spend on the Munro Reserve and at Mount Hope.

I intend to spend at least one day at the Department of Education at Toronto with Dr. Brier and others who may be of assistance.

As per your instructions, I am visiting Ottawa and your officials if necessary. I believe that Mr. Dozy wishes me to call on him while in Toronto. Do you expect Mr. Joblin to accompany me?

I note in Mr. Hoey's letter of August 23rd, that he wishes me to report on the number of Indian pupils in each reserve for whom my judgment, institutional care or residential...
A. Qualification and Training of Teachers

1. Brant - Teachers on Six Nations Reserve trained at Normal School. All hold First or Second Class Certificates - generally well qualified. Additional training in particular school; leadership like Manual Arts, special Summer Course, Art, Manual Training, First Aid Training, etc.

2. East Middlesex - recommends special training for work with Indians. Summer school preferred. Correspondence courses would help. (Indian education, the objectives, social position and future of Indians). Suggest that the Government pay tuition and living costs for teachers of Indians taking provincial courses. Teachers should be trained in Indian schools for at least three years. Training should be held at one point under direction of experienced leaders among Indians. Suggest that K. P., Choral work and Manual Arts be the special courses.

3. Lambton - Special training - Auxiliary Classes, K. P. and Manual Arts.

4. Kent - The job requires the full time of the teacher. Does not favour special Summer Course for Indians and teachers.

5. Bruce - Special Certificate - Art, Music, Home Economics, Manual Training, Agriculture. Underlined preferred. Special Summer Course - Special methods for teaching Indian Children.

B. Employment and Remuneration

1. Brant - Make position attractive enough to draw those who may make it their life's work. Pay teacher's cost of special training. The residence desirable - particularly when hiring a married man - desirable arrangement. Remuneration graded - increases available as experience demonstrates worth. Maximum to be attraction. Agent and Inspector co-operate in hiring teachers. System works in Brant.

2. East Middlesex - recommends the plan used in Brant. Favours better salaries, living accommodations, superannuation, etc.

3. Lambton - recommends same. Indian teachers should be paid $200 to $300 per year more than teachers of white schools in same locality. Increase should be based on Inspector's report.

4. Kent - Objects to reduction of 1/10 by closing schools for one month - calls better pay. Dominion Government should consider them as Civil Servants and allow them to participate in Dominion Superannuation. Does not favour admitting them to provincial superannuation scheme.

5. Bruce - Bruce citizens should be on plan. Should be one. Estimate - 21,000 rising by $100 to $1,500. Objects to present method of luring teachers. Inspectors recommendation should be observed and considered.

C. Courses of Study

1. Brant - Modify Provincial Course. Emphasize Arts and Crafts - have Economics, Manual Training, Agriculture. Social Studies - emphasis on Historical Background of Indian People.

2. East Middlesex - No special suggestions but apparently has similar views.

3. Lambton - Specified fundamentals in English, Arithmetic, Science, Geography and History of Canada and Britain. Arithmetic to be taught by extensive use of concrete material and practical applications of this subject. English of business and everyday life in community. 1/3 to time to be devoted to craft work - home economics and manual training.

4. Upper Grand - Science should become Agriculture. Garden at every school planted and supervised with active co-operation of Agent. Agent should provide necessary supplies and become responsible for the appearance of the school grounds.

5. Kent - Not satisfied with use of provincial course. It should be modified to meet their needs.

6. Bruce - Similar to Brant.
De Institutional Training

1. Brant - Impressed by work at Mohawk Institute. Likes the arrangement except for the lower grades. Proposes that half day system (half day school - half day work on farm) be deferred to Grade V.

2. Kent Middlesex - No remarks.

3. Lambton - No knowledge.

4. Kent - No experience with Institution directly. Pupils return to reserves after leaving former mode of life. Suggests that graduates of institutions be encouraged live as self-supporting citizens and succeed away from the reserves. Appears to favour encouraging Indians to a definite movement from reserves to an independent successful life among whites. Believes that, given a fair chance, the Indian can take his rightful place as a citizen of our country.

5. Bruce - Likes the practical courses given in institutions. No experience beyond a visit.

E. On a Central School

1. Brant - Not favourable - believes Grade IX at Day Schools merely wanted to prevent pupils from attending institutions. Favours a bus service to Brantford Collegiate for Grade IX and for such promising pupils as may be able to profit from more extended secondary school training to provide trained Indians as leaders, teachers, nurses, etc.

2. Kent Middlesex - No comment.

3. Lambton - No comment respecting central schools. Favours the continuing of secondary education at local High School or Collegiate Institute. Suggests that Department of Indian Affairs pay fees and collect the same from the parents.

If Department pays fees, it should guide the student in selecting his secondary school course.

4. Kent - Favours a central school for senior pupils.

1. It would give Day School teachers more time with juniors and thus overcome some of the retardation in the primary classes.

2. A larger number of students could succeed.

3. The cost of transportation or residence might be too heavy as to hinder the adoption of such a plan.

5. Bruce - Such a plan is highly desirable where the population of the reserve warrants its adoption.

F. General Remarks

1. Brant - 1. Recommends addition of some effective means of enforcing more regular school attendance.

2. Favors employment of the joint function. An inspector surgeon (traveling with school, etc.)

3. Primary or Lower Grade teachers should be assigned to old reserves.

2. Kent Middlesex - All graduates 1 and 2 given by Bruce. Adds that a large part should be adopted and trained with special training.

3. Lambton - Suggests that the inspectors should be assisted by one of the following:

1. By the local sanitary and hospital.

2. By the local physician.

The Indian Agent may be another competent man interested in the welfare of the reserve. If such an individual exists, he should receive proper attention under present system. Reeves Nos. 1 and 3 of Report very definitely.

4. Kent - Highest on Nos. 1 of Report.

5. Bruce - No remark made here because of separation.

6. Brant -

1. Would need sufficient teachers in Indian schools nationally and provincially.

2. One annual inspection not satisfactory. Inspectors at least two and their inspectors be persons to be most familiar to local superintendents.

3. Inspectors in reserve districts so located that other equipment should receive attention and action.

Sept. 2, 1946.

Re: Enrolment, Mount Elgin Institute.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant and also copy of a letter received by Dr. Cochrane from the Principal of the Mount Elgin Institute, sent forward therewith.

The records here indicate that a number of our residential schools throughout the Dominion are experiencing difficulty this year in securing the number of pupils for which per capita grants are allowed by the Department. This difficulty can be attributed, in part at least, to prevailing economic conditions. At the time of my visit to Brantford a few weeks ago, I was informed that Indians were earning $10.00 a day in the tobacco fields and that a great many teen-age boys were engaged in this work.

In addition to existing economic conditions, there appears to be on the part of certain Indian agents in southwestern Ontario a deep-seated prejudice against residential schools in general and the Mount Elgin Institute in particular. This opposition or prejudice was very much in evidence at the conference of agents held by Inspector Arneil in Toronto early in 1943. As a matter of actual fact, I was the only one at that conference who spoke at all in favour of the courses provided at our residential schools. I did my best, in my own peculiar and awkward way, to remind the Indian agents that we had twelve million dollars invested in residential school buildings and that in this critical period it was their duty and responsibility to see that these institutions...

I have tried three pupils of that age on my own premises and do not wish in any case to leave them here and come to Residential School, but if all the Agents were to be convinced that by sending in here a larger enrollment of students that all students could then get the training in art, music, machineshop, poultry, bee keeping, animal husbandry and a host of other things then it might be that we could carry out our program. We must have more students and we must have more twelve to seventeen year old students. On Saturday afternoon, February 10th, Walter Sumners, of the Onetidas of the Thames, a resident pupil of the Mt. Elgin Residential School, was run over by the School's truck.

It appears that the truck had been down to the village, and on the return trip the above-named pupil ran behind and either slipped, or fell, and the rear wheel passed over his leg causing a double fracture. Other pupils were around who picked the boy up and carried him into the School. Immediate emergency treatment was given and the lad's parents notified. Dr. Washburn was called and he placed the leg in a plaster bandage, after which arrangements were made for his removal to Victoria Hospital for X-Ray and necessary treatment. Owing to snow-blocked roads the removal was somewhat delayed. He was taken out on a westbound freight to the village of Melbourne and transferred to an ambulance for travel to the hospital.

There is no blame attached to anyone; all concerned feel that it was a regrettable, unfortunate accident. Mr. Soper assures me that it is a rule of the School that no student should run after, or climb on, a moving truck or car. Complications are not anticipated and it is hoped that the knitting process will be successful.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Mount Elgin Residential School

I visited the School last week-end and went into certain aspects of its operation with the Principal. The Auditor has just completed his visit and I hope that the report which he has to make will be in the hands of the Department very soon.

The financial situation - that is so far as cash transactions are concerned - is getting worse. The overdraft has increased. The actual situation of the School, having regard to its liabilities and assets, is undetermined, as we have not tried to estimate either the extent of the assets nor whether they have increased during the year. In any case, this would only be of value if we were going to close the school and thus have to know whether we had sufficient assets to meet our liabilities.

We must face the situation for the coming year, because it seems obvious that there will be increased difficulty in keeping up the pupilage, and we certainly cannot continue to operate at the present rate. I have made a very hasty comparison between the Receipts and Expenditures for the period, May 1st, 1943, to April 30th, 1944 - for which there is the last audited statement - and the year April 1st, 1944, to March 31st, 1945, which is the last fiscal year for which you will have a report. I find that the School has been operated with very little, if any, increase in expenditure, but there has been a drop in receipts of over $3,000, in the per capita payments. These figures are by no means audited, but they do, I think, show the situation.

To make matters worse, there recently appeared in the London Free Press a somewhat lengthy statement by the Archbishop of Huron in his address to the Synod of the Diocese of Huron. In this statement the Archbishop said that a crisis had arisen in the history of the Mohawk Institute. I am attaching to this letter a copy of the two main paragraphs in the Archbishop's statement. Our people have been stirred up by the fact that the Archbishop said that changes had been considered by which the pupilage of Mount Elgin School would be transferred to the Mohawk Institute. From the statement, I gather that the Anglicans are going to operate the School. Whilst I am in no position to speak for The United Church of Canada as a whole, it is my considered judgment that one residential school for the Protestant Indians of Southern Ontario is quite sufficient; but I am equally sure that it should not be operated either by the United Church or the Church of England, if we are to have any sort of good understanding. I expect to be in Ottawa next Thursday and will be glad to have the opportunity of going into the matter with you.

P.S.
Our Executive will meet on June 29th, and I must at that time bring the matter of the continued operation of the Mount Elgin School, under the present circumstances, before the meeting. I should be glad to have the opinion of the Department to assist us in coming to a conclusion.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Mount Elgin Residential School

I regret to say that, due to a variety of causes, I have omitted writing you about the Mount Elgin School until it is almost too late. Our Executive will meet on Friday, and I want to place before it the matter of the future of the School, based on your letter of October 22nd, and also the memorandum which I received, dated November 14th. As I see it, our Executive would like to know:

1. Whether the Department would like to carry through in principle the recommendations of the Special Report made by Inspector Young and submitted February 18th, 1944. These are in general:

(a) The discontinuance of the Mount Elgin School as a residential school as at present carried on.

(b) The taking care of the educational needs of the Indian people by the establishment of a Senior School on the Muncey Reserve, with a set-up as outlined in the Report mentioned above, with such modifications as the present situation may require.

(c) The taking care of the children that cannot, for various reasons be accommodated in day schools in a way that would be satisfactory to the Church authorities.

I have in mind that there are on the Caradoc Reserve some children who would find it very difficult to get to school and for whom transportation should be provided; and that in attendance at the Mount Elgin School there are children whose parents are dead or who come from broken homes. In our conversations at various times, it has been suggested that these would be taken care of either by adoption or by being taken into an already existing school, such as the Mohawk Institute. I might point out that this would probably entail careful supervision, either through the Children's Aid Society or through the appointment of an officer of the Department who would act towards these

p.t.o.
children as an officer of the Children's Aid Society would in other parts of the Province.

You will realize that our Executive must make a definite decision, because, if the School is to be discontinued as at present carried on, we ought to give notice to all concerned at the present time and make provision for the staff.

If the School is to be carried on for another period of twelve months after June 30th, I feel sure that our Executive would like to know, so that it can deal with certain financial matters which have arisen.

I shall be glad if you will give consideration to this and let me have an answer, if possible, by air mail, special delivery, in time for our Executive, which will meet on Friday.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 23rd, in which you seek information with respect to the administration of the Mount Elgin Residential School.

It is our intention to discontinue the operation of the school as a residential school on or about June 30th. Provision has been made in the estimates now under consideration for the construction of a four-room Indian day school, to be erected on a site not yet definitely selected. Provision will be made for the transportation by bus of pupils living beyond walking distance of the school. It is our intention to make provision for orphan pupils either by adoption on the reserve or by enrolment at the Mohawk Institute or by the utilization of both these agencies. No definite decision has yet been reached with respect to the future of the Mohawk Institute. The representative of the New England Company has found it impossible to secure transportation facilities to this country and has asked the Government to defer its decision until his arrival. Because of the closing of the Mt. Elgin Residential School and the lack of information concerning the plans for the future, there are many questions in your minds. It will be the chief purpose of this News Sheet to answer those questions as soon as answers are available for them. Your Director of Education, Rev. E.E.M. Joblin, is particularly anxious that you should have a part in developing and carrying out any plans for the education of your young people. This means that you should have all possible information from time to time. At the earliest possible date, a public meeting will be arranged for the discussion of these matters. In the meantime, the News Sheet will try to fill the gap.

With respect to the Day Schools which have been in operation, the teachers of last year have all been engaged for the coming term, and it is assumed that school will open in September as usual. The next date will be announced later.

For the new school, the excavating has been completed and we are assured that the new building will be ready for use some time in the fall. The Director has recommended that the senior pupils begin their terms at the proper time and carry on in the classrooms of the old building until the new school is ready. This has not yet been confirmed by the School and Training Division, however. Transportation has been promised for those who need it.

Very little definite information can yet be given, but it is hoped that the new school will be reasonable at least for pupils from Grade VII to X. It is quite important therefore that the Director be notified of those pupils who want to attend the school for the work of Grade IX or X. Those who failed in a grade will be able, we hope, to take the subjects they need to complete the grade in addition to each work of the next grade as they are able to do. Pupils who have been out of school and are interested in returning for either academic or practical training, should see Mr. Joblin. One of the main guiding principles of the new system is that the school programme should be adjusted to the needs of the pupils. You can help us to determine those needs. The Director will welcome your suggestions and opinions as to the educational needs of our young people.

It is expected that Mr. Lloyd Johnson will be continued as teacher in the Senior School. Other teachers will be secured depending on the enrolment and type of work to be taken.

Incidentally, Rev. Joblin and I would like to thank you for the warm welcome we received from so many of you since returning to Muncey. We look forward to many pleasant associations with you in the life of the Church, School and Community. I have set up an office in the old school building where you may find me from 9 a.m. to noon from Monday to Friday at least until Sept 1st. Office hours will doubtless have to be altered after the two weeks.

Rev. E.E.M. Joblin, M.A., B.D.,

On this date Mr. G.J. Down, Indian Agent, Muncey, Ont., contacted the writer and stated that some of the buildings at the above school had been broken into during the previous night and a quantity of goods were missing. He asked that this detachment make an investigation regarding the matter.

A patrol was made to the school by S/Cst. Minham and the writer and it was learned that a battery from a tractor had been taken. This tractor was in a locked garage and lock had been forced. Also missing from this garage was a five gal. can of gasoline. There was also a farm wagon in the implement shed and the two back wheels and tires of this wagon had been taken. These tires and wheels were practically new. The tires were Firestone Rib Implement tires - 6.00 x 16. The implement shed was not locked. From the blacksmith shop there was a small tool box full of tools missing and a cupboard containing an assortment of tools had been broken into and a number of tools were missing. This cupboard was locked and the lock had been prior off. The door of the blacksmith shop was broken on the morning of the 5-11-46 but it was not known whether it had been definitely broken on the night of the 4-11-46. The lock bore no signs of being tampered with and it is thought possible that it might have been closed but had not caught. All the locks on the doors and cupboard were ordinary padlocks.

It is not definitely known what tools are missing other than that it is believed they are mostly wrenches. These tools belong to Mr. Bush, farm instructor and he is away at the present time.

A close examination was made for finger prints or foot prints and nothing was found. There were some tire marks at the far end of the yard and it is believed that they may be the marks of the car that was used by the person or persons who committed the thefts. However, they were of very little value.

Extensive inquiries have been made both on and off the Reserve regarding this theft but to date no information has been obtained that would indicate who the guilty person or persons are, nor where the goods are. It is thought that it is all probably that some of the Indians from the local Reserves are responsible for this theft and that they will have cached the goods in bush or some out of the way spot. Searches of likely places have been made but nothing has been gained.

Inquiries are continuing in this matter and a further report will be submitted to meet the aforementioned diary date.

S/Cst.,
D.O. 19-12-46.

With reference to the above and previous report from this detachment, continued inquiries have been made regarding this theft but nothing definite has been obtained.

Information was received regarding a car being hidden in dense brush on the Reserve and this car was supposed to have the tires on which were stolen from the above school. Searches of the bush were made in an effort to locate the car but was nothing found.

On 2-13-46 information was received from Cst. Carmichael O.P.P., that a 1940 Plymouth coach was abandoned on No. 2 highway and that stolen license plates were on this car. In company with Cst. Carmichael a patrol was made and the car located. Inquiries revealed that this car had been stolen at Courtland, Ont. near Delhi, Ont. A search of the vicinity was made and a number of articles were found hidden in the ditch. There were a number of jacks, wrenches and a number of records together with an old phonograph. Also found was a five gallon can of gasoline together with a funnel. A check revealed that this can and funnel were the ones missing from the school. Inquiries failed to reveal any information regarding who the person or persons might be that abandoned the car.

On the 7-15-46 information was received from Cst. Fulton, O.P.P., Strathroy, regarding a stolen 1933 Ford V8 and he asked that members of this detachment be on the look out for this car in case it turned up in the district. Cst. Fulton advised that two men had held up the owner of the car earlier in the day and robbed him of five dollars and had beaten him. They were carrying a .22 rifle and had clubbed him with this together with a cane and a piece of heavy stick. They had also taken a small mantel radio from his house.

In the fall of the 8-13-46 one Cecil Cadiz (Indian) drove a 1946 Chevrolet to the detachment and stated that he and two companions had found this car hidden in heavy brush while out hunting. Inquiries were made regarding this car and it was learned that it had been stolen near Tillsonburg during the early AM of 6-12-46 and that it belonged to one Eddie Downie, R.R. #1, Nodaway, Ont. In the car were found two tires, 1 Goodyear tire, 6.00 X 16, Ser. No. 64J9833, 1 Seiberling tire, 6.00 X 16, Ser. No. 6704795 and 1 Seiberling tube, 6.00 X 16. One set of tire chains were also found. There was also a number of wrenches and a tire wrench and jack. On closer examination four pairs of cheap car rims were found and there was one of these broken. On making further inquiries regarding this car it was learned that a 1935 Ford V8 had been seen on the Reserve about 8:00 AM this date and although it was not definite it was believed that one Lyle Riley and Hubert Greenock (Indians) were in the car. Cst. Fulton was immediately notified and he, together with Csts. Shipley and Carmichael patrolled to Nodaway. Cst. Fulton stated that they had recovered the 1933 Ford V8 near Homoka about 11:00 AM this date. On examining the two rear tires on Downie's car Cst. Fulton stated that tire marks near where the Ford had been abandoned were visible.

Former Mount Elgin Indian Residential School building -

The attached files concern the main building formerly occupied by students attending the Mount Elgin Residential School.

In 1896, when this building was erected, various Indian bands that were served by the school contributed $19,000.00 from their funds towards the capital expenses. Since that time, the Department has expended from parliamentary appropriation for buildings and improvements a sum in excess of $130,000.00.

In 1915 fire destroyed some of the outbuildings and pursuant to the collection of insurance $7,400.00 was repaid to the band funds leaving an equity of only $11,600.00.

This school building was condemned two years ago and is no longer in use by the Department or by the Indians. We have erected a new day school a short distance away and intend opening this school during the summer of 1948. We are still continuing to use the separate classroom block of the old school.

It has been recommended that this old main building (not the separate classroom block) be declared surplus and turned over to our Assets Corporation as surplus government property. The point at issue is whether we have the authority to do this, in view of the Indians' equity in these buildings.

SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS.

To assure equality of opportunity to the Indians of Western Ontario and the type of education they require for this critical period of transition, the following recommendations have been made:

1. That a single administrative unit for the purposes of education be made of the five reserves included in the survey (Kettle Point, Sarnia, Wabigoon, Muncey), and that a Superintendent of Schools be appointed for this area.

2. That day schools be developed as community service centres; that those of the first four reserves be two-room schools. That the Mt. Elgin Indian Residential School be such be discontinued, and a Senior School or Junior High School be built on the property at Muncey.

3. That the teachers for these schools be carefully selected from among the best in the Province on the basis of their personal qualifications, training and previous successful experience. To make this possible, other provisions must be made:
   (a) Inducements. Salaries must at least equal those of the town schools of Ontario and provide an increase for satisfactory service; there must be membership in a Pension Plan, either in the Civil Service or Teachers' and Inspectors' Superannuation Fund of Ontario; living and teaching conditions must be made attractive.
   (b) In-service training must be made obligatory, including regular Summer School Courses in Kindergarten-Primary, Auxiliary classes, Educational Psychology and related subjects; a Summer School for teachers of Indian schools should be held the first week in September, as well as monthly meetings of teachers for study and fellowship. Supervision should be more thorough, helpful and encouraging.
4. That the methods of the Activity Programme be thoroughly studied and applied, and that materials and equipment be adjusted to facilitate this type of classroom procedure. That assistance be given those teachers who will use to advantage the Audio-Visual Aids now available.

5. That the Curriculum of the Province be accepted, with adaptations made by the teacher on the basis of pupil needs. Grades I to VI should be of a general and basic character, with emphasis on the mastery of spoken English and Reading. Grades VII to IX should be provided in the two-room schools, with opportunity for High School Entrance, but emphasis on the Optional Subjects for those who will go no further. At Muncey, the day schools should include only Grades I to VI, pupils to be admitted to the Senior School at twelve years of age or after completion of Grade VI. The Senior School should specialize in Grades VII to X, both academic and vocational, but to include classes for Grades I to VI. Classification of senior pupils should be by their year in the school rather than by grade. There should be development of the courses, Home Economics, Commercial, Agriculture, Building Trades, Motor Mechanics and other practical work as the demand arises. Pupils should have the opportunity of part-time work and educational training from 16 to 18 years of age. The possibilities of apprenticeship in the building trades should be investigated. Social and recreational activities should be encouraged, and the leadership available when needed.

6. That a programme of Educational and Vocational Guidance and placement be developed and directed by the Superintendent of Schools with the co-operation of the teachers. That this programme includes responsibility for pre-school children and graduates, as well as those of school age.

7. That a serious consideration be given to making the advantages of the Senior School available to pupils of reserves other than Muncey, by the provision of residential accommodation of a kind suitable to teen-age young people.
That the Senior School be free of denominational bias; the United Church of Canada, while retaining its voice in the broader policies of the school, may surrender some of its prerogatives in the interests of the total good of the Indian people.
Superintendent of Schools:

Such an administrative unit implies the appointment of a Superintendent of Schools for the area, who would have responsibility for the education of the people of these reserves, through the day schools, the Senior School at Munsey, their attendance at High or Vocational Schools and Community and Adult Education. He would have the responsibility for the selection or approval of the teachers, the supervision of their work, the direction of their in-service training, and would co-operate with the agents and the Department in the improvement of their working conditions. With respect to the pupils, he would operate a follow-through and follow-up programme of Educational and Vocational Guidance and placement, the use of cumulative records and testing - the responsibility for adapting the educational facilities to the individual's needs. He would encourage such activities as would secure the understanding co-operation of parents and the community in the work of the schools, through some form of Home and School Clubs, community responsibility for school grounds, and possibly the formation of a school board.

The duties of a school board might have to be largely advisory in nature, but it could be given at least one responsibility, the regular attendance of the pupils.

Memorandum:

MR. HONEY,

Inspector Arnell and I visited the Caradoc Agency on May 22 and 23, in connection with the proposed erection of a new four-room day school, to replace the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

There are two sites available - one in the village of Rodney and the other on the property formerly occupied by the Mount Elgin Residential School. We favour the latter site because there is an excellent location available and, in addition, we have an opportunity for teaching agricultural subjects to the pupils.

The only difficulty with this site is that the road from Rodney to the new site is reported to be in very bad condition at certain periods of the year. The road is one mile long and it may be expensive to put it in condition to be used at all periods of the year. However, this work will be necessary, as we expect to be driving the children to the new school and, consequently, a year around road will be required.

We interviewed Mr. T. A. Caldwell, District Engineer, Ontario Highways Department, London, with a view to obtaining some assistance from the Provincial Government. Mr. Caldwell promised to inspect the road and let us have an estimate of what it would cost to put it into proper condition. When visiting Mr. Caldwell, we also met Mr. Marshall, Chief Engineer of the Highways Department, and the latter instructed Mr. Caldwell to forward a report indicating the amount which might be saved regarding what portion of the cost could be met by the Ontario Highways.

With reference to the erection of the new school, Inspector Arnell obtained the following information:

(a) Foundation - Graham and Graham, London, Ontario, are prepared to shovel out the excavation in three days' time. They will require 2 weeks' notice before we desire to have the work completed.

(b) Building Foreman - Charles Lidy, builder, Rodney, Ont., is available. He has an excellent reputation as a builder and his services can be secured within the next two weeks. He has built many houses and one church at Rodney. He can read blue prints and take full charge. Indian helpers, many of whom are competent carpenters, are available, as well as other Indian labour.

(c) Material - This can likely be secured within two months' time. It may be necessary to apply to the Timber Controller for priority. Arrangements were made with a qualified man to prepare a list of the materials and forward this to the Department by June 1.

In view of the above information, secured by Mr.
Arnall, I would appreciate it if we could receive permission to proceed. The sooner we start purchasing the material, the sooner we can commence building.

I might also mention that both Indian Agent Down and the newly appointed farm instructor have had considerable experience in erecting buildings and will be in a position to supervise the erection of the school and keep the Department fully informed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
GORDON YOUNG

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In order to ascertain what plans with respect to the education of Indians on the reserves of the Caradoc Agency had been made, I called on Rev. Mr. Joblin recently.

While I found the old buildings more or less discarded and vacant, the only signs of a new building were, (1) a hole in the ground and (2) a pile of new siding clocks. It is very evident that a new building will not be ready for September.

May I therefore suggest that Mr. Down, your agent, (or, better still, Rev. Mr. Joblin) be authorized to proceed immediately to arrange temporary classrooms in the old buildings to be used only until the new rooms are ready?

You will appreciate the immediate necessity of organizing a staff, arranging equipment and even lining up pupils for this school. Courses of study have to be planned and the supplies purchased.

I shall be pleased to hear from Mr. Joblin any news he may need, but I do urge that he be directed to see me on the opening of school in September and be authorized to take the necessary steps. He should be told what measures your department has to pursue.

Certainly the matters mentioned above should have been given consideration, and the very ill-advised delay of the following were determined:

1. The times to be used by this school;
2. The likely enrolment;
3. The number of instructors to be employed;
4. The courses to be offered;

SCHOOL NEWS

A WEEKLY NEWS SHEET FOR THE CHIPPEWA, MUNCEY AND ONEIDA RESERVES AT MUNCEY, ONT.

SATURDAY, JULY 27

Because of the closing of the Mt. Elgin Residential School and the lack of information concerning the plans for the future, there are many questions in your minds. It will be the chief purpose of this News Sheet to answer those questions as soon as there are answers available for them. Your Director of Education, Rev. E.E.M. Joblin, is particularly anxious that you should have a part in developing and carrying out any plans for the education of your young people. This means that you should have all possible information from time to time. At the earliest possible date, a public meeting will be arranged for the discussion of these matters. In the meantime, the News Sheet will try to fill the gap.

With respect to the new Schools which have been in operation, the teachers of last year have all been engaged for the coming term, and it is assured that school will open in September as usual. The exact date will be announced later.

For the new school, the excavating has been completed and we are assured that the new building will ready for use some time in the fall. The Director has recommended that the senior pupils begin their term at the proper time and carry on in the classrooms of the old building until the new school is ready. This has not yet been confirmed by the Welfare and Training Division, however. Transportation has been promised for those who need it.

Very little definite information can yet be given, but it is hoped that the new school will be responsible at least for pupils from Grade VII to X. It is quite important therefore that the Director be notified of those pupils who want to attend the school for the work of Grade IX or X. Those who failed in a grade will be able, we hope, to take the subjects they need to complete the grade in addition to such work of the next grade as they are able to do. Pupils who have been out of school and are interested in returning for either academic or practical training, should see Mr. Joblin. One of the main guiding principles of the new system is that the school programme should be adjusted to the needs of the pupils. You can help us to determine those needs. The Director will welcome your suggestions and opinions as to the educational needs of our young people.

It is expected that Mr. Floyd Johnson will be continued as teacher in the Senior School. Other teachers will be secured, depending on the enrolment and type of work to be taken.

In closing, Mrs. Joblin and I would like to thank you for the warm welcome we have received from so many of you since returning to Muncey. We look forward to many pleasant associations with you in the life of the Church, School and Community. I have set up an office in the old school building where you may find me from 9 a.m. to noon from Monday to Friday, at least until Sept 1st. Office hours will doubtless have to be altered after the term begins.

Rev. E.E.M. Joblin, M.A., B.D.,
Director of Education
Indian Affairs Branch,
Welfare and Training Division,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Gentlemen,

You will appreciate the shortness of the time now before the opening of the school term, and the need for some clarification of my plans and responsibilities. I trust you will be able to give me an early answer to the following questions and authority to act on several suggestions herein made.

1. I am most anxious to initiate our Teacher Training programme this year by holding a class from Sept. 4th to 6th inclusive during regular school hours. This implies that the schools would not open until the 9th Monday, but since so many Indians are away, there are few pupils in attendance during the first week, I should like your approval of this plan, so that I can engage the visiting speakers and arrange the programme. I see no reason for waiting a full year to inaugurate this plan, which has already been approved in principle.

2. In view of the obvious delay in the new building, we ought to plan to start school promptly in the classrooms of the old school building, which should cause no difficulties. It would entail the provision of a cleaning woman for two or three days prior to the meetings of the teachers.

3. It has been impossible as yet to discover in detail the number of pupils for the Senior School, but it is evident that there will be a good class for Grade IX. At the present it appears that we should include Grade VI in this School, to relieve the load in the other schools and enable the teachers to overcome the lag in the lower grades. In the main I prefer to think in terms of an age entrance of about twelve years, so as to provide Auxiliary class work for those of that age, whether they have reached Grade VI or not.

4. The attendance of these pupils at the Senior school will be largely dependent upon the provision of bus service, ready to begin promptly on Sept. 9th. There is no time for delay in this regard.
5. It is evident that we will need another teacher in addition to Mr. Johnson, who will be responsible this year for the shop work with the boys in addition to the studies in the senior grades. We can do part of the Grade IX work, but there should be a lady teacher as well to take the remainder of the Grade IX work together with the Home Economics work. It is altogether likely that a third teacher will be needed for the lower grades, but this can be determined later when a survey has been completed. As yet I have no information whatever as to who will secure teachers or what salary they will receive.

6. This raises the question of living accommodations for the teachers. The second apartment is now occupied by Mr. Bush, who works on the farm for the Agency. He will not be finished till Sept. 30, if then. Is he to be permitted to remain, thus preventing our engaging a married teacher, or providing boarding accommodations for the teachers? Surely Mrs. Joblin is not to be expected to board two or three teachers!

7. Parents are asking also whether text books will be provided in Grade IX. It would seem reasonable to me that this be done, but that they be expected to supply their own work books, pencils etc.

Until I receive clear answers to these questions or am authorized to proceed on my own judgment as expressed in my thesis (the contents of which are known at least to Mr. Hoey), I shall be flying blind. This is not a pleasant experience, and may prove disastrous to the whole venture. If we are to "take off" at the proper time, the visibility should not remain at zero much longer.

Would you be good enough also to direct me as to whom I should address in such letters on policy, and the proper procedure to follow? Thank you for your indulgence thus far. All the above matters have been condensed, perhaps at the risk of being incomplete, or omitting important details.

Hoping for an early reply, I am,

Respectfully Yours,

E.E.M. Joblin.

MEMORANDUM

Educational Plans for the New Caradoc Day School

The matter of educational plans for the new Caradoc Indian Day School has, for some months, been an open question and not without the usual flood of rumors and speculation. It was, therefore, with pleasure that I received your telephone message, followed by your letter, under date of August 1st, requesting a meeting and outlining the preliminary important points for discussion. The proposed agenda is as follows:

1. Temporary Use of Residential School Classrooms
2. The Grades to be Served at the New School
3. The Curriculum to be Offered at the New School
4. The Teaching Staff; Appointment, Number and Qualifications
5. Transportation Requirements
6. Teacher Training

Before proceeding I should like to point out that, contrary to some beliefs, the closing of the Mt. Elgin Residential School has not and will not create any problem in our six Indian Day Schools such as accommodation, classroom teaching and general school routine; or the necessity of breaking up classes. I feel that any temporary arrangement, under present conditions, would react unfavourably toward the new school. I simply record this fact and would like the point kept in mind and placed in the record; also the fact that I have not at any time favoured the location of the new school.

POINT 1

Temporary Use of Residential School Classrooms

It has been rumored, and I am sorry to say from official quarters, that the Mt. Elgin Residential School old classrooms are to be used for temporary purposes in teaching the higher grades at present attending our regular Indian Day Schools. Owing to the fact that we have not yet any pupils in sight, and the general courses have not been arranged; also, the facts that heating facilities are poor, that we are not overcrowded and that it is only three weeks...
before the fall term commences I see little reason and no advantage in disturbing our existing Indian Day Schools. Such a proposition would undoubtedly meet with opposition and create more problems for the Indian Agent. There is another fact which seems to have been overlooked. Many of these children of the higher grades do not return to their homes, on the Reserve, until late in the fall and even as late as December. Their parents are working in the tobacco fields or canning factories, and the children either help or go to school in the white sections. My final recommendation at this time is that we have no use for the Residential School classrooms; and until we have something definite and beneficial in the way of education in an up-to-date manner to attract and not dishearten the pupils. Under present day conditions of short supply the new school should be well on its way toward the end of 1946, and with the minor finishing touches it should be ready for a grand opening early in 1947. In the meantime every effort should be made to plan suitable courses, secure the number of likely pupils to attend and decide the teacher requirement.

POINT 2

The Grades to be Served at the New School

Grades to be served can only be determined by a knowledge of the type of school under discussion. Is it to be primary? part primary and part secondary? or secondary? Personally I think it should be mainly centred around normal grades, including Day School work, improvement and properly staffed, are efficient and able to care for all grades requiring primary academic courses. If we decide that this school is to be part primary and part secondary then there will be later difficulties to overcome which I will not discuss. Being what we are, a governmental institution, personalities, ambitions and achievements are based on grades. If we decide that this new school is to be secondary (in the main) then it calls for particular curriculum rather than the secondary curriculum. I.Q.'s are based on capabilities along the narrow channels of academic education, and entirely lose sight of brilliant possibilities along other lines. Therefore courses should be set to meet the requirement, rather than the requirement set to meet the courses. The usual requirement for University Entrance should, of course, have its place but in setting up a general Course of Studies to meet the Indian requirement the following should receive consideration:

1. Health Education
2. Machine Shop Work
3. Wood Working
4. Motor Mechanics
5. Home Economics
6. Office Practice
POINT 3

The Curriculum to be Offered at the New School

The curriculum followed in all schools is usually based on provincial requirement. It may, however, be varied to suit the local requirement and I think we should follow the line most suitable and acceptable to our Indian pupils except perhaps for a student who wishes to lead up and down for University education. He or she should then receive the very necessary assimilation requirement; by this I mean a preparatory course leading the way to immediate adjustment. This type, of course, could better be taken care of in the white High Schools.

POINT 4

The Teaching Staff: Appointment, Number and Qualifications

This point is tied in closely with point No. 2. It is usual for Secondary School teachers to hold special teaching qualifications on perhaps two or more subjects with a principal capable of teaching all academic grades; but if we are to introduce special courses then teachers with special qualifications should be selected. The number of teachers required will depend upon the subjects taught. In a school of this type teachers should be selected and appointed strictly on the basis of qualification to teach the required subject; and they should be hired on the basis of every other Civil Servant, namely a probation period. The appointment of teachers should be under the direct control of the Department; and any deviation of control to persons or group of persons or associations would definitely be avoided. It is essential when introducing new methods of education that the Department exercise its authority and accept its responsibilities. This applies not only to education but all administrative agencies. Dual control and dual authority lead only to misunderstandings, inefficiencies and a temptation to dodge onus of responsibility.

POINT 5

Transportation Requirements

Under present road conditions leading to the new school, and the general reserve conditions in particular, transportation will always create a major problem and must, of necessity, stay on main roads. No person could with any measure of assurance guarantee that students would be comfortably transported. However, since we are introducing a type of consolidated school, and since the Reserves are separated by the Thames River, also the fact that the trip covering each Reserve will take
approximately one hour with no waiting, two buses of the station wagon type, should be provided. These buses will be required to travel the main roads and pick up the students at the intersections.

POINT 6

Teacher Training

This is an interesting point and one which should be given deep thought. When one speaks of "Teacher Training" I go back into my own school days, and I am a class of student teachers who have graduated from Secondary Schools who are not in a position to finance a University education. I think they referred to them as "pupil teachers". They were students who had chosen the teaching profession as a career. I think their term was two years, and they would be placed over the Secondary School curriculum with actual teaching periods under the direct supervision of the principal or a qualified teacher. In this way the pupil teacher became very efficient and upon graduation was able to walk into any classroom with confidence and dignity. Could not such a system be arranged in connection with the new schools so that it could develop into a nucleus for supplying Indian teachers for Indian Day Schools throughout Western Ontario. This system could broaden itself out to other types of teaching such as Health, Home Economics, Mechanics etc. The thought of "pupil teachers" might be kept in mind.

CONCLUSION

In submitting this memorandum I would ask you to keep in mind that I am particularly interested in the welfare of this new school and anything I may have said is constructive suggestion, and I am sure that the officials will accept it accordingly. In a few years I shall have passed from the service of Indian Affairs. If I am able to leave a thought that will grow and build and contribute in some small measure to the uplift and education of our Indian people, I am satisfied.

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Visit to Caradoc Agency

On August 13 Mr. Arneil and I visited the above Agency. At 2 o'clock we had a long discussion with Mr. George Down. I attach a copy of the memorandum which he handed to Mr. Arneil and myself and which formed the basis of our discussion (Appendix A attached).

At 4 o'clock we held a second meeting with the Reverend E.E. Joblin and Provincial Inspectors of Schools Young and Smith. At this meeting the following decisions were reached:

1. That it would be impractical to rely on the opening of the new school until next Spring. This opening might be delayed even longer, as it depends entirely on the material situation.

2. The following difficulties present themselves to the operation of the present buildings as a temporary school:
   (a) The road from the crossroads to the school is nine tenths of a mile long and is very narrow. There is money available for the widening of this road, but the reconstruction will have to be delayed until a steel culvert is obtained. This piping has been ordered but will likely not be available for at least three months.
   (b) Several modifications will have to be made in the present heating system. Material shortages may hamper these alterations.
   (c) It is impossible to obtain snow equipment for clearing the roads. A Provincial School Consolidation is also being carried out and it will be almost impossible to borrow any of the local equipment for our use.
   (d) It is apparently impossible to have a bus contract let for the transportation of the children to the school. It will also be difficult to buy a large school bus. I am now investigating the possibilities of buying two converted Army Personnel Carriers for use as small buses.

3. The division of responsibility was clearly defined to the satisfaction of both the Indian Agent and the School Principal. It is as follows:
   (a) All matters of school administration must be forwarded to this office through the Indian Agent.

4. Recommendations:

Mr. Arneil and I are agreed that the following course should be taken:

(a) That we immediately purchase two 4-wheel drive personal carriers for use as school buses. These will have a capacity of 12 pupils each and due to their high chassis, 4-wheel drive and truck engine should be able to overcome both difficulties (2 + e and 2 - e).

Assuming that we shall be having school here this year, and for most if not all of the school year, it will be essential that we be given complete control of the Manual Training shop again, and that the tools either be returned or replaced. On this point Mr. Phelan can tell you of the present arrangement. The power tools are still the property of the Church, and Dr. Dorsey has permitted me to say that these will be sold to the Department only on condition that they be for school use. The shop is or was well equipped and will see us through the year for the boys' work. For the girls, it should be possible to have the use of part of one of the three rooms here, where sewing and dressmaking at least could be done.

Mr. Johnson has not yet had any word of his appointment, and since he has had many excellent offers of other work, it is due only to his keen interest in our work that he is still waiting. I respectfully submit that in view of his many capacities he should be offered net less than $1000 with his room, without board. He has been a successful teacher of Indian pupils for some years, can do the work we want in mechanics, radio, general shop, and the senior grades in the classroom. I have been promised a confirmation of his appointment now for nearly three months. There is plenty for him to do here in the event that the classroom did not open for two weeks after the regular time. He could do the plumbing required here, and set the manual training shop in order. I trust you can give me definite word soon, as it would be a distinct loss to us if he should accept some other work.

Could you give some thought also to the present method of recommending children to other schools, either Indian Residential or white secondary? The Agent continues to assume this responsibility entirely. It would seem to me that eventually it should at least require my approval. I trust that Mr. Arnell's expression of policy, namely that the pupils here are not going to be herded off to other schools, is the true one, and that any recommendations which may be coming in will be scrutinized carefully.

There are other matters, but I have already trespassed on your time. If my remarks have appeared too effusive, or impatient, forgive me. You may realize that I have invested a great deal in this project, I believe in it, and I believe the Department wants to see it put into operation. It would be a great tragedy if one man were permitted to prevent it. His power to do this ought not to be underestimated.

Your meeting with us last week left us with a variety of feelings. First, one of considerable encouragement by reason of the experience and vision which you bring to the work, and a feeling of greater hopefulness for a constructive forward-moving policy for our work. But in addition to this we all understand me when I admit a feeling of disappointment and even disgust at the extent to which our Agent appeared to succeed in his attempts to block the whole enterprise. I sincerely hope that his analysis of the situation will not be accepted as final.

I appreciate your sending me a copy of "Education for Action", but I already had a copy, and in view of the scarcity, am sending it back immediately. It should be available to us. I was able to secure other materials of the U.S. Office as well, such as their Manual for the Indian School Service, and their Bibliography.

Plans are under way for our teacher-training course on Sept. 4 to 6. I believe it would be of very great value to all of us if you could yourself attend at least one day of the three. If doing this, could we secure Mr. Doucet? I would appreciate it if you could let me know for which day one of you could be present. It would also be worthwhile if you could send us a sample set of the new series of texts which you mentioned.

Some instructions would also be welcome as to the making out of requisitions for materials, including books for classroom use, for library use, and also supplies for athletics and recreation. For example, I should like to secure a Volley Ball and net ($15) for use here. I have the usual forms; shall I send them in through the Agent as the teachers have done, and does this method include all types of requirements? Is it your intention to supply the text books for Grade IX? A WEEKLY NEWS SHEET FOR THE CHIPPEWA, MUNCEY AND ONEIDA RESERVES.

August 17

A meeting was held last Tuesday, which was in charge of the new Superintendent of Welfare and Training, Col. B.F. Neary, and attended by Mr. Down, Mr. Arnell, and the two school inspectors, Mr. J.G. Smith and Mr. Pearson Young. One matter of educational policy was readily agreed upon. Entrance to the Senior School will be at the age of twelve years or thereabouts, so that those who for any reason are retarded or behind in their grade will have extra help and a chance to do the practical type of study in shop work and home economics. This type of help for retarded pupils is known as Auxiliary Class work and may include pupils from Grade II up. By grades, the Senior School will probably include those from Grade II, and also (for a time) such other pupils enough for it. It was agreed also that the curriculum should be that of the Province of Quebec with such adaptations as are found to be necessary but the academic subjects should receive credit for advanced work in other High or Vocational schools if they have the ability and desire to continue. For the larger number, it was decided, work will be placed on the more practical courses of instruction such as Shop Work, Motor Mechanics and Agriculture for the boys, and Home Economics, including Dressmaking, Cooking, Home Planning, etc., for girls. Beauty culture and stenography may have to be added later. It should be repeated that the nature of the curriculum will be to meet to a great extent upon the interests and needs of the pupils, and will not be laid down in advance.

Col. Neary said that he had extensive plans for the training of teachers, which will be carried out during our plan for a brief period of three months after the opening of the school term. This means that the six teachers who now serve will open on September 1st, instead of August 15th. It will be expected to be looking the latter part of the school term, except for those who will be devoted to the study and observation of the year's work, its objectives and methods, and to observe the pupils. This will prove of great value for the work of the coming year.

It was felt that the scarcity of building materials is only delaying the completion of the new school, but it is hoped that the new classes will be able to carry on in the old building. The addition of the rooms has the effect of transportation and facilities. There is still some doubt as to whether bus service can be provided in the fall, although the idea is being worked out. Even with all its difficulties, however, it could not be expected to operate so long under the present conditions of the new type of schooling.

E.J. Martin.

The following is a progress and policy report on the above school.

I. Temporary Use of Old Residential School

(a) It is now evident that shortage of materials will delay opening of the new school until next spring.

(b) Therefore it has been decided to use temporarily the buildings of the old residential school.

(c) The two main difficulties in beginning the consolidated school system are:

1. Heating the old buildings,
2. Transportation.

(d) Heating Difficulties

There are two alternatives already proposed for overcoming this problem. Everyone concerned is hereby directed to make every effort to overcome this difficulty and to solve it in a practical manner. Mr. Louise will visit this school on September 6 to ascertain the progress made in this regard and to assist in making satisfactory arrangements.

(e) Transportation

As soon as the steel culvert arrives the short road leading into the school is to be widened and made more passable for the school buses.

....... The real
The real delay now in the opening of the school will be the provision of school buses. In order to overcome the road and snow difficulties, it has been decided to obtain two M.U.F.'s (Army Personnel Carriers). These are four wheel drive vehicles with a very high chassis and with careful drivers should be able to provide transportation for 24 children for practically the entire winter.

Four separate ways are now being explored in an effort to obtain these vehicles, namely, Van Amstel Corporation, General Motors Company, Wilson Bodies Company and Arundell Bodies Company.

II Opening of School

This should take place about October 1 using the old buildings. Every attempt will be made to overcome the main difficulty now outstanding, namely, the provision of school buses, by that date. It is emphasized that the opening is entirely contingent upon the provision of these buses.

III Division of Responsibility

(a) All matters of school administration will be referred to the Department through the Indian Agent.

(b) All matters relating to teaching procedures and curriculum adoptions can be referred directly to the Department.

IV Pupils

(a) This school will be operated in its first year for Grade 9 and 10 pupils and for those pupils requiring auxiliary training.

(b) When the school is functioning efficiently, consideration will then be given to operating it as a junior-senior high school, which will mean that it will be responsible for educating children from Grade VII upwards.

(c) A careful study of attendance at the present six day schools...
schools will be made to ascertain the number that will be available to attend the consolidated school.

I Teachers

(a) The number appointed will be dependent upon the average attendance.

II Teacher Training

(a) A brief training course will be conducted from September 4 - 6.

(b) The day schools on the reserve will open on September 9.

(c) Mr. Doucet will attend this training course on the afternoon of September 6.

III Summary

The Department has decided that it is better to begin this school on a small scale and in the old buildings rather than to wait for an indefinite period until the new school is ready. The opening date is now entirely contingent upon the provision of the two small buses.

I have your letter of August 16, and your suggestion that the main building of the Mt. Elgin Residential School be fitted up as temporary classrooms and residence, has been discussed with the Rev. Mr. Joblin.

In this connection we both readily, and hastily, agreed that the proposition would be impracticable; and would involve major difficulties which we could not hope to overcome in the near future. We therefore felt that no point would be gained by going into detail.

2. This brings us back to the original proposition of the old building. In this I have not been idle, and I submit the following:

My first job was to locate the main water supply from the springs to the main building, and then trace it on to the old building, including classrooms and apartments above. This I have done; and it would appear that our problem is to cut the main feed line, remove the pump and the present tank from the main building and install it in the basement of the old classroom building. The major part of this alteration is a digging proposition as the pressure tank is underground; and my information is that it would be cheaper to lift this tank and reinstall it, also move the pump rather than attempt to insulate the present set up which could not be accomplished with any measure of satisfaction.

I have had a plumber look the situation over and, while he is not prepared to give an estimated contract price, he is prepared to undertake the job on a labour, plus cost, basis. He estimates the job would take four or five days after the uncovering of the pressure tank, a trench dug connecting the two buildings and all disconnections made. For this work he would need three of his own men, 9 hours a day at $1.00 per hour. Basing it on the 5-day period this would amount to approximately $135.00; in addition, four Indian labourers, 5 hours a day at 60¢ per hour, approximate cost $96.00. This amount, totalling $231.00 might be estimated at $250.00 plus cost of materials such as extra pipes and fittings.

The over-all approximate cost would perhaps be less than $400.00. If you decide to have the change made please advise at an early date as the
plumber concerned is very busy and cannot guarantee his offer to do the work if we do not accept him in the very near future.

3. I have been in touch with Mr. Gordon Young, Inspector of Public Schools, and at your and his suggestion I have inspected the vehicle mentioned for pupil transportation. I understand that he is writing you on this matter and, from my telephone conversation with him, he is not particularly impressed; neither am I. The vehicle is what is known, in Army circles, as a Personnel Carrier; and I understand it is being released to Chevrolet Dealers, and not direct to the General Motors Corporation. The information, therefore, given me by the prospective purchaser is not definite enough to assure one of repair parts. It is a right-hand, four-wheel drive with an auxiliary crank-case controlling the drive which is not standard; and is not mentioned by the dealer unless questions are asked. The engine, radiator and headlights, however, are standard. Wheels are 16" with 16-925 tires. Extra tires of this size will be somewhat difficult to obtain.

There are five doors, and some type of running board would have to be installed to help the children in climbing aboard. The interior is arranged to seat five persons, but with some changes would accommodate perhaps ten children. The vehicles are second hand with, in many cases, several thousand miles registered. As I said before, I am not in possession of any vehicle except the Ford for local transportation. I do, however, realize the difficulties in obtaining the regular station wagon or the small type of school bus; and if you have decided that school must open on the suggested temporary basis immediately rather than wait for the new school, perhaps there is no alternative. But I must ask you to please keep in mind that I do not and cannot, under present conditions, especially through the late fall, winter and spring months, assume responsibility in matters of transportation. This must be entirely the responsibility of local school officials.

I have gone into this matter in detail in order to present to you a picture of the situation, and what I have accomplished since your recent visit to this Agency.

I am leaving for my vacation on the third of September running through to September 14th. I am, however, leaving everything in order for the workmen, and all concerned, to carry on during my absence.

Geo. W. Down,

Dear Col. Neary,

In the hope that some new word would be forthcoming as a result of Mr. Doucet's visit three weeks ago, I have refrained from writing you concerning our situation here. No such word has arrived; we are now but four days from the last of October, and the opening of school is scarcely more of a possibility now than it was at the time of your visit. Surely it is not too much to expect that some immediate action be taken to assure the opening of our Senior School.

In your Progress and Policy Report of August 29, the case was clearly set forth, but a very serious change of policy was declared as to the pupils to be admitted here.

"This school will be operated in its first year for Grade II and X pupils and for those pupils requiring auxiliary training."

"When the school is functioning efficiently, consideration will then be given to operating it as a junior-senior high school, which will mean that it will be responsible for educating children from Grade VII upwards."

"A careful study of attendance at the present six day schools will be made to ascertain the number that will be available to attend the consolidated school."

I submit that the above policy would be totally inadequate to the need and would have serious results in the loss of confidence of the people, and of the United Church. Your Department can ill afford any such consequences. At our first meeting, the principle of an age entrance of twelve years, to take care of retarded pupils as well as Grades VII to X, was accepted, and the people have been looking forward to the possibilities in this plan with considerable interest. The delay has already begun to make itself felt. Senior boys and girls in surprising numbers are waiting for the opening; their work in the tobacco is about over, further delay will result in a period of demoralizing idleness.

The figures submitted by me at our first meeting were based upon a thorough house-to-house survey which provided names and ages of pupils. Yet the Progress Report speaks of a careful study of attendance was made to ascertain these facts. Were my figures taken to be fictitious? A survey of attendance will not provide the required facts. Our concern is with the children in the area of school age, a larger number than have hitherto appeared on the rolls of the schools. A few of the senior pupils are attending the other schools, but even without them, there are enough pupils to constitute a good class (around thirty, with the exception of River Settlement, which has, as yet, but 19).

My survey listed 156 pupils under 12 years, 86 over twelve. This was in August, and does not represent the total. Of the older pupils, a few have since gone to Residential schools. But other pupils, not listed, have signified their intention of returning from Detroit and other places, in order to attend the new school.

It is a simple statement of fact, and no boast, that there is no other person who knows the educational needs of this place better than I or who can do as much to meet that need. Yet my hands have been effectively tied, and my judgement set aside. I can scarcely be expected to remain silent, faced with the urgent need of my children on the one hand, and the inexorable, as it seems to me, delay of the only persons who can give us the green light. Mr. Down, probably for good reasons, will take no action without direct instruction from Ottawa. I beg of you, send the needed directions immediately.

Even such details as cleaning the classrooms here, and the girls' outside toilet, setting up the water pump in this building, not to say the installation of the radiators in our apartment. The appointment of a second or even a third teacher is also awaiting your decision. I am not free to advertise or even get a line on such prospects by the ordinary means. Perhaps I am unduly concerned on this point, but it is the 27th of September, and teachers are hard to secure.

The two vehicles arrived, the ambulance most satisfactory, the lorry capable of handling all the Onaidas, but in need of alterations. The Agent has no mechanics at present; to send it out to a garage might involve weeks of delay; why not let the senior boys and Mr. Johnston work on it as a project in mechanics? This would at least permit us to use it in the meantime. These two vehicles could handle the pupils for this year, even when admitted for Grades VII to X.

At the risk of wearing your patience thin, I have felt it necessary to set forth these facts again. I have always found facts very effective weapons; can it be that a new defense has been perfected? You will have an opportunity, I believe, to set me right on Oct. 11, but I sincerely hope that before that time I shall have been pacified by the opening of our school for Grades VII to X plus auxiliary pupils, as recommended in the Young report, and as expected by the people and Church.

Respectfully Yours,

Dear Col. Neary,

For the sake of clarity, I have listed the pupils of the senior grades or ages, on the enclosed sheets, so that you could see at a glance the situation here. It is obvious that there are more pupils than can be admitted this year. I take it that those would be left in their local schools first, who are in Grade VI and making normal progress, provided that their school can give them adequate instruction. This would apply to about nine, if necessary, in all schools but Oneida No's 1 and 2, which are so taxed for space as to necessitate our taking all those 12 years or over.

Permit me to recommend, and ask you to confirm at an early date, that we begin school on Nov. 1st., regardless of any uncompleted preparations. This is a Friday, but it would give us a day to enroll and classify the pupils and Saturday to plan our work. This might mean that Mr. Johnston and I would have to manage alone until the second teacher arrives. Therefore I suggest that we open on Nov. 1st., with Grades VII, VIII, IX and X, without fail. As soon as the second teacher arrives, we would then include as many of those who are eligible as we felt we could provide for. It is fairly obvious that it will be necessary for me to supplement the classes with work of the other teachers to some extent, if they are to provide any instruction in non-academic subjects.

I am not too hopeful of securing a teacher immediately. Even though I presented an Ad to Mr. Down on the next morning, Sat., Oct. 12, it appeared for the first time on Sat., Oct. 19, with most of the items which might be inducements deleted. However, we may receive applications, which must then be sent an application form to be filled out, and returned, which must then be considered and sent to Ottawa before an appointment can be made. With little delays of a day or two here and there, this can extend for quite some time. Had it been possible to offer the apartment, or even light-housekeeping rooms as I had proposed in the Ad., you can see how much more attractive the offer would have been in these times.

On the positive side, Mr. Down has had the classrooms cleaned up this week, and we intend ciling the floor next week. Nothing has been done, however, to the water system or heating plant. I trust that there will be no delay in completing the appointment of the bus driver, and in clearing the way for the work on the bus. The truc
