Dear Col. Neary,

You will recall that I wrote two weeks ago to say that I intended to begin classes on Nov. 1st, in fairness to the senior students who were missing their work. This we did, yesterday, with 30 present in the four grades, and with six more at least who will be here next week, except in the case of two who are sick. Since the order had not come through for the driver of the truck, I undertook to drive it myself, not entirely with Mr. Down's concurrence, though he put no obstacle in my way. I intimated that while you had not actually given me permission to do so, yet you had not forbidden it either. May I say that the bus works well, and if it were at all possible to procure another such vehicle it would answer very nicely.

We are fortunate that the pupils have remained interested this long, and I am confident that any further delay would prove merely the loss of quite a number of them. You will know that Mr. Johnston will have a heavy load until the other teacher arrives, which will be in the near future I hope. It will be necessary for me to help him in some subjects.

I appreciate your sending the telegram re the truck repair, since it enabled us to have it done for yesterday, and made me feel that you doing everything possible to help us get started. We have a fine group of students and look forward to a very fruitful year. The actual beginning has done much to bolster the people's faith in our project, in which they show a keen interest.

May I ask your approval of the following suggestions?

As soon as Mr. Burch is free to drive the bus (when his appointment has been approved by the Treasury), that I be permitted, as per my earlier suggestion, to take the Lt. Elgin truck, for the pupils on the Chippewa side. This in order to have them all arrive for nine o'clock. At present it will be necessary for the bus to make two trips, as you suggested.
Upon the arrival of the second teacher, I earnestly hope I may be permitted to admit certain other pupils not yet in Grade VII, namely those who are to be regarded as Auxiliary pupils, and those from Oneida #2 and #3 schools who are 12 years of age or more, since these two schools are overcrowded, and some of them have been asked to remain at home pending entrance to this school.

By reference to the list of students I sent to you, you will see that this will mean about ten in Grade VII, five in Grade V, three in Grade IV, two in Grade II, and one in Grade I, a total of 21 pupils out of the 37 who are listed as below Grade VII. Dr. Down's present instructions prevent the admission of any but Grades VII to X. The addition of these pupils will still leave our group of a size to be handled by the two teachers and will round out the complete programme for this year for which the new school was intended.

For information, the Oneida trip totals 13 miles; on the Chippewa side I intend to pick up pupils at three strategic points only, letting them walk some distances because of the bad cross-roads. This will involve a round trip of about 11 miles. This seems to me a very reasonable undertaking for so worthwhile a project.

You will of course note that Mr. Johnston began work on Nov. 1st., so that arrangements should be made for his cheque to be paid when the time comes.

I feel quite hopeful of a good year's work and a valuable start on the new programme. Your suggestion re Miss Inwards sounds splendid, and I hope she can be induced to come.

We should be glad to have your article for publication in WAMPUM. May I add also that your Bulletin will fill a long-felt need, and is a fine piece of work. There may be times, when the deadline looms on the horizon, that you will wonder why you started it, but somehow it will be done. Our thanks for your co-operation.

Sincerely Yours,

Dear Col. Keary,

You will be interested to know of the progress of our Senior School. I should make it brief. Our enrollment began with 30 on Friday, and has been consistently 36 this week. There are two others sick, which will make 38 in Grades 7-10, with a possibility of several others after Christmas.

I am pleased to report that I had to drive the bus only two days; Mr. Burch has been on the job and running on schedule. One thing still bothers me, however, several pupils who return on the second bus have some distance to walk on muddy roads and do not get home till six o'clock, after dark. For this reason it would seem wise, if at all possible, for us to provide some other means for these late pupils to get home earlier by the use of a second bus (or the truck I have mentioned), or by paying the mileage on a car for these few. The present arrangement could hold in the morning, if we could supplement it at night, we might gain 15 minutes by sending the first load out at 3:45.

Dear Col. Murray,

In view of the approaching meeting in Toronto, it would seem worthwhile to submit a further progress report on our Senior School here. Since the actual opening of school, our relationship with Mr. Brown has steadily improved and a number of details have been attended to. He will have reported that the water system has been set up in this building during the past week, and it seems likely that the plumbers will return tomorrow to complete our appointment this week. We are negotiating for the necessary parts for the stove, which will be put in order as soon as these can be had; this is both more convenient and will take care of the quantity of coal already here.

The school bus, with Mr. Burch driving, has been doing splendid service; he is an excellent man. However, it is being overworked, since there are 31 Oneidas for their loads. It seems a pity that Mr. Doucet's original plan to use the lorry was set aside, since it would have taken care of the Oneida crowd plus others who should be attending. In considering another vehicle, we must think of coming years as well as this, and the Oneidas will require either a large vehicle such as sits idle here, or two similar to the one we now use. When Mr. Doucet decided on the lorry, it was with a view to limiting the number of drivers to two. Everyone at this end approves of the remodelling of the lorry, except Mr. Brown, who would prefer something more attractive. Mr. Burch, who knows the vehicles, has expressed the opinion that the lorry could have been made suitable for our needs. For the present, we have been able to send a few pupils home with the new trailer, and I have given up the idea of a second temporary truck. When a second one is secured, it will need to be large enough for future needs.

As to the pupils attending, the enclosed table gives the data. I submit that 96% attendance for a new school is a good start and justifies our making a beginning. While we haven't a high enough record to prove that any doubts of the pupils' interest were groundless. On November 19, I admitted eleven pupils who were not yet in Grade VII, and have been holding classes with them myself in our third room. This was again an arbitrary action on my part, but to have left them out would have been a breach of faith on our part. Seven of these came from Omeida #5, and were not attending school because of lack of room there. Two were from Omeida #2, admitted because of their size and years (one girl 14 yrs., Grade II); the remaining two from Bear Creek, older girls in Grade VI.

Dear Col. Neary:

On Friday, December 6th, I spent a day at Mount Elgin. As you will readily understand this visit was not one of formal inspection though I had some opportunity of observing the work being done.

The staff had had some opportunity of finding where they were, so the courses were discussed and suggestions made.

The enrolment is: Grade 10 - 4; Grade 9 - 7; Grade 8 - 13; Grade 7 - 12; and lower grades - 12. The work of Grades 9 and 10 will be handled capably by Mrs. Jette Hyslop who is highly qualified and has had good experience. Grade 7 and 8 are largely in the charge of Mr. Johnson who is keenly interested in the welfare of Indian children. Mr. Joblin was looking after the retarded children.

You are likely aware that he has taken this latter group into the school to relieve the congestion in one of the Onelas Day Schools. With more adequate transportation facilities, the number of these older retarded pupils could be increased. If Mr. Joblin is to keep close supervision of the Day Schools, a teacher of this group should be provided in the New Year. Mr. Joblin has a lady in mind - Ms. Lockwood. She was successful in Indian Schools at an earlier period. I suggest that her engagement be considered favourably.

While difficulties have prevented plans from following original intentions, the atmosphere and spirit of the school even as it is indicates that we are on the right track. The whole student body was alert, attentive and eager. Progress has been slow but is evident. I suggested to Mrs. Hyslop that Grades 9 and 10 be combined in Science as they are in Health, Geography and History, Art and part of the English taking Grade 10 course. Next year both grades will follow the Grade 9 course.
A similar plan may be adopted in Grades 7 and 8. We follow these plans in the white schools.

These suggestions may annoy you as the order for texts will be changed to some extent but I imagine they understand.

Mr. Joblin and Mr. Johnson are the janitors so far. I presume that this is a detail which will be amended at an early date.

One bus is making two trips daily. With another vehicle the attendance can be increased and the present enrolment served more satisfactorily. You appear to have a very capable operator of the vehicle now in use.

I visited the River Settlement and Pack Settlement schools earlier. The day I planned to visit the Bear Creek School, teacher and pupils had gone on a hike. I hope to call on them before Christmas.

A new spirit of expectancy pervades these schools. Teachers are aroused and pupils are on the alert. It is too early for appraisal of results, but the situation is the most hopeful in my eight years of contact with the Indian children. At Mount Elgin unusually regular attendance has occurred—not perfect but close to it.

Supply of blank Forms I. A. 401 is depleted. My formal report will be submitted at the close of this term. You may be pleased to forward a supply of these forms prior to that time.

As discussed with you this fall, I hope to visit the Grade 8 several times during the winter in the hope that next June we have a record at the Entrance Examination superior to that made in past years. You will understand that only mileage will be charged for the extra visits.

Yours sincerely,

GORDON YOUNG

The attached Monthly Report is submitted for your perusal, and I wish to draw your attention to the underlined; also the grades listed.

Personally I am not concerned as to what grades attend the school, or what your future plans are, but I am thinking perhaps I misunderstood your verbal statement and maybe misinterpreted your letter of October 15, 1946 all of which quite definitely intimated that Grades 7, 8, 9 and 10 would be admitted to the New School this year. It is also recalled that all matters of school administration were to remain the prerogative of the Indian Office. I also recall a telephone conversation when you stated:

"I do not ever intend to correspond direct with the new Principal but he will, when the occasion arises, receive a copy of my letter to you."

You were so specific and so emphatic that I cannot think that you have changed your mind. As I said before I am not concerned with what grades attend the school but I am concerned for my administration and the close co-operation I have always enjoyed with my teachers. After receiving your instructions I advised all teachers that Grades 7, 8, 9 and 10 would be permitted for this year at least to attend the new school and all grades below would continue in their usual classrooms.

In view of what has happened I find it somewhat confusing, if a little embarrassing, when the question asked is:

"Do Mr. Joblin's instructions supersede the Indian Office?"

It has been my pleasure to give and receive very close co-operation and amicable relationships among our
teachers; and the fact that I have been able to hold five teachers throughout the past four difficult years, also the fact that I have had an ex-Indian Day School teacher in my Office for the past four years is, I think, sufficient to warrant my statement.

I do not determine policy, I merely administer it; and am one of those whose policy is, "Come what may! Loyalty, Discipline and Efficiency." If you agree that Mr. Joblin's instructions to the various teachers supersede the Indian Office you will please advise, and I will advise all concerned accordingly.

A little old lady said,

"I'm going to have a party,
And I'm going to invite my friend,
And I'm going to give them a treat,

She went into her room,
And she took out a box,
And she opened it up,
And she found a big Christmas tree.

She put it in the corner,
And she lit the candles,
And she sang a little song,
And she said, "Merry Christmas!"

And they sat around the tree,
And they ate and they drank,
And they had a wonderful time.

And when it was all over,
And they went home to bed,
And they thought about the party,
And they knew it was a good idea.

And every year after that,
They had a Christmas tree party,
And they always had a good time,

It was in the days of "Vineland", a thousand years ago, when Christianity was young in Europe, that Vikings in romantic ships came up out of the far Laurentian Sea into the River of the Iroquois and even unto the Bay of Quinte.

Several ships remained on the Quinte for a season or two at Kay-Say-Ronth-You (meaning Thunder and Lightning) and the White Folk told the Indians about Jesus and a beautiful story of the starry night when Christ was born.

Kay-Say-Ronth-You was an Iroquois place, for the Bay of Quinte was considered a part of the great Iroquoian Sea now called Lake Ontario. Wealth of wild life, safe waters and seclusion made the Iroquois jealous of this beautiful bay of peace and plenty, but there was no war in the land; and inasmuch as rumours of big white men among the stars had spread, Indian fashion, on the wings of God's imagination, strange messengers tramped on the Quinte trail. Curiosity brought Algonquins from afar to see these Vikings and their ships like swans that swam with the wind of the wind - white swans from another world! Great, white swans, and under the spell of Nino Manitou, The Good, bearing, as they did, rose-white people with raiment fair to see!

There came a young Algonquin Chieftain, whose brow was noble, whose heart was clean, and whose look was the look of the rising sun - piercing as a sword! He sat apart, alone, and heard no word of Jesus until, one day, he couldn't help watching and hearing a charming white maiden telling some children a dream-like story in her own tongue, and shyly looking his way, knowing that he was listening. It was about a Manitou child whom the Lord of Heaven had sent to earth. His eyes were filled with wonder, she all the more lovelier, listening with encouragement in his heart. His voice was lost upon her, and her lovely voice was as the sweetest sound of any bluebirds in migration.

Then he knew this maiden; he loved this Viking girl with a fervent love, passion of divine purity and visited her many times by night and by day, he named her Inakona - "I am the light" - meaning, You inspire me to good actions."

He was so captivated, heart and soul, when he transposed for her the children's tale of the birth of Jesus, retelling it himself to the children in poetical signs and symbols of the new man's way. His magnetic power made her afraid, but his wild radiance persuaded her - and she loved him. On the spur of the moment he told her that his name was Inakona - "My voice is her light."

Thus things went. Even the tang of early autumn seemed to get its joyous song from Inashia and its urge from Inakona, inspiration of the morning! Hills of maple all on fire! But nature spoke differently to Inashia's father, leader of the White Folk; he saw warning in the Moon of Falling Leaves.

Soon thereafter, and with promises to come back, perchance the following year - the Vikings descended to the sea.

No one had seen the weeping Inashia, save a wordless Inakona. Baffled by the White Man's way, he gave his anguish quiet, Indian-wise; and the bluebirds murmured autumn, winnowed parting to the water. "Inashia! Inashia!
'I'll return, oh, Inakona!

Only the timeless headdress heard and white eyes solo to their sighing threnody of love.

Long was the lingering of Inakona where he had watched the Vikings vanish. It was with soul-searching reluctance, therefore, that he departed to measure the trail to his own far people, and keep his heart's impulsive promise to carry to them the story of 'The Star of Bethlehem' in the Indian manner of his own interpretation.

In a corner of the Moon of Falling Leaves found pensive cadence in the softly falling feet of this young Chieftain, as he passed and passed the spruce and cedar scented trail.

One day, from a hilltop lying balmy in the sun, the Red Man saw a wisp of blue-gray smoke; he was home! Soon that fire's home aroma blessed him with home's age-old blessings: familiar faces, thoughts and things.
So, in the light of the evening fire, in the centre of his village, in the custom of his people, and after telling of his travels among the Iroquois, Inakon let fall upon Algonquin ears the story of a Moon of Beebon's Mighty Star.

Gwengowea, virgin maid of the Algonquins, dreamed that she had been the bride of the Thunderbird, the winged Spirit of Light from the clouds, and that she would bring forth a child—a Manitou of Peace unto all men. Her people were at war with the Iroquois, and she was afraid.

It was winter—the Moon of Beebon—and spring would be fearsome. Gwengowea must seek safety in a far land of peace, dangerous though the journey would be. She would go on snowshoes, alone and unseen—but how? Her name gave her the answer: Gwengowea, "The Little Owl!" Usually the Tucker Owl is gray, but once she had seen pure white one, an albino. Ah! The pure-white owl! She would dress in white fur—pass unseen in the snow. So, she did.

One afternoon, as the shadows of waning day deepened to morn blue, and the sun was no longer warm to her back, she came upon a great, snow-covered spruce tree—her shelter for the night; and there, on a snowy bough before her, silent and motionless sat an albino squirrel, white as down-down snow, its red eyes reflecting the setting sun with unearthly fire—and gazing strangely into hers!

Her heart was troubled, for the ghost squirrel held a wild-rose in its tangle of thorns, red like fire—not the snow! Something would happen. Something must come—surely, something beautiful—but what? The weirdness of the sight! The thought of thorn! The red of rose twice—very bright in moonlight unclouded burning red! She could not understand. What did they mean? She slept and dreamed of wonder at the lin.

At long thereafter, Gwengowea entered a friendly village, for it was near her time. Their longhouse was already too filled for comfort, but she was permitted to rest in a stable lodge with some captive deer in whose big, soft eyes there twinkled the light of a Magic Star, shining through a large smoke-hole in the roof, and illumining the interior. Thus, in this place, warmed by the bodies of the gentle deer of the forest, the child of peace was born to man-most-wild.

Inakon knew the potency of fitting pause, so, Inakon slept in the fitful night—thinking...
In the shadowy stillness, there in his thoughts for the brevity and beauty of Indian expression, he was himself a thing of strength and beauty, like them in their midst. Indians didn't bother much about details; they pictured only powerful essentials. Consequently, when Inashia had translated for him, he had said at times:

"Starry Light Anang Wabanong - The Manitou Star in the Sky"

Now, in this silence, out of his mind's song for lost peoples, he chanted "Three Mighty Hunters fishing in pool in the Ice," while he softly wrote down:

Three Mighty Hunters, on the ice,
Fished through the night, alone,
And there appeared a strange device,
A star that brightly shone,
Serene and cool
Upon their pool,
One star - and one alone!
One star reflected in the hole,
That gave its darksome deep a soul!

Upon the starlit, tranquil night,
A Spirit voice then rang,
"Your mocasins shall trail the light
Of Manitou Among,
Of Mino Wabanong - the Star!
Anong! Anong! Anong!"
Oh, Anangoka - Starry Night!
Anong! O, Wabanong!

After another long, weary silence, during which the truck circled slowly, the Indians, all of them, knew that he were thing most, some felt as if he had vanished or called them beyond reach.

It was not until late, trailing Anang Wabanong, found the little ones, the young ones, owea strangely expecting them at this hour, according to native custom. Nor did they yield to curiosity or knowledge of their elders.
Chief Thlonoty went to all store corn—oil for flour; Chief Pekolok went to get virgin copper to show for fuel, the most precious thing he had, and which he had got at great price, in trading with remote tribes north of the greatest of fresh water, inland seas; for food and fuel these tokens were, they were matched and given meaning by the present of Chief Our Voice, who brought the sign of light, a fire-bow and its kindling arrow, to loose the sun within the lodge, make free wood's blessed power—all of them symbols of life and peace among men.

"Ah! I am a Wino banong!" sang Inakoné in conclusion.

Thus the story finish, the people were moved with beauty unutterable, and over hills went the story. And from far came the voice so heard in all winter, in and again, came the people. All the hills and hills were telling.

And so the story goes on, and on, and on, but yet there they stand, within the vision of setting suns, beyond the sea, beyond the land, beyond the thunder of the sea, beyond the wind, beyond the white man's lands—but the story goes on, and on, and on.

Only we come here, and wander at convents! Convents! In the land of the Will of the Lord—she was nun! In token of which she did not go further, but would to go into Vineland, a land of the old, old order, where beauty is possible—where there is such as has been known, and be known shall return, or, shall it be said, this is not true—at the new.

And so the story goes on, and on, and on.

The maiden's murmur then will sigh,
'I know! - 'Tis he! 'Tis he!'"
Inkona carried little, golden cross, made of pine twigs bound with golden hair. The child, on his favorite tall ridge, he set the cross on a flat rock stone, then faced the setting sun, to sing his evening psalm.

A storm was rolling up out of the East, blue-black storm all overcast its purple haze—so faintly distant rumble yet, so ominous it seemed to settle it, animating by the unearthly low of deep-throated defiance which it hurled forward into the flushing face of setting sun. Imballed, he stood and watched that woeless yield of hue, and as he calmly wondered at its form some lonely, feeling bird came with him—therefore unfurled—into the covert of each corner that sinister sky, there dwelt, with him at shadowing, tender twin of keen swans! In silence—wild rose—white pine in first glowering fall.

Seven white swans, sunset-rose in hue; slowly, in perfect rhythm, flying like a line of living song, they twirled their measured melody like silence lost in space. It was enough.

Then mutter rolled the sky with sullen night! He turned, before too late, and faced the setting sun to sing his evening psalm:

"O, Power to make me clean!
O Mano-Tanahla!
Inkonon! Menitou!
God, show me how to go!"

Thunder rumbled! The Thunder spoke! The Lightning flashed! But there was no reply!

The child had found him. It had found also, in little pine-twig cross, the soul's outline on the rock where it had lain.

Day, you, Inkonon-Maitou! I heard the song in the soul of Inkonon. Inkonon! God and His Cross, in the rock eternal, burned forevermore.

MUNCEY - ONTARIO

March 26, 1947.

COL. B.F. NEARY,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
(Ottawa), Ontario.

Dear Col. Neary,

During the past months I have tried to spare you the annoyance of complaints but it has become imperative now that you be furnished with some facts which may assist you in reaching a fair conclusion concerning the reports you have had of us. There are issues involved which are too serious to be ignored any longer if the ultimate success of the work is to be made possible.

The causes of misunderstanding between us and the Agent fall into two main classes. First, those due to our widely divergent views as to my position as Supervisor of Education. In this matter I am of the opinion that the fault must lie with Ottawa rather than with either of us, since Mr. Doucet evidently shared Mr. Down's opinion.

Second, those matters in which he did have instructions but which he has failed to put into effect, and which bear on the question of co-operation.

It has been made quite clear at this end that my position is nothing more than Principal of Mt. Elgin Day School. In support of this statement I offer the following facts:

I learned at our meeting in January that Dr. Moore visited our reserve last fall and called on two schools, yet no mention of the fact was made to me.

When it was necessary last fall to advertise for a teacher to replace Mr. George on Onda #3, it was done, the teacher engaged, and I received no intimation of it, though I should have been satisfied if I had been notified.

In connection with Mr. Doucet's inspection visit in January, the other teachers received letters some two weeks in advance, while I had no word till a few days before, in the form of a late postscript. While Mr. Doucet was inspecting the work I believe for four days, Monday to Thursday, I neither knew who was here, nor saw him until 10:15 A.M. on Thursday, and practically no opportunity to discuss our needs or present our side of the picture.
In connection with his visit, I had arranged for the teachers to meet at one of the schools at 4 p.m. Thursday, so that they might discuss the health posters, and perhaps give the visitor a chance to meet with us. Without consulting me, or notifying me of the change, the meeting was changed to 2 p.m., and to the Agent's office. I learned of it only when the two men called at the school that day. I cannot believe that a man in Mr. Doucet's position would make so many errors if he had thought of me as being in charge of education. I did not raise the issue, but it is one which must be clarified.

At that teachers' meeting, I suggested that we might have all the pupils assemble here and display their posters on February 7th, from 3 to 4 p.m. Mr. Doucet approved; I was into the office at least twice concerning it, and invited Mr. Down to attend, and to act as judge for the posters. He did his work as a judge well and appreciated it. The pupils had a fine time visiting us; the senior pupils served lunch and presented a little programme; they presented extra prizes for the best posters. It was such an occasion as I am sure you would heartily approve. Yet as a result of it, the teachers received the most perplexing letters from the office in which Mr. Down implied that no one had any right to arrange such a gathering or to let the teachers attend, but himself. Because of this attitude, the teachers have been kept in a state of uncertainty, and since this letter was sent, I have felt it necessary to absent myself from the other schools lest I "put the teachers on the spot". Until the teachers are clearly informed as to my responsibility, how can I carry out any programme in connection with these schools?

I was engaged by Mr. Hoey as Supervisor of Education as outlined in Mr. Young's report, and it was on this understanding the Church consented to the closing of the Residential School. I felt that you had accepted this too, but somehow the matter has not yet filtered down to those further down the list. My position is intolerable, and if allowed to continue would be a serious breach of faith with the Church and the people. If this position and the work of education is to be made dependent upon the whim of the Agent, it is doomed to failure. Let not my silence heretofore be taken for acquiescence. This matter is fundamental to the whole plan, and the future of the work as well as the future position of the person in charge is at stake. There can be no compromise. Speaking for myself, I could not continue to work for a Department in whom I had lost confidence. I have steadfastly believed that Mr. Hoey and later yourself intended to make of this project one of the best efforts yet made on behalf of the Indians. If I were forced to believe that Mr. Down's treatment of us this year were a true representation of the Department's will you would very soon have my resignation. Since I look upon you as my superior officer, I have not written of these matters to Mr. Hoey, but would hope that you would consider them of sufficient importance to discuss with him. However, I feel responsible also to Dr. Dorey, who will receive a copy of this letter.
In the second category, there are matters for which it is impossible to blame anyone but Mr. Down. We are not inclined to criticize him for our having no road and no telephone, since this is a part of the price of a new road. Since the new year the road has been passable for less than two weeks early in March, and will probably be closed for at least two weeks yet. The telephone is not yet replaced; that unpaid balance which the two offices could not straighten out, I have paid so that nothing could prevent our getting service again.

On July 3rd last, Mr. Down was instructed by Mr. Arneil in my hearing, to have the furnace put in order with the stoker, and to set up radiators in our apartment, to heat from the same system as the classrooms. These instructions were repeated at different times when some of you men were here. Not neither has yet been done, and I have carried coal up 25 steps for two stoves, and stoked an old furnace with stoker coal, making trips every hour and half from 6:30 a.m. till 11 p.m. I was allowed to do this for over three months without Mr. Down securing a caretaker. After Mr. Down's visit, he told me to find someone to do the work and tender an offer. This was done and immediately approved by you, so that they took over on Feb. 10th or the three months I had done all the work of the school, including daily sweeping and dusting. When it was evident that nothing was being done with the furnace, we began to write about it and learned that there were no parts available and patterns would have to be made for ourselves. This Mr. Johnston did, working late for weeks and completing them in time for the official visit in January. We offered them to Mr. Down, who did not take them. Instead he thought he could secure the parts. Nothing more has been heard of the matter, the parts are still lying here. The work involved in keeping heat up with stoker coal in this way has been beyond a joke; it is still necessary for me to attend to it night and morning, since the caretakers cannot stay around all the time. Our apartment is far from warm in cold weather even with two stoves. All this because of two relatively small tasks which could have been done last summer.

After some correspondence during the winter regarding cups for the pupils, I suggested that a pair of fountains or "bubblers" over the basins in the two classrooms would be most sanitary and inexpensive. Mr. Monet approved this in January; our pupils are still drinking out of two granite cups, which has had some share in causing the spread of colds and leading to several absenteeism this month. They are available, yet two months have passed without results. To date we have 74 rolls of toilet tissue and 24 packages of towels, which is at best about an 8 weeks' supply. I leave you to decide whether such matters are due to incompetence or wilful neglect.

Mr. Down complains of my not going into the office. I have been in a good many times; sometimes well received, but frequently to receive a lecture which becomes tiresome. Two weeks ago, at his suggestion, and after his assurance of "lady courtesy," I wrote saying I would call on a certain afternoon at 6 o'clock, and leaving time for him to let me know if this were undesirable. I went and waited, but he neither appeared or left any explanation.
It should not be surprising that I have been in no hurry to make another attempt. I intend to do much of my work with the office by correspondence; it is less wasteful of time and much more pleasant. On the other hand he has, so far as I know, forwarded our requisitions promptly, and attended to our fuel supply.

Another matter which will cause confusion sooner or later, is his persistent attempts to change the name of the school to "Caradoc Continuation School." It was my hope to keep the link with the past hundred years by simply changing the name to Mt. Elgin Indian Day School. This has apparently been accepted by your office in my correspondence, in our supplies and in the making out of our cheques. Yet from this office, the former name is used. It is scarcely necessary for me to point out that our school is not a Continuation school at all, but is in a class by itself, and is in my opinion something better than any other existing type of school system, for this situation. There is no point in my arguing this matter with Mr. Down, but if misunderstanding is to be avoided between the many offices concerned, this should be cleared up, one way or the other. When it has been settled, then it might be possible for us to have some new letterhead paper and envelopes.

There could be more, but your patience may be exhausted. As concerns next year's work here, it seems to me that I should have an opportunity of seeing you soon after the Easter holiday and at a time when we would not be too rushed. If you were unable to come to Muncey, then I ought to go to Ottawa. There should be a clear ruling as to what students are to be admitted another year, and something needs to be done to secure another teacher, if the need of one is admitted, so that an attempt might be made to find the one we need before June, when most of them have to submit their resignations where they are now employed.

If we are able to get out, I hope to attend some of the sessions of the O.E.A. in Toronto during the holiday week. Believe me, I should welcome an opportunity to discuss these controversial issues with you, and my correspondence is open to your inspection at any time.

I reiterate my faith in the value of the system of education proposed for our Reserves, and my confidence that eventually it will become a reality.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

My dear Col. Neary,

I am writing first, that I returned to my work with a new feeling of confidence and a greater optimism for the success of our venture. A visit to Ottawa left me with no doubt of the government's support and their understanding of the situation here.

My immediate concern is to make sure of the best available teachers for next year, and not to leave it too late. Hence this letter.

1. Our teacher at No. 2 Oneida is resigning in June. We have received a letter from Miss Jackson, who is in Ottawa and would like to teach here. I visited her when I was in the city and would like to recommend her for No. 2, when you receive Mrs. Heldsworth's resignation. She has agreed to call on you so that you can examine her qualifications and experience yourself. She has had experience which seems to require her for what we need; she will also take part in the life of the community. Moreover, she expressed her willingness to attend the Course in Toronto this summer. If she can be secured for this school, I think it should take care of our key schools on the reserves for next year.

2. Mrs. Neslips, our High School teacher, is willing to remain, in view of the probable increase in salary suggested by the schedule. In this regard I am enclosing a list of her study courses, which, in addition to her 20 years' experience, will, I hope, entitle her to the maximum salary for Grade IV teachers. She is not only willing but eager to carry our three Grade XI pupils on next year. Some early indication of your interpretation of her salary for next year would be greatly appreciated I am sure.
Mr. Johnston, as I suggested, is willing to serve on half-time, principally for shop work, but helping in mathematics. I feel inclined to try this arrangement and would ask you to engage him on half-time for the full school year. However, I should like to make a reservation that, in the event that our needs should be greater than I anticipate, he could be engaged full-time for the winter months from Nov. 1st to May 1st. This would be satisfactory with him and might prove to be necessary.

For our second full-time teacher, I have an excellent prospect in Mrs. Marjorie Docker, at present principal of the Bridges Continuation School, formerly a teacher on our Reserve, and one of the most successful teachers we know. She is keenly interested in the Indian people and in our experiment here. She has a very fine personality and a very successful way of working with young people. She has the care of three boys of her own, but often gives help in the home. She is only able to interpret her leaving her present position, however, because Bridges is likely in the next few years to be closed to utilize in a larger school area.

Mrs. Docker is receiving $1900. Would it be possible for you to evaluate her experience and training by the enclosed sheet, and give me an early reply as to what we could offer her? If I interpret the schedule correctly, it seems to me that she would qualify for the maximum for Grade III teachers, namely $1980. If I could offer her this in addition to the apartment and fuel, I could persuade her to come to Lumsden. She would be able to take care of Grades 7 and 8 and assist in high school work as well. She can travel very little, so I am sure her science work and in fact all work which we might require. Her work in cooking and sewing would be a valuable asset, but her greatest contribution would be in her own personality and influence.

Our inspector Mr. Young would be very kindly of her I know, as I have heard his opinion before. It would indeed be a day of a new day in Indian Education if we could engage such a person, competing with salary schedules of other schools.

The need for haste in this matter is due to the fact that if she cannot be secured, I need time left to go after Mr. Cowan, or whom I spoke, prior to the end of the month, or some other person.

Mr. Lineau would suggest that I attend the course in Toronto, in auxiliary classes, since much of this responsibility could be left with me next year. Am I to understand that I could have permission to do this, in view of the fact that I am employed on a twelve-month basis? It would seem to be a more immediately useful course than for me to take the normal course. I had intended enrolling at Columbia, but I've decided that for this year I should take advantage of the course you are sponsoring in Toronto.

This had better suffice for now, writing you soon to see how an earlier letter.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. McCubbin:

I have referred Mrs. Docker's letter to the Indian Affairs branch. Mrs. Docker's salary for the 1947-48 school term has been set at $1,740.00. She will also receive free house, fuel and light.

Work observed: French IX, Latin IX, French IX, French IX, Algebra IX.

The subject of the French IX lesson was a translation of a portion of l'Abbe Sandel. The procedure consisted of (1) assigned written questions on the grammar of the text for homework. This assignment was comprehensive; (2) production of a prepared translation. Many pupils contributed; (3) careful check on grammatical forms and English expression. An effective lesson—good drill a strong feature.

Latin IX. Subject, exercises on the subjunctive. Procedure: (1) Latin to English—careful analysis—the teacher makes little; (2) English to Latin—pupils at the board, teacher dictating; (3) assignment of additional oral drill exercises. This was a good drill lesson. The teacher shows confidence that she has from thorough knowledge and a masterful technique. She moves from one pupil to another in a rapid, thorough manner.

French IX. Procedure: (1) conversation consisting of instructions in French as to the preparation of work; (b) checking of exercises, comment in French; (c) conversation by means of pupil question and answer; (2) vocabulary building; (3) assignment—little stories of things in the room. I commend Miss Fisher's method and venture to suggest patient continuance of the direct method.

French IX. Subject—comparisons, adjective and adverb. Procedure: (1) check of students' work, drill on essential points, selected students working at the blackboard; (2) good drill; (3) assignment adequate, and not too heavy. A good lesson.

Algebra IX. Subject, factoring the difference of squares. The lesson consisted mainly of checking problems done as assignment. Satisfactory.

Miss Fisher shows enjoyment of her work, is energetic, eager, kindly, keen and patient.

Dear Col. Neary:

I have visited all schools on the Manosey Reserve once this Fall, and my reports are being forwarded on the regular forms through my superintendent's office to your Branch.

You may be interested in the comments given below. Some of these matters should have early attention; others are just for your early information.

I. Mount Misin School

(a) It is a pleasure to see that the new building is now enclosed and to note that we may expect to use it next year.

(b) I find that Mr. Joblin has to tend to the furnace; the boys who do this in the daytime are on the bus and so he is compelled to be night-fire-man. You have placed a stoker in the building, but, for some unaccountable reason, it has never been put into service. If it were installed, Mr. Joblin would be relieved of this needless addition to his work.

(c) In my reports I commend Mr. Joblin for the splendid work he is doing among the pupils below Grade 7. He has re-established one in Grade 7 and has four others well on the way. His training this summer is bearing good fruit.

(d) This work ties him to the school and prevents any service to the day schools. Mr. Johnston will be available for full time duty from now until the Skyways Theatre reopens next Spring. If he were engaged to work under Mr. Joblin's direction for three months following Christmas,
Joblin could:

(1) Complete compilation of cumulative records of pupils on the reserves and at this school;

(2) Supervise the educational programme of the day schools;

(3) Conduct tests in the schools. May I recommend that this be done?

(e) Mrs. Docker is putting new life into the work of Grades 7 and 8 and you will be pleased with the performance of pupils from these grades.

(f) Miss Hartledge is scholarly and well trained. No doubt she is a splendid teacher. With a group of students academically inclined she would be unusually good. For pupils not so interested but more inclined to physical and practical affairs, she is not so helpful. The slower pupils have just quit school. The brighter pupils make good progress. She hardly fits into the programme of a school which must emphasize vocational as well as academic aspects of the curriculum.

(g) Mr. Johnston is almost the exact opposite. He is weak in academic work, but, does well in the Shop and on the Play Ground.

(h) You personally assure our heartiest commendations for your interest in the school. You have spared no effort in giving the teachers good references, good equipment and giving the pupils most satisfactory supplies.

(i) The old bus is still running. We hope that the new one soon relieves it.

II THE DAY SCHOOLS

(a) Mrs. Bateman continues her excellent service. Miss Annett shows promise and is doing a fairly good job. Mr. Reid, as I have reported, surprised me at first. He did better than I expected. He disappoints me now by showing no further improvement.

(b) Mrs. Bateman reports that she needs:

(1) More workbooks for Grade 3 Readers.
(2) A Health Book for Grades 5 and 6.

It appears that she received the Health Book for Grades 1 to 4 and 7 and 8.

(c) At Bear Creek School the enrolment has increased beyond the seating accommodations, so limited seats and desks are in use. These are not suitable.

Such an increase, also, means a shortage of books, and, pupils' supplies.

These matters should have immediate attention, and, Miss Annett was advised to repeat her requests to Mr. Down until she received them.

The fences at this school should be repaired.
My visit to River Settlement followed several days after Halloween. It appears that the evil spirits went on a rampage that night. The damage had not been repaired. The register of the school was gone. No doubt Mr. Down and Mr. Reid are proceeding to remedy this situation. In fact I thought that they had had time to have that completed before I arrived.

A copy of this letter will be included with the reports on each teacher.

Yours sincerely,

Gordon Young

Dear Col. Neary,

May I offer somewhat belated congratulations on your new position. It should prove of great value to our work in education to have you giving your full time to it.

For the present, I shall limit my letter to one matter. Would it be possible for us to engage Mr. Johnston for full time after Christmas, for three months, or even for two months? My thought is that he could take my room in the mornings and set me free to visit the other schools, and to do some testing and setting up of records for all our pupils. In consultation with Miss Delaporte last summer, we agreed on some tests which, over a period of time, would provide a good deal of information concerning the pupils. For example, the Otis Quick Scoring test for the smaller grades. There are also some children who should be given the individual intelligence tests. I bought quite a number of tests myself with this kind of thing in mind, but have no time to use them.

Furthermore, it would give me an opportunity of finding whether such an arrangement would work out satisfactorily for next year. Namely, using Mr. Johnston in the junior room for the mornings, and for shop work in the afternoons. I should like to look forward to having half of each day free for the work of the other schools and for interview work with the seniors, and for testing and keeping of records. If this is a possibility for another year, a trial for a few months might be worthwhile. At present, I am in my classroom from 8.00 until 5.30, when the last bus leaves, and take only 15 minutes for lunch. With the evenings taken for community activities, there is little time for some of these other types of work. It will be a big relief to Mrs. Docker and myself, if and when a second bus is in use, and will let the pupils get home in better time. I suppose it is not possible, but if it were, I should like to recommend a bonus of some kind for Mrs. Docker, who gives an extra hour each night after four o'clock, to the late group. No such thing is in her mind; she is not one to measure the work she does.

I should like to wish you and yours the very best of the Christmas season, and a satisfying New Year.

Sincerely Yours,

Dear Col. Neary,

In reply to your letter regarding Mr. Johnston, I would say that, following Col. Randall's suggestion, we started using him full time early in the month. Our rink has been a lot of work but is the source of a great deal of healthful exercise and recreation for both pupils and the whole community. Our school is gradually coming to its proper position as a community centre and an institution dedicated to the service of the people generally.

The office will have written you I believe, concerning a former pupil of the residential school, one Walter Raymond Minham, who has been working his way through the Basil Technical School in London, with some assistance from your department. SCHOOL NEWS

A WEEKLY NEWS SHEET FOR THE CHIPPEWA, MUNGEY AND ONEIDA RESERVES.

May 29

For many of the pupils, the important events of this week have been several ball games. The weather at last permitted us to get started. On Tuesday Oneida #1 came to Oneida #3 and defeated them by 14-7 in a good game of ball. On Wednesday River Settlement came to Mt. Elgin and defeated the junior room by about 15-4. On Thursday Rock Settlement played a return game against River Settlement, but were unable to make much headway against the cup-holders; however, the pupils take their defeats in a fine spirit, and will some day make good ball players. The girls' team from Delaware Continuation School came back for a return game here on Thursday at 3:45 and were once more defeated by a good margin. Both teams worked hard and turned in some good ball along with some errors. We hope to get back to Delaware on Tuesday next.

Weather permitting, Oneida #1 plays at Oneida #3 at noon on Tuesday.

Many of our pupils took part in the Field Day held at the Oneida New Hall last Monday. Such events are fine opportunities for our people to get together for a good time. The Society sponsoring the day were most generous in their treatment of their guests, serving free ice cream, oranges and lunches. Ball games between the schools proved interesting, while the young people organized several games of their own. Our students here are planning a Field Day for the end of the term, the date will be made known as soon as possible.

Our schools are to be honoured by a visit on Monday from two representatives from the Royal Commission on Education for the Province of Ontario. They will be accompanied by our two inspectors, Mr. Young and Mr. Smith. Their visit may prove of real importance in the years to come, and we are anxious that they receive a good impression of us. All we ask is that our pupils try to be at school and not stay away because of their visits. The time of year has come when the older pupils find it difficult to remain in school, tempted as they are by the appeal of the out-of-doors and by the attraction of big wages. Yet how wasteful it is to invest eight or nine months in attending school only to drop out without completing the year! Something like letting an insurance policy lapse after paying several years' premiums. The responsibility of self-discipline is proving to be pretty difficult for a few, but if they will persevere, they will have won a moral victory which will build character and be of great value for the rest of their lives. There is very little compulsion being used, but the experience of years has convinced adults that children need to attend school until at least 16 years of age. Of course, many people think parents and other adults don't know what they are talking about, but they do, at least some of the time. Young people sometimes think it shows their independence to disregard the judgements of their elders, when in reality it usually reveals a lack of judgment in themselves. Go to school while you may, the day will come when you will wish you had done so, and you will be trying to tell your children to do what you had not the will-power to do when you were young.
Muncey, Ontario,

Dear Col. Neary,

Inspector Young has been here on his visit and we have discussed our needs for next year, particularly as to staff. No doubt you will hear from him directly, but I wanted to remind you of them and to send along the enclosed application.

I earnestly hope you have been able to provide for a change in our High School teacher, and that you will be able soon to let me know of it so that I may take some steps to secure another. Mrs. Smith, unable to wait longer, has accepted another position. I know of a teacher still available, but can do nothing until Mrs. Hartledge has been provided for, or at least knows about the change. If it proves to be impossible to secure a H.S. teacher, Mr. Young agrees that we should have Mrs. Docker take this work, and find a really good teacher for Grades VII and VIII. Indeed, we went so far as propose to Mrs. Bateman, at Back Settlement that she take this room, and not attempt to get a H.S. Teacher. She prefers to remain where she is, largely because of her family and transportation.

As to River Settlement, which I proposed to bring to our new school, I trust there is no reason to prevent this. You made mention of the possibility of sending us a teacher from the Brantford Reserve. I approve the principle of hiring an Indian youth, and am sending an application from the only one from our reserve to have qualified for this work. Mrs. Schuyler is the daughter of one of our finest families, and her teaching has not been seriously criticised. While at Kettle Point she may have given some cause for concern in the manner of private life, but I feel that she should be given a chance here, in the school under my immediate direction. If we are to encourage any students to continue their training, it seems to me we must be willing to use those who have done so. To give Mrs. Schuyler the opportunity here would give proof of our intentions for others. I would therefore request that you give serious consideration to appointing her to teach my Division III (pupils from River Settlement plus retarded pupils; the latter to receive extra help from me). If possible, I should like to provide for her use of the teachers' residence on the Oneida reserve, which has been vacant for some years. She has four children, and could be of much-needed help to her parents, by having her mother care for them during the day. Her husband is a day labourer and is home only on week-ends. An early confirmation of this plan for River Settlement and the appointment of Mrs. Schuyler would be greatly appreciated.
We hope that somehow we can give Myrtle Minham her Grade XII next year, which will be possible only in view of the small number of pupils in the High School grades. If there is any opportunity, it would be desirable for the three of us, yourself, Mr. Young and myself, to discuss at some length the courses to be offered in future years, how far we can attempt to carry them in academic courses, and what practical courses to provide. There will not be many for some years who will want an academic course, and as you suggested, these might be sent to town. For next year, however, we are hoping to provide for Myrtle, possibly two in XI, four or five in X, and four or five in IX. These will again be 35 or more in 7 and 8. If River Settlement is brought in there will be about 30-35 in Division III. I could easily use better than half my time as a helper-teacher for these various groups, and the remainder in the other schools. I am hoping that this program will be possible this coming year.

We are to have a visit from two members of the Royal Commission on Education in Ontario, next Monday, accompanied by our two inspectors. One of them is the secretary, Dr. Jackson, with whom I did my work in Toronto.

It has been a good year in many ways, though our attendance has been badly hit by sickness, with mumps, measles and whooping cough taking their toll. For another year too, there needs to be a clearer understanding about what can be done about absenteeism. Several have been allowed to absent themselves with the result that others have come to think that we can do nothing about it.

Dear Mr. Joblin:

A short time ago I was invited to attend a workshop discussion and demonstration of puppetry at the National Museum. Members of the May Court Club of London were brought to Ottawa by the Museum to give the demonstration in question. I was amazed by what can be accomplished with ordinary materials, and impressed by the fact that marionettes and puppets are being so successfully used in schools and sanatoria.

It was brought out that working with puppets and marionettes not only gives children self-confidence, but encourages them to use their hands constructively, improves their use of the English language, and teaches them to put their ideas together in an interesting fashion when working out little plays.

Mrs. L.W. Sipherd, whose address is 111 Elworthy Avenue, London (telephone Metcalf 9993M) seems to be the moving spirit in the May Court Club Marionette Group. Two other members of the group who are particularly interested are Mrs. Wilson, and Mrs. Sim. Mrs. Sim, I believe, is instructing out at the Sanatorium.

Shepherd, the Principal of the Mount Elgin Industrial Institute, has requested the Department to obtain an appropriation of at least $4,500 to meet the cost of new material, heating apparatus and labour which cannot be done in the present school building in connection with an addition which will complete and perfect the buildings of the institute.

"This school is conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Church. It receives an annual grant of $60 for 100 pupils, and is one of the oldest and most efficient schools in the Province of Ontario. The present main building was completed three years ago. It costs over $22,000, and is a substantial structure, fitted with all modern improvements and considered one of the best buildings for the purpose in the country. Towards the cost of this building the Indian bands interested contributed $19,000, and the House at its last Session granted $2500 to provide for the apparatus and stove.

"The undersigned does not think it would be proper to levy upon the capital of the Indian bands any further contribution towards this school, at present. It is no longer necessary, and in the interest of the institution to tear down the old buildings."
buildings and erect more modern structures, which will provide a recreation hall and hospital and additional school room.

The Principal has submitted plans for these additions, which appear to have been carefully drawn, and which will undoubtedly do, with certain slight alterations. The undersigned hopes to submit the application to Mr. Sheppard for the Superintendent General's consideration, in order that if he so desires an amount may be inserted in the estimates to cover the necessary outlay."

"The accompanying tracing of the plan of the Mount Elgin school property shows the position of all the buildings and the one it is suggested should be altered to meet the requirements outlined in the Rev. Mr. Shepherd's letter of the 27th ultimo which discusses changing the proposed purposes.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE SECRETARY.

With reference to your memorandum of the 7th instant, in regard to the matter of the proposed grant to the Mount Elgin Industrial School, I beg to state that the report to which you refer, of the 2nd February last, was prepared by the direction of the then Deputy Minister, and was intended for his signature. It does not embody my views on the subject, but was intended to set forth the policy of the Department towards further grants to this school. I signed it through the accident of his absence.

My fixed principle in the matter of contributions to schools, so far as the Indians in Ontario and Quebec are concerned, is that the Bands whose children are in attendance should provide—largely if not wholly—the funds to meet the expenditure, where they are available.

As to the proportion in which the Bands should contribute to the Mount Elgin School in the present case, I am unable to speak definitely without a report from the Schoolmaster shewing the Bands to which the Indians in attendance belong; but if the grant is to be made on the same basis as the last, the capital at the credit of the Bands would justify the contribution of the necessary funds in a lump sum at once.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 1st instant, with which you enclosed an estimate of the cost of placing the hot water system of heating into the old building at the Mount Elgin Industrial School, I am directed to inform you that, owing to the very large expenditure required in regard to Indian Schools, the Board has not been authorized to make any expenditure at this institution.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. A. Sutherland, P.T.,

Methodist Mission Home,
Toronto.
Sir,- I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, No 155,001/5, stating that on account of the very large expenditure on the Indian schools, the Department does not feel warranted in authorising a change of the heating system in the old building at Mount Elgin school.

I regret very much the decision, being persuaded that the hot water system would be the most efficient, and in the end the most economical; but we must make the best of the other system that circumstances will allow.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

A. G. Macdonald
General Secretary.

Sir:-

The work of remodelling the old buildings here has been carried forward as far as the season and the money will admit.

The grant was $1,500, used to be spent on material and such work as the Institution staff could not do. The work so far as carried forward is well worth $1,500, but to do that we have exceeded the grant by $1,200. That is, we have unpaid invoices for material amounting to that figure.

Our apology for exceeding the grant was the urgency of the case, "necessity known no law."

To save two of our old houses the logical way also other it was absolutely necessary to clear the rock foundations well; i.e., to fit them for cattle stable with cement floors, etc., which cost for material, but in a colonial job will stand test for a generation.

The old Institution has been remodelled out with its splendid slate roof, a much sharper roof than the old one was, and its walls painted and "locked off," the appearance is that of a new and beautiful building. Its hospital wards, school-rooms and home of the cook and family and the watchman and his family are all adapted for the purpose.

Work yet to be done on this building, heating, plumbing and furniture for one school room and for the hospital. At a close calculation this will cost $1,500.

We have one other barn 110 by 40 ft., built over twenty years on a wood foundation, which must be put on the same kind of foundation as the other barns to save it and bring it into harmony with the other buildings in the block. It is one side of the block. At a close estimate it will cost $400. for the material.

Again we are very anxious to complete the attic of the new building which was erected in '95. The contract did not include the attic and it is a great disadvantage to have it unfinished as our water tanks are there and the pipes leading to different parts of the building. We have had much anxiety every winter in the extreme weather conditions to keep the chimney of this attic will give us a closet room for the girls in one end and a dormitory in the other for twenty more boys. It will take 1,100 yds. of plastering and all the joist, studding, base boards, window and door cases and at a close estimate will cost for material and work we cannot do at least $600.

If the Department can see its way clear to grant us the sum of $3,000 we can see our way to help make the most complete Institution of its kind in the North American area. It to the Department and the chapel.

The proposed improvements will place the old institution in harmony with the new and will cost approximately $2,000.

The completion of this work will also accommodate to the growing needs of the school.

Department of Indian Affairs
OTTAWA, 3rd January, 1902

The Secretary:

An application made by the Principal of the Mt. Elgin Industrial school for a grant of $500 to be expended in the purchase of material for making certain improvements in connection with that institution.

In this connection I beg to refer you to official reply to Mr. Shepherd sent him on the subject and turned out herewith.

The whole cost of these buildings has apparently been provided for by the Indians and a small Parliamentary vote. Any amount contributed by the Methodist Missionary Society is not known to the Department.

This school has been under the care of the Methodist Church since '81 and has cost a large amount of money, the buildings being worth over $40,000, and I do not think it would be right to call upon the Indians to make any further contributions.

You will see by Mr. Shepherd's original application that he asks for $900 to improve the water supply; $400 for pipes to convey the drinking water and $500 for fire protection. The management is responsible for providing pure water and if there is any trouble in this respect it is owing to the defective manner in which the pipes were laid and they should remedy it.
The school is well supplied with tanks and fire appliances and an insurance of $36,000 is carried on the buildings.

As to the enlargement of the barns I may say that Mr. Shepherd has now ample stable and barn accommodation for the ordinary needs of the school, but as he is extensively engaged in cattle trade, feeding stock for the market, I suppose he may need more space for that purpose. This business is carried on for the benefit of the school and is hardly necessary for the training of Indian pupils to the extent followed by him, as the extra amount of work entailed ceases to be instructive and becomes mere drudgery.

He asks for $1000 to reconstruct the old shops as he wishes to have all the buildings in keeping.

Over $350.00 is asked for to meet a deficit; this is no concern of the Department's and will have to be made good by the Methodist Missionary Society.

You will see that in Mr. Shepherd's second application on file he hopes that the Department will see its way clear to recommend the grant "without the necessity of additional pressure on the head of the Department". A statement like this hardly comes with a good grace from the Principal of one of our Industrial schools.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General,

The original building of Mount Elgin Industrial Institution was completed in 1863, at a cost of $6,500.00; the building was enlarged in 1866 at a cost of $3,000.00 and in 1867 an additional expenditure of $640.00 was made for repairs and improvements, so that the original cost may be computed at $9,840.00. The site for the Institution (4 acres) was dedicated by the Chiefsmen of the Thuron for the purpose on the 13th February, 1849, and also an additional 200 acres for use in connection with the Institution.

The land is not officially the property of the Indians who contributed to their construction, however, I think, 300 acres of the land but the title to the 4 acres on which the first buildings were erected, is in doubt.

In addition to the 300 acres above referred to the authorities of the Institution occupy by lease or otherwise about 300 acres (the rent for which is, I presume, paid for the profits which accrue from the land). The negotiations are now being carried out.

The funds for the construction of the building came from contributions from the Great Plains of Canada and bonds:

- Chippewas of Lake St. Clair and Bearte.
- Laken Baron and Simon
- Mohawkmen of No Thuron
- Mississaugas of the Credit
- of Rice A Land Laken
- of Alnwick
- of Shingwauk & Nawash.

For the contributions were first made, the Methodist Missionary Society promised to supply necessary furniture, books and

To the Honorable Clifford Sifton,
Minister of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

The subject of communication referred to is
the necessities and conditions of this Institute over which
I have been placed. I have understood that it was the in-
tention of your Department to increase the per capita grant
and to place this Institution on a more equitable basis as
compared to others in the west and thereby enable its man-
agement to attain a standard of efficiency now absolutely
beyond its reach. The late Principal felt as I feel that
with the present grant it is impossible to effectively
carry on the work even supplemented as it may be by occa-
sional grants for repairs and equipment. When I entered
upon my duties July last last I found repairs under way,
contracts let and material purchased. I have done all
possible to secure the best results from the outlay made,
but after boarding the workmen and counting only cost of
material and of wages paid, I find the cost of completing
the work has far exceeded the amount of the grant. This,
notwithstanding the fact also that our regular staff car-
penter and two of the apprenticed pupils were constantly
employed upon said works. I find no shadow of fault with
my predecessor. A natural sanguine temperament led to an
over estimation of what might be done with said grant, and
the largely increased cost of all kinds of material as also
labor could not have been foreseen by him. The work done
is of a permanent character and will add much to the conven-
ience and equipment of the Institution. Still there re-

remains much needing serious attention, which can only be accomplished by the kindly and sympathetic co-operation of your Department.

I have lived a most anxious life during the past six months, in that I have been the responsible head of an Institution representing not only a large invested capital representing the interests of your Department as also of our Missionary Society, but also the more valuable lives of its more than one hundred inmates. Such accidents as the burning of the Mohawk Institute last year and such sad fatalities as that of the recent fire in Chicago cause uneasiness to the responsible head of such an Institution as this, when the utter inefficiency or entire absence of protection against fire is as marked as it is in this Institution. I have worked hard to conceive a plan suitable to our isolated condition and feel confident that with the assistance such as I am assured you will freely grant that such plan can be put into operation with entire satisfaction and without serious cost. The assistance I ask is not a special grant (though I might be justified in making that request) but it is that of an increase in the per capita grant, which would enable me to make these improvements little by little through the work of our regular staff and at a much less cost than is the case when the work is of a special character and done by contract. The present per capita is so small that with the late Principal I am in entire agreement when he stated that "the mere struggle for existence is so keen and constant as to paralyze the management in its efforts towards efficient work in the interests for which the Institution was founded."

As you know the land grant contains but 225 acres granted at a time when the pupils in attendance were limited to forty, increased to sixty, then to eighty and later still to one hundred, but in all this there has been no increase...
of the lands from which we are to draw our supplies through cultivation. To meet this want the late management as also the present has been compelled to resort to leasing of such areas of land as our needs have demanded. This has been and is a serious drain upon our current income. There are adjacent lands that could be purchased from their holders at a nominal price, the possession of which is very important, not only for the above mentioned reasons, but also because they contain the sources of our water supply in large measure and it is important that we should control them. I do not think that I am asking more than sheer necessity forces me to and the important work committed to my trust demands, when I press upon you the necessity of an increase in the per capita grant and also the importance of an increased area for cultivation.

Ottawa, January 30th, 1904.

Memorandum,

Mr. Sifton,

Having reference to the personal letter from Reverend Mr. George, Principal of the Mount Elgin Industrial Institute, in which he deals with the difficulties confronting him in the successful management thereof and alluding particularly to the scarcity of funds and the insufficiency of the land, I beg leave to report that the Mount Elgin Industrial School cost in 1851, $1,000.00, later on $3,660.00 for an addition thereof and in 1857 an additional expenditure of $640.00 was made for repairs and improvements, making the original cost $9,500.00.

The funds for the construction of the building were contributed by the following bands:

_The Chippewas_

Indian Affairs. (FC 1C, Volume 6205, file 468-5, part 1)
The Chippewas of Lake St. Clair and Ecarte,
The Chippewas of Lakes Huron and Simcoe,
The Moravians of the Thames,
The Mississaugas of the Credit,
* * * * Rice and Mud Lakes,
* * * * Ainvick,
* * * * Saugeron and Kawash.

In 1896 a new main building was constructed, the bands contributing $19,000.00 and Parliament $2,500.00.
In 1898 Parliament voted $3,300.00 to cover the cost of other additions and improvements and in 1900 the interested bands were assessed for $3,600.00 for a similar purpose.
Last Session Parliament voted $2,500.00 for improvements, repairs, etc., the cost of which, according to the account rendered by the Principal, exceeds the grant by only $30.54.
It will thus be seen that since 1896 the Indians have paid $32,600.00 and the Department, from Legislative Grants, $8,300.00, for the buildings. Both the Department and the Indians have contributed liberally towards the support of this institution and the particulars of the alleged financial straits are wanting to substantiate the Principal's case. The per capita grant is $60.00 for 100 pupils and without a very full statement of the case being submitted to the Department by the Principal I would hesitate about recommending increased financial assistance.

Indian Affairs. (FO 1C, Volume 6205, file 468-5, part 1)
Regarding the land connected with the Institution, I beg leave to say that the school authorities have been in possession for many years of four acres and 200 acres surrendered and used for the purposes of the school. In addition to these the school has under lease 275½ acres, is using 30 acres of unsurrendered Indian lands and has applied to lease 100 acres, making a total of 607½ acres.

With reference to the water supply, Mr. George's predecessor found no fault with this either as to quantity or quality, and in his last annual report there is nothing to show that the supply of water was not satisfactory, in fact his reports are the other way.

The buildings would appear from the report to have a fairly good supply of fire appliances, such as extinguishers, etc., and besides this a very heavy insurance is carried, $36,100.00, probably two-thirds of the value.

This Institution has run along from year to year and in so far as it is a going concern has been practically self sustaining. I really do not see how much more the Department or the Indians can be expected to do under the circumstances and no satisfactory reasons are given for an increase in the per capita grant. It may be considered that the Principal should either visit Ottawa and take the matter up in detail here or if not he should be asked to

Indian Affairs. (RG 1C, Volume 6205, file 468-5, part 1)
prepare a fully detailed report setting forth the particulars of the needs of the Institution.

If the per capita grant is raised for the Mount Elgin Institute we will undoubtedly be asked for a similar increase for the other Industrial Schools of this Province.

Ottawa, February 18th, 1904.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your favour of the 11th ultimo, with reference to the Mount Elgin Industrial Institute, in which you indicate the financial and other difficulties confronting you in regard to the successful conduct of your work as Principal of that Institute.

I have given the subject matter of your letter careful consideration and while desirous of promoting the efficiency of this school, in so far as doing so is reasonably incumbent on this Department, I am as yet unable to determine exactly, from your letter, to what degree or in what particular assistance is necessary.

The Mount Elgin Industrial School, erected some fifty years ago, cost originally about $3,600.00, contributed by the Chippewas, Norwegians and the Mississaugans Indians.

Reverend T. T. George,
Principal, Mt. Elgin Industrial Institute,

In 1896 a new main building was constructed, the bands contributing $10,000.00 and Parliament $3,500.00; in 1898 Parliament voted $3,300.00 for additions and improvements and in 1900 the interested bands were assessed $3,800.00 for a similar purpose. Last session Parliament voted $2,500.00 for improvements, repairs, etc., and the accounts which you have rendered in connection with the grant exceed it by only $30.54. These contributions since 1896 thus amount to $23,600.00 by the Indians and $8,500.00 by Parliament and in addition there is the per capita grant of $60.00 for 100 pupils.

In so far as the land question is concerned, I find that there are 204 acres surrendered and used for the purposes of the school, 273½ acres under lease, 30 acres of unsubmitted Indian land used by the school and that application has been made to lease 100 acres, which, if favourably dealt with, would make a total of 607½ acres available.

As to the water supply, the information in the possession of the Department, based very largely upon the annual reports of the school, would show that this is satisfactory both as to quantity and quality.
I quite agree with you that fire protection is essential in connection with these institutions but I understand that the Institute has a fairly good supply of fire extinguishers, etc., and there is carried also an insurance of $36,100.00.
