Memorandum:

The Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to the application made by the Principal of the Mount Elgin Industrial School through the Rev. Dr. Sutherland, General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, for a grant of $3,000.00 to carry out certain improvements and repairs in connection with that Institution; I beg to say that when I visited this School in July last I found that, while the new Principal had been carrying out extensive improvements and repairs to the barns, fences and drainage and water supply for the past two years costing $6,166.91, he had done nothing to provide for the comfort of the pupils.

The boys' playhouse, for the repair of which $1200.00 is now asked, was in a most deplorable condition; it was bad enough when I was at the School in 1902, and, as nothing had been done in the meantime to improve it, it had gone from bad to worse until now it is totally unfit for habitation during the winter months and unless it is thoroughly overhauled and supplied with a heating plant and appliances for washing it would be cruel to the boys to expect them to pass another winter in it. They perform their ablutions at the pump in the summer and bathe in the river occasionally and I am at a loss to know how they manage in the winter.

This building, which is the oldest on the premises, consists of two stories and a basement and a stone foundation, is forty feet by twenty-eight feet and the
rooms are nine feet, six inches high.

The old furnace is completely worn out and should be replaced by a new one. Stationary basins and at least two bath tubs should be supplied. The concrete flooring should be repaired and the brick casing around the old boiler removed, and entrance to the basement should be from the first story instead of from the outer door as at present, which is below ground.

The building wants reflooring as there were broken boards which have been patched by laying other boards on top. The walls should be reshaped on the inside and the whole building repainted.

If it is decided to do anything to this building the Principal should be asked to give a detailed estimate.

With regard to the laundry, for which $1,000.00 is asked, although the repairs are needed, there is no such immediate demand for their being made as for the boys' building and the overhauling of the girls' playroom, which contains a lavatory and bathroom and is situated in the basement of the main building. I consider it a mistake to place the lavatory and bath in the playroom, as the constant slopping of water on the floor keeps it damp and unwholesome. There would be no difficulty in finding room for a lavatory immediately in rear of the playroom, and I think that in its present condition it is anything but a suitable place for the girls to spend so much of their time. The room certainly needs to be changed and I think the Department should ask for a detailed estimate of the cost of these improvements.

The Mount Elgin Institute has been carried on under the control of the Methodist Church since 1851 and large amounts have been expended on buildings, nearly all of
of which has been provided for by the Indians by assessment on Indian funds aided by small Parliamentary votes. The Methodist Missionary Society have contributed in the way of improvements, most of which has been given during the past two years, and they do not feel disposed to let Rev. Mr. George expend any more money at present. It would be a hard matter to call upon the Indians to make any further contributions, and, as there is no doubt about the immediate necessity for these repairs, the Department should provide the necessary funds.

Attached to this memorandum are copies of Financial Statements of this School for the years ended the 30th June, 1904, and 30th June, 1905, which were furnished me by Mr. Shannon, the auditor and accountant of the Methodist Missionary Society.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 12th #15500/3 respecting certain repairs and improvements at the Mount Royal Industrial Institute, and enquiring if the Missionary Society would advance the necessary amount with the understanding that it would be recouped by the Department from next year's school appropriations. As some of the repairs and improvements appear to be of a very urgent nature, I beg to say that we will advance the necessary funds for these.

I have instructed the Principal, the Rev. T. T. George, to report to the Department from time to time the work done on the various repairs and improvements, and with a detail of expenditure thereon. I understand that some of the work cannot be done this autumn, but Mr. George is instructed to undertake what is most urgent and let the rest stand over until next spring.

We had a memorandum some time ago of the various repairs and improvements asked for, which I think aggregated three thousand (3000) dollars or over. You do not say if all these are included in your request to us, and I shall be glad, therefore, of an indication of the limits to which we would be justified in making advances.

I have the honor to be,

Very obedient servant,

C. W. Macdonald

The Secretary,

Thus the work involves the change of certain sewer connections in the school hall & the fact whether I found it impracticable to go on with this business. I have enclosed the pipe house-pan & pipe for the house on an upper floor of white maple from which I took off two coats of old paint but the windows have not been given our so far as possible. In other words, I believe, if I were able to get started on the cement work where they can be completed the work would have advanced or for no practicable.
